PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the proposed Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 will endanger the Federal system in Australia, the State and Federal criminal justice systems, the State and Federal Police Force, the State and Federal education systems, the independence of the churches and religious associations, marriage and the family, children, the unborn, the handicapped, the aged and the infirm, employer and employee relationships and Australian society generally.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
That your Honourable House defer debate on the Bill for twelve months and circulate the Bill for twelve months for the widest possible debate, scrutiny and discussion.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Schemes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
That many Australian wage and salary earners and self-employed persons do not enjoy secure retirement incomes provided by superannuation; and

That the Government issued in December 1985 Guidelines for the implementation of the proposed productivity decision by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and draft Operation Standards for Superannuation schemes.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government:
1. Guarantees to every employee the right and freedom to select the superannuation scheme of his/her choice.
2. Protects the individual exercising that freedom of choice from any coercion, influence or other pressure which may be applied by any employer, association or trade union.
3. Will recognise only those schemes which provide genuine superannuation and reject those schemes which do not provide for-
preservation of benefits to retirement
vesting of employer contributions
equal employer and employee Trusteeship control to ensure security of investments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That all legitimate business expenses incurred in earning or producing assessable income should be allowable deductions.
That the proposed Capital Gains Tax is an unwarranted burden on the rural and small business sector, which will severely affect its long-term viability.

That the delay by the Government in introducing the legislation into Parliament, full details of which still had not been revealed after it had legally been in operation for more than six months, has caused confusion and hindered farmers and small business people in the organisation of their affairs.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government introduces the Capital Gains Tax legislation without delay and that the Australian Democrats join with the Opposition to defeat the proposed legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth that whereas:
1. The present Australian national flag is not distinctively and uniquely Australian and is confused with other national flags.
2. The people of Australia have never had an opportunity to express their views on an appropriate Australian national flag in a referendum.
3. The present Australian national flag does not properly represent Australia as a sovereign, independent nation.
4. The present Australian national flag falsely proclaims Australia as a colony, homeland, protectorate, dominion or government department of Great Britain.
5. The first condition in the flag competition of 1901 required that the design should show Australia's loyalty to the British Empire. The British Empire no longer exists.
6. A public opinion poll held in 1984 using the Gallup Method revealed that 52% of Australians surveyed wanted a competition for a new design for the Australian flag.
7. There is no inherent link between Australia proclaiming a unique and distinctive flag and the political issue of Australia moving to a republican form of government.
8. The adoption of a truly Australian national flag would serve as a focal point for Australia's bicentennial celebrations in 1988.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable house will:
(a) Appoint a Committee of the Parliament with representatives from both Houses and all parties to invite and consider proposals for the design of a new Australian national flag, and

(b) Require that Committee to make recommendations on the form of a minimum cost referendum at the time of the next general elections, in which the electors will be given the opportunity to vote for a flag from a selection of at least three designs which will include the present Australian national flag and the winner of the Ausflag-Bulletin-2MMM.FM competition of March 1985.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Hail Mary
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned in the State of Queensland respectfully showeth:
That the film `Hail Mary' is pornographic and blasphemous and gravely offends our religious beliefs and those of the vast majority of Australian christians.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Parliament will respect the will of the undersigned and have the pornographic and blasphemous film `Hail Mary' banned in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights: Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows: That we oppose utterly the proposed Australian Bill of Rights because the Bill will-
limit rather than protect the rights and freedoms of Australians
set up a coercive and powerful Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission that will operate contrary to the individuals' rights and freedoms
endanger our Federal System by its improper intrusion into States rights.
Your petitioners therefore pray: that the Senate rejects the Australian Bill of Rights Bill and all cognate Bills.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights: Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Bill
1. Offer nothing more than is already available under Common Law,
2. Deny some Human rights and do not include others,
3. Give dangerously wide powers to an unelected body, and
4. Could cause far more damage than they could possibly cure.
Your petitioners request that the Senate should: Completely reject both the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack-itself the creation of 3 Christian crosses represents the nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law.
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901 and each point depicting a State and the Territories of the Commonwealth.
3. They know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to its form or to its acceptance as the sole Australian National Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should ensure that the existing Australian national flag remains sacrosanct from change and remains the sole national flag.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: African National Congress and South West Africa People's Organisation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: the petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth: that the humble petitioners respectfully believe that the representatives in Australia of the African National Congress and South West Africa Peoples Organisation should not have to suffer unending financial problems related to the cost of rent, food and clothing, and the maintenance of two small offices run on the most austere basis.
Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should urge the provision of:
1. Official recognition of A.N.C. and S.W.A.P.O. as the legitimate representatives of the people of South Africa and Namibia.
2. Financial support to the offices and representatives of the African National Congress and the South West Africa Peoples Organisation to promote the anti-Apartheid cause.
3. Additional financial support for the official representatives of the A.N.C. and S.W.A.P.O. to assist the humanitarian needs of Namibian and South African refugees who are victims of Apartheid.
4. Scholarships for South African and Namibian refugees. These to be provided through the A.N.C. and S.W.A.P.O. education departments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That human embryos deserve legal protection to enable the development of their full human potential.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should: Pass Senator Harradine's Bill to prohibit experiments involving the use of human embryos created by in vitro fertilization.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth concern over Plant Variety Rights (PVR) legislation. We agree that:
1. PVR will inhibit the free exchange of genetic material for plant breeding.
2. PVR will not enhance Australia's access to plant varieties developed overseas but will encourage the dumping of unsuitable varieties on the Australian market.
3. PVR will restrict the public plant breeding program to basic research for exploitation by private enterprise and discourage breeding for disease and pest resistant varieties.
4. PVR will lead to the domination of the seed industry by foreign interests not responsible to the Australian people.
5. The proprietary rights granted by PVR will encourage the introduction of seed distribution and marketing monopolies and lead to seed price increases.
Your petitioners therefore pray that parliament refrains from enacting any legislation on PVR.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Youth Coalition for Housing: Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth that:

We, the undersigned, representing youth housing organizations, residents of housing services and interested people call on the Government to provide appropriate, adequate and ongoing funding for the National Youth Coalition for Housing.
1. In the first instance the provision of an additional $45,000 is needed by May 1986 to prevent the imminent closure of the Coalition due to inadequate funding for the 1985-86 year.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That we strongly support ``The A.C.T. Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Bill'' introduced by Senator Evans, because it represents the first positive national step towards the eventual elimination of wide-spread serious ill health caused by smoking tobacco.

SPEECH.PARA: In November 1985 the Government agreed to provide $30m to enable the construction and fit-out of the building for the Australian National Maritime Museum on a site at Darling Harbour provided by the New South Wales Government. The Federal Government will own and operate the Museum which will be the first national collecting institution to be located outside Canberra. The Government is committed to the Museum opening its doors to the public in 1988. The need for an Australian National Maritime Museum, reflecting the significance of maritime activity in the history and cultural life of Australians, was recognised over a decade ago in the report of the Pigott Committee of Inquiry on Museums and National Collections. Possibly no other country has relied more on the sea and acknowledged this debt less. The present Government has affirmed the need for an institution to provide Australians with a central and comprehensive record of their past and present dependence on the sea. The Australian National Maritime Museum will provide a focus for our maritime history and an insight to its visitors of a major facet of our cultural tradition, until now little acknowledged.

The Bill will establish the Museum as a body corporate and its functions will be to develop Australia's national maritime collection; to preserve, acquire, recover and maintain maritime historical material and exhibit that material which is in the national maritime collection or otherwise both in Australia and overseas. The Museum will also be able to conduct, and assist in research and to disseminate information relating to Australian maritime history.

Maritime historical material is defined in the Bill to mean material relating to Australian maritime history. Australian maritime history is widely defined to include the natural history of Australia, the history of the interaction of human beings with the Australian marine environment, and the history of sea travel for every purpose. The reference to Australian marine environment includes the sea above the continental shelf and the sub-soil of the continental shelf adjacent to the Australian coast. It also includes the environment of the lakes, rivers and internal waters of Australia. This allows the Museum effectively to acquire any material of a maritime nature provided it has a connection with Australia. I hope there is enough room in the place. A Museum Council is established by this Bill. The Council will ensure the proper and efficient performance of the Museum and determine its policy, subject to ministerial direction. I will speak shortly about its constitution.

The Bill empowers the Museum to develop a national collection of maritime historical material which shall be determined by its Council as being included in the national maritime collection. Any such determination by its Council shall be based upon criteria and made in accordance with guidelines approved by the Minister. The Bill provides for the Museum to purchase historical and other relevant material. It will accept gifts and bequests and it will acquire and operate vessels of historical interest and significance. It will collect maritime information in various forms, such as books, charts, manuscripts, log books, films, videotapes and sound recordings. The Museum will be subject to the law of copy right and to the laws relating to the preservation and use of archival resources, and to the rights of the public to have access to official documents of the Commonwealth Government and its agencies.

Much of Australia's historical material reflecting the involvement of its people with the sea has never been exhibited on a large scale. The creation of this Museum will correct that. The Government intends that the displays for the Museum will be based on a series of exciting and dramatic themes dealing with particular aspects of our links with the sea and Australian waterways. It will not be a mere collection of inanimate objects. It will be a place of public education, participation and enjoyment for all who enter-a dynamic, living complex of activities and interests.

The Bill is expressed to apply not only to the Australian mainland but also to its external territories, past and present. This is to ensure both the comprehensiveness of the national maritime collection and the respect accorded the heritage and culture of Australia's external territories. Material of significance from Australian external territories in the Pacific, Indian and Southern Oceans and Antarctica would be transferred to the national maritime collection only after consultation with the Minister for Territories or the Minister for Science, as the case may be, and the local governing body of the relevant Territory.

Whilst the Museum as a Government institution will be funded through the annual budgetary processes the Bill also provides for the establishment of a National Maritime Museum Fund which will consist of money, or money from the disposal of gifts, bequests and the assignment of property-otherwise than on trust-to raise money for disbursement in accordance with the functions of the Museum. The Museum will be able to charge an admission fee and to operate a broad range of commercial activities. The Museum is required under the proposed legislation to prepare annual estimates of expenditure and shall not enter a contract for an acquisition exceeding $100,000 without the Minister's approval. The Museum will be subject to audit by the Auditor-General and will also be obliged to prepare an annual report by virtue of being subject to certain provisions of the Audit Act 1901. The Museum will not be subject to taxation under Commonwealth or State law. The Museum will be able to operate a restaurant and catering facilities on vessels or property which the Museum owns or controls, and for this reason the Bill provides for the Museum to supply liquor.

The Council of the Museum which I referred to earlier shall consist of a chairperson, the director and other members, appointed by the Governor-General, to be no fewer than seven nor more than ten. An appointed member is to be a person having knowledge and experience with respect to matters relating to Australian maritime history or such other areas of know-ledge relevant to the affairs of the Museum. The day-to-day management of the Museum will be conducted by a director who shall also be appointed by the Governor-General for a period of up to seven years. The director shall have all the powers of a secretary of a department in relation to the staff of the Museum who will be employed under the Public Service Act. The management of the Museum by the director will be subject to directions given, and policies formulated by, the Council. The Museum will be encouraged by the Government to adopt an entrepreneurial outlook in organising its activities. For example, I would expect that the theatre proposed to be included in the Museum will be available for use by outside groups for film screenings, seminars and lectures. A publishing program will be developed and the Museum shop will sell books, toys and a whole range of quality goods and souvenirs.

In addition to the Museum's attraction and effect on tourism it also will support a number of people in related professions, trades and ser-vices. Its establishment and work will help to revive traditional maritime crafts and provide opportunities to pass on skills which would other-wise be lost. It is the Government's intention that the Museum place special emphasis on the young. This will be reflected in the practical exhibits, educational and other facilities, in the focus of a section of the library on material for younger readers and on the goods for sale in the Museum shop. The Museum's curatorial and conservation laboratories will also be designed so that visitors can view the activities there, to see not only the skills required in preservation and in mounting displays, but also to appreciate the effort and expense incurred in preserving our maritime heritage.

I would like to stress the national emphasis of the Maritime Museum; it will neither compete with existing institutions in the States or Territories nor duplicate their efforts; rather it will complement the collections of those institutions. The establishment of the Australian National Maritime Museum by this Bill is a further development in this Government's unequalled record of achievement in the preservation and display of Australia's heritage. This record reflects the aspirations and concerns of the Australian people and their enhanced pride in their history and development. The National Maritime Museum will take its place alongside our other national cultural institutions as a lasting, living, record of the richness and diversity of our past and present achievements as a maritime nation. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to order of the Senate of 14 April 1986, the resumption of the debate shall be an order of the day for the first day of sitting in August 1986.

That Business of the Senate, Notice of Motion No. 1, standing in my name relating to the disallowance of the Motor Traffic (Amendment) Ordinance 1986, be postponed till five sitting days from today.

DEBATE.TITLE: PROTECTION OF THE SEA (PREVENTION OF POLLUTION FROM SHIPS) AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 March, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —With due respect to the desire of the Senate for a speedy progress of the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Amendment Bill 1986 and with due regard to the significance of the legislation I advise that the Opposition supports the Bill. I will be brief. The purpose of the Bill is to extend the control of pollutant discharges from Australian ships on the high seas to include Australian ships in Australian territorial waters and, generally, to strengthen pollution control in our territorial sea and coastal waters. This Bill will enable early ratifications of the International Maritime Organisation Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships, or the MARPOL Convention as it is more commonly known.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition parties support this legislation as they supported the 1983 Bill. In fact, the coalition Government introduced such high seas legislation in 1982, but it lapsed with the 1983 election. The present Government passed the legislation in 1983. Since then, the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen), has told us that he has been encouraging the States to pass the complementary legislation for the territorial seas. The Minister in his second reading speech said that he was not prepared to wait any longer for the States, that he warned the States of his intention to proceed with this legislation, and that there had been no adverse reaction from them. He also stated that there is a saving clause which will ensure that State legislation overrides the Federal legislation when a particular State passes its own. The Minister also stated that he wanted the MARPOL coverage completed, so that Australia could ratify the Convention to ensure the early and adequate protection of particular environmentally sensitive areas such as the Great Barrier Reef.

I am pleased to say that my own State, Tasmania, has already indicated that appropriate legislation will be introduced this year. I am particularly pleased because Tasmania has rich and important fishing grounds which are expanding all the time and which need the type of protection provided by the MARPOL Convention. As an island Tasmania has a very active dependence on shipping. Tasmanian ports continue to show big increases in the numbers of ships and the amount of cargo being handled. It is, therefore, important that this growing number of ships does not threaten our marine resources. It is also satisfying to me, as it should be to all honourable senators, that the saving provisions have been included so that the States will retain their traditional control over coastal waters.

While States rights have not always been respected by this Government, I must acknowledge that on this occasion the States have been looked after. The legislation continues the bipartisan concern for the preservation of Australia's marine and coastal environment which has been evident for years and to which the Minister referred in his speech. The Opposition supports the Bill but not the proposed Australian Democrats amendments. There are several good reasons why we cannot accept these amendments. First, the matter of radioactive waste is more properly the province of the sea dumping legislation which we have seen and which will be introduced into this chamber in the next session. Secondly, the Bill is the means of facilitating the ratification of the MARPOL Convention. Radioactive waste is not part of the MARPOL Convention. It is dealt with in a separate international convention known as the London Dumping Convention. If the Democrats had done their homework they would not have even considered these amendments in light of the above. I guess they will bring the amendments forward again when the next piece of legislation, the appropriate one, comes up in the next session. Thirdly, no Australian ships are nuclear powered, so the second amendment is irrelevant. Fourthly, by specifying areas of effect, the amendments will override the saving provisions of the Bill. This is a direct contravention of the integrity of the States. Significantly, the two areas referred to are Queensland and Tasmanian waters. The Democrats have shown that they regularly are prepared to override the States powers, so the Opposition will not support their amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the Government on the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Amendment Bill 1986. The sea, for too long, has been used as a bottomless garbage dump. Radioactive, toxic and environmentally destructive waste has been willy-nilly dumped or spilled into the sea. The passage of this Bill will allow Australia to ratify the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships 1973 as amended by the protocol related to the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships 1978. The Australian Democrats are eagerly awaiting the sea-dumping Bill which will complement this legislation. This Convention and the protocol for preventing marine pollution are known as MARPOL. Ratifying these would extend the MARPOL Convention to Australian vessels world wide and to foreign vessels in Australian waters. By regulating the discharge of waste from ships, the Convention reduces pollution levels in coastal waters. By setting higher construction standards for oil tankers, the Convention also diminishes the probability of accidental waste discharges.

SPEECH.PARA: MARPOL was ratified in 1983 by the necessary 15 countries, which incidentally represent more than 50 per cent of the world's gross shipping tonnage. These countries were Liberia, Colombia, Denmark, France, West Germany, Greece, Italy, Norway, Peru, Sweden, Tunisia, the United Kingdom, the United States of America, Uruguay and Yugoslavia. However, Australia so far has not ratified the Convention and this Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Amendment Bill 1986 does this. It is deplorable that Australia should be so far behind other nations in ratifying this important international agreement. It has not been possible to ratify MARPOL because of the need for complementary legislation from the States, as Senator Archer mentioned. This legislation would cover territorial waters inside the three-mile limit. This Bill introduces Commonwealth legislation which will cover those State waters until State Acts of parliament override these provisions.

The Bill is urgent because the penalties which can be imposed under the MARPOL Convention are very real deterrents against foreign ships dumping pollutant wastes in our coastal waters. Ratification of the MARPOL Convention is urgent so that we will have a real measure of protection for our marine environment. However, the MARPOL Convention currently fails to provide adequate protection to Australia's sensitive Great Barrier Reef and Bass Strait waters and this Bill also fails to extend its protection to these areas. The MARPOL Convention also fails to give adequate protection from the dumping of radioactive waste in the sea. This is because certain of the ratifying countries had an interest in excluding such provisions from the MARPOL Convention. Nuclear-powered ships of the United States of America in particular have been identified as causing considerable radioactive contamination in the ports they visit but they have refused to accept any responsibility for this contamination. The London convention on dumping waste at sea mentioned by Senator Archer does cover the subject of radioactivity. The accidental or deliberate discharge of operational radioactive waste is not covered under the MARPOL Convention. We believe that the Government should move to try to add this to the Convention.

In the meantime, I propose to move amendments to this Bill to protect waters of the Great Barrier Reef and Bass Strait and to prohibit the discharging of radioactive waste in any of our coastal waters. Coastal waters are the most productive areas of the ocean. They are rich in minerals and nutrients and therefore support the basic organisms at the bottom of the food chain. These organisms, in turn, support a rich marine life in the coastal waters and support our fishing industry. Any pollutants in these coastal waters are thus concentrated in the fish we eat and poison the water so that the fish numbers are severely depleted in some cases. It is both economically and environmentally important to protect our coastal waters from all forms of damaging pollution, and particularly from cumulative poisons and long-lasting radioactive substances.

The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation described many of the hazards of oil pollution in its report `Oil spills-Prevention and Control of Oil Pollution in the Marine Environment' in 1978. It listed five main dangers from oil pollution: Firstly, the coating of birds, plants and fish larvae with oil, which causes suffocation and death of these particular things. Secondly, toxic components of oil are indeed lethal to a number of living things, even in very small quantities. Thirdly, oil pollution alters marine and coastal habitats, which causes disruption to the often fragile ecosystems, particularly in areas such as our Great Barrier Reef. Fourthly, hydrocarbons accumulate in the water and the soils in the seabed, placing sensitive marine species under stress. Fifthly, oil pollution alters behavioural responses to factors such as colour, smell or other environmental characteristics which are deleteriously changed, and can have a serious effect on the tourist industry, for example. All of these effects of oil pollution destroy marine life and are particularly damaging to protected waters. It is also true that other pollutants have these effects, and they are covered in separate schedules in the report.

The Great Barrier Reef is especially protected by MARPOL but this protection does not extend sufficiently to cover the area which is at risk. The reef is the world's largest and most complex expanse of coral. Many unique forms of marine life make the reef their home. It is the most biologically diverse ecosystem known to man and is a product of millions of years of evolution. We are the custodians of that beautiful part of our coastline. There are 1500 species of fish and about 400 species of coral in the reef, as well as many other groups of animals and plants, including two endangered species of turtle and the threatened dugong. I seek leave to incorporate a succinct statement on the importance of the reef from the application to place it on the World Heritage list.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
Nomination of The Great Barrier Reef by the Commonwealth of Australia for inclusion in the World Heritage List.

The Great Barrier Reef provides some of the most spectacular scenery on earth and is of exceptional natural beauty. The Great Barrier Reef provides major feeding grounds for large populations of the endangered species Dugong dugon and contains nesting grounds of world significance for the endangered turtle species green turtle (Chelonia mydas) and loggerhead turtle (Caretta caretta).
The Great Barrier Reef thus meets all four criteria set out in Article 2 of the World Heritage Convention:
(i) being an outstanding example representing a major stage of the earth's evolutionary history;
(ii) being an outstanding example representing significant ongoing geological processes, biological evolution and man's interaction with his natural environment;
(iii) containing unique, rare and superlative natural phenomena, formations and features and areas of exceptional natural beauty; and
(iv) providing habitats where populations of rare and endangered species of plants and animals still survive.
The area nominated is of outstanding universal value on the basis of its natural heritage and in recognition of this Governments have acted, and will continue to act, to preserve these features.
The area nominated also meets the condition of integrity in that it includes the areas of the sea adjacent to the Reef.

The area of this nomination contains many middens and other archaeological sites of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander origin. There are over 30 historic shipwrecks in the area, and on the islands there are ruins and operating lighthouses which are of cultural and historical significance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The great diversity of life forms make the reef an area of great scientific importance and also of tourist appeal, and as such it deserves very special protection. The research station on Heron Island has already identified 38 species of starfish, 32 species of brittle starfish, 35 species of feather starfish, 107 species of coral, and 931 species of fish, and a number of these are threatened. There are also many examples of plant life and many different species of birds, all within an area of approximately 36 square kilometres of that island.

SPEECH.PARA: The Great Barrier Reef is a major tourist attraction. In 1983-84 tourists spent around 660,000 visitor nights in the area. The millions of dollars spent in the area by tourists each year is indicative of the value of the reef to our country's financial success. It would be economically as well as environmentally disastrous to destroy this asset through pollution. Even the restricted levels of pollutants allowed under the MARPOL Convention could be deadly to the reef, according to scientific advice. The reef is listed on the World Heritage List, but additional steps must be taken to protect the reefs from threats caused by shipping.

Following two recent groundings, the Government has finally agreed to insist that pilots be carried on all vessels over 100 tonnes which are within the reef area, and I commend this. The International Maritime Organisation's safety committee supports this measure. MARPOL and the principal Act being amended by this Bill, the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act 1983, already totally ban any discharge of waste within the reef itself and inside a line that runs down the outer edge of the reef as defined in the Convention and the Act. They prohibit discharge of pollutants within 12 nautical miles of this outer edge of the reef. Outside this area the pollutant concentration must be less than 100 parts per million and the waste must not be from an oil tanker. In fact, tankers have a broader berth and can discharge waste only beyond 50 nautical miles from the edge of the reef, and then only if the pollutant concentration is less than 33 parts per million and the flow is more than 60 litres per nautical mile. There are similar provisions for discharge of noxious bulk liquids from ships.

The difficulty with existing limits is that winds, tides and currents carry discharges within 60 nautical miles of the reef along and towards the reef because of the particular patterns of the sea. While the rate of discharge of pollutants is controlled, there is no limit on the number of ships which may discharge waste within an area over a limited period. The combined discharges of several ships can multiply the damage caused. Jointly, they can cause considerable damage to the reef by discharging their waste within the 12 nautical mile limit and having those wastes carried on to the reef. Small spills or operational discharges can be devastating to the fragile ecosystem.

Although oil pollution is generally perceived by ordinary people as massive oil slicks from super-tankers, the major source of pollution and damage comes from very small spills. However, the effects are cumulative. The accumulation of hydrocarbons over time is very damaging to marine life and a massive spill can coat thousands of birds. We hope that this will never happen. If it does we will have real problems. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation said in its report on oil spills that it was probable that most of the oil spilled in the sea originated from a large number of small spills rather than small numbers of large spills. The report said that it was evident that regular numbers of small spills caused more environmental damage than occasional large spills. I draw that to the attention of the Opposition. There is also a real risk of damage from large accidental spills which would aggravate the effects of the existing numbers of small planned spills. There is no justification for allowing preventable discharges so close to the Great Barrier Reef.

For these reasons the Australian Democrats will move an amendment to the Bill to extend the protected area beyond the reef to 60 nautical miles from its outer edge. We propose to add new section 8a which moves the line defining the outer edge of the reef, defined in the principal Act as `nearest land', one degree east of its current position, which will correspond to adding approximately an extra 60 nautical miles of protection beyond the reef. This increased protection beyond the reef will considerably reduce the amount of pollution which can actually reach the reef through tides, winds and currents and through the carrying of polluted waters back on to the reef. Hence, the risk to the rich marine life in this area will be much reduced.

In the case of Bass Strait the controlled dumping of oil from machinery spaces, bunkers and even tanks is allowed currently under the MARPOL Convention in regions away from land. However, there is very little escape of pollutants from Bass Strait which means that we can get high accumulations of hydrocarbons. Already in certain areas around the oil stations there is prohibition of dumping. Throughout the world all closed seas, such as the Mediterranean Sea, the Black Sea, the Baltic Sea, the Red Sea and the Arabian Gulf area, are declared areas of special consideration. Australia has not been strong enough in pushing for Bass Strait to be considered such a closed sea area. The shape of Bass Strait justifies it being so considered. The areas within have special oceanographical and ecological conditions plus certain sorts of traffic as described in schedule 1 of the Act. The Great Barrier Reef is protected to the same extent under the MARPOL Convention by extending the land limit out beyond the outer edge of the reef. We believe that it is extremely important that Bass Strait should be so protected because of the life forms along the Victorian and Tasmanian coasts.

The Australian Democrats will move an amendment to prohibit the dumping of pollutants into Bass Strait. This narrow enclosed strait is Australia's busiest shipping lane and carries the largest concentration of vessels anywhere around Australia. The many oil platforms in the protected area further restrict passage through the strait while posing a considerable threat in themselves. Bass Strait is a rich fishing ground which is extremely vulnerable to pollution, especially pollution of its bottom sediments which would affect the bottom feeder fish and shellfish which are so highly prized and appreciated by Australia's export markets. The Bass Strait marine area is a prime tourist attraction. The devastation that could be caused by oil pollution to our fairy penguins and the Australian fur seal colonies as well as other Antarctic and temperate marine life would seriously affect tourism in the area. The long term damage of oil, even in small quantities, to the wetlands bordering Bass Strait must also be taken into account and acted upon. These wetlands are the major source of food, shelter and breeding sites for many of the young fish, birds and animals in the area. It is vital to protect this strait, which is both our busiest shipping lane and a unique sheltered area bordering the Southern Ocean.

I now turn to radioactive substances. The Australian Democrats will move an amendment to prevent the dumping of radioactive waste in Australian coastal waters and to prevent Australian ships from dumping radioactive waste in coastal waters anywhere in the world. The Democrats' amendment defines a substance as radioactive if it emits radiation in excess of 350 becquerels per kilogram-that is, more than 350 emissions of radioactive counts per second per kilogram of the substance. Radioactivity is an insidious destroyer of the environment. Through genetic mutation it affects the inheritance of life for all future generations of affected organisms. The sea is a major source of food for humans as well as other animals. Radioactive pollution of our seas is a real potential hazard for thousands of years to come. The MARPOL Convention and the principal Act, which this Bill amends, already recognise the extreme threat of certain chemicals to the world's seas and seek to minimise these risks. The Australian Democrats are seeking to include radioactive materials amongst the dangerous chemicals which are controlled under our local Act. Basically, we are putting the criteria of the London Convention into our Act. There is no reason why the Prevention of Pollution from Ships Bill should not extend the provisions to include the London Convention for radioactive dumping. Why should we have to wait for that to happen?

In conclusion, I commend the Government for at last biting the bullet and ratifying the MARPOL Convention on Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) and for providing interim cover for the States until they get their acts together. However, the Australian Democrats consider that Australian interests would be much better served by providing full protection for the Great Barrier Reef and the Bass Strait areas. The Australian Democrats also consider that this Bill should prevent the dumping of radioactive material in Australian coastal waters. If the Government is dinkum about wanting a nuclear-free zone in the Pacific, it must surely want to keep Australian shores clear of nuclear and radioactive waste. One thing which disturbed me was that the Government said originally that it would support these amendments but, because the House of Representatives is not coming back, the Government has withdrawn from this agreement. I believe that treating the legislation in this way is quite unreasonable. I note that the Opposition also will not support our amendments. If it is true that the Government will not support our amendments, I am appalled that such an event as the House of Representatives getting up earlier than the Senate should prevent us making reasonable and sensible amendments to the Bill, amendments which had been previously agreed on and which would have been passed had this situation not arisen. I bring this to the notice of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government accepts its responsibility for protecting the seas from pollution and for maintaining a balance between the environment and other factors which from time to time put the environment at risk. Of course, maritime pollution has been with us for a long time and, in presenting the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Amendment Bill to the Senate, the Government has adopted a balanced position in meeting its obligations in this area. I can understand the concern expressed by Senator Vigor, but there is no discernible problem apart from projections that from time to time certain developments in respect of the movement of maritime vessels may create problems which would affect the environment. To that extent the Government has taken into consideration the issues that have been raised by Senator Vigor and has presented legislation which it conscientiously believes will protect the environment, fulfil our obligations to the maritime industry and protect our heritage.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments that are to be moved by the Australian Democrats present difficulties from the Government's point of view because they would impose at the national, Federal level principles which have not been negotiated with or agreed to by the States or the industry. Whilst we cannot take away the right of the Democrats to move the amendments as they will do, the Government is of the view that the legislation at least should be given the assent of the Senate. This would give us the opportunity to fulfil our obligation to consider and take into account the various interests with respect to maritime pollution. There has been no discussion with government authorities or the industry of the amendments to be moved by the Democrats.

The Government accepts its obligations to protect the reef. The Great Barrier Reef is an important environmental area. It is common knowledge that both the Opposition and the Government accept our responsibilities in the area. The amendments moved by the Democrats would place extra responsibilities upon the Australian shipping industry and would have no effect upon other ships over whom we have little jurisdiction if they are outside our own waters. I am advised that there does not appear to be any justifiable scientific evidence of the nature to which Senator Vigor referred. In those circumstances the Government is quite justified in saying that the amendments are not acceptable and that they will not significantly change the level of environmental protection afforded in the areas Senator Vigor has referred to, largely Bass Strait and the Great Barrier Reef.

Scientific study has shown that the 50-mile limit gives adequate protection to coastal resources and reefs from operational discharge from oil tankers. The existing regulations or agreements and the principal Act under which we operate with respect to our responsibilities in the area already contain all the protection provisions to which Senator Vigor referred. We do not believe that the amendments will have, therefore, any discernible effect on the environmental quality of the sea. We believe that the legislation will largely protect the environment. It is on that issue that we find ourselves at disagreement with the amendments put forward by the Australian Democrats.

The effect of the first amendment would be to extend the area adjacent to the Great Barrier Reef by a further 60 nautical miles. I do not think Senator Vigor has produced any cogent, acceptable evidence that that will make any great difference to the region or to our responsibilities to the environment. After all, governments are obliged to accept international standards. Governments are obliged to accept scientific evidence, and Governments are obliged to find a balance between competing interests that express themselves from time to time in these matters and, in so doing, put into legislative form the means by which all those interests can be protected. It is a matter of opinion whether the legislation will meet those requirements. It is the Government's view that it will. If it is found by some practice, some event or some incident that there is a deficiency in the legislation, any government would be foolish not to take that evidence or those incidents into account.

We have been regaled by Senator Vigor about the problems of radioactive waste. Neither I nor the Government resile from our responsibilities in these matters. I have been as active as any public figure or private citizen could be in the whole problem of radioactivity over many years. I am not a recent convert and I am not suggesting that others are, but I have been long concerned with that problem. In fact, the Government is on the public record as expressing concern about the dumping of radioactive waste. Whether it be the decision of governments, ship owners or captains of ships, we do not believe that that poses a major problem in respect of the issues that we are currently debating. After all, there is common ground in the Australian community, and indeed in this Parliament, about the Government taking whatever steps are available to it, in line with international conventions and decisions, to protect the Great Barrier Reef. It is one of the great ecological wonders of the world and nobody in this Parliament would resile from his responsibilities to protect that great area. Similarly, of course, we are having regard to the sea between the mainland and Tasmania. We have an obligation there because of the effect that any pollution would have on the beaches, the marine life and the protection of the environment in that region.

The Government is of the view, having considered all the factors, having taken into account all the evidence and having taken into account the international position-the conventions which we are bound to follow-that, nevertheless, the legislation is a step forward. I am sure that Senator Vigor accepts that it is a step forward from where we were. All legislation should be progressive. All legislation should be based on past experience and we should learn from past experience. To that extent we have brought forward legislation that learns from past experience and takes into account the various interests which governments are obliged to consider when they present legislation to the Parliament.

I thank the Opposition for its general support of the Government's position. In fact, I am sure that, in years past, when the previous Government presented legislation dealing with these matters, it enjoyed a measure of support from my Party in respect of its obligations as they were perceived at that time. I am sure that the Opposition would agree that we need to move further down the track of taking whatever steps are humanly possible to protect marine life, to protect the environment of the seas and to protect the Great Barrier Reef. To that extent, the Government has encompassed those objectives in the legislation. It has discussed the matter with the States and the Territories with whom we have not only government to government obligations but also obligations in respect of their approach to their environmental responsibilities and those that are accepted at the national level. I hope the Australian Democrats will appreciate that the Government, in voting against the amendments, has a genuine concern for the protection of the environment, a genuine concern about marine pollution and a genuine concern that we should take every step that is available to government and to the Parliament to enact legislation that protects those various interests. We believe that the legislation meets those requirements.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 5-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Proposed new clause 5a.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 2, after clause 5, insert the following new clause:
`Interpretation
`5a. The Principal Act is amended by adding after section 8 the following section:
``8a. This Part has effect as if-

(a) that part of the line referred to in paragraph (9) of regulation 1 of Annex I to the Convention which is between the point latitude 9*00' South and the point latitude 21*00' South were 1*00' East of the position indicated in that paragraph; and

(b) that part of the sea in Bass Strait which lies between 143*00' East longitude and 149*00' East longitude and which is more than 50 nautical miles from the nearest land were less than 50 nautical miles from the nearest land.''.'.

This is the amendment to protect the Great Barrier Reef that I described in my speech during the second reading debate. I bring to the attention of the Committee that we have moved the line of land one degree east of the current boundary of the Barrier Reef. This one degree east does not correspond exactly to 60 nautical miles. It would be 60 nautical miles at the Equator but around the reef it is somewhere between 50 and 60 nautical miles further out from the edge of the Australian coast. We believe that this will be sufficient to disperse any pollution that would be caused by the dumping of waste from ships and it means that we will have a much bigger buffer zone to handle any spills that may occur. If one is right on the reef the major problem is that any measures taken to counter pollution may be too late. It is extremely important that this amendment to the boundary of the Barrier Reef be supported.

The statements of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) and the Opposition that we should follow the MARPOL Convention and bow to it are quite unsatisfactory in the sense that we are participants in negotiating conventions and we are able to put much more stringent conditions on our shipping than on foreign ships. If we have such stringent conditions on our shipping we have a much stronger bargaining position to negotiate better conditions for future conventions.

I believe that the Government should have welcomed the Australian Democrats' amendment. If the Government did not consult with the major shipping companies, the shipping organisations, the unions and its own Department, I am appalled, because we did. In formulating these amendments I consulted with Australian National Line, with Mr Eccles from the Department of Transport, and with the various maritime unions, all of whom said either that they did not mind and the amendments would not economically affect their operations or that they were very much in favour of them. In fact, the unions said that the conditions that they would like to impose on shipping would be much more stringent than the ones that the Democrats have incorporated into this amendment. It is quite important to note that we have done our homework on these amendments. I will come to that again later when we get on to the amendment dealing with radioactive substances.

It has been said in the past that we can continue to dump material into the sea and it will have no effect. We are now beginning to realise that the sea is just a very small pond in terms of dumping and that dumping has a number of deleterious effects on the biological life that exists in the sea. I believe that we are quite a distance ahead of the Australian Labor Party and miles and miles ahead of the Liberal Party of Australia in terms of trying to protect this very important resource that Australia has. I commend the amendment and I beg the Government and the Opposition to reconsider their position.

With regard to Bass Strait, which is covered in the second part of our amendment, we have said that all of the Bass Strait area between longitude 143 degrees east and 149 degrees east shall be protected. This is the same type of protection as is afforded to the internal seas in all other parts of the world and I do not see why Australia should be disadvantaged by having Bass Strait treated differently from the Black Sea, the Mediterranean Sea, the Caspian Sea and other such areas. I urge the Committee to support this amendment. We will call for a division if it is not supported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issues have been well canvassed in the second reading debate. The proposed amendments seek an extension of the area within which operational discharges from ships are prohibited, largely to cover the Great Barrier Reef and Bass Strait areas. There has been adequate debate. Senator Vigor has not raised any new evidence to support his contention. I do not quarrel with his conviction on the issue but he fails to appreciate that, in the way in which politics and governments operate, the Government has to consult with other organisations and with other authorities. We have come up with amendments to the principal Act which accommodate the various views that have been expressed. I appreciate that they are not acceptable to the Australian Democrats, but they are acceptable to the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That proposed new clause 5a (Senator Vigor's amendment) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses 6 to 10-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Proposed new clause 10a.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 4, after clause 10, insert the following clause:
`10a. After Part III of the Principal Act the following Part is inserted:
``PART IIIa-PREVENTION OF POLLUTION BY RADIOACTIVE SUBSTANCE
Prohibition of discharge of radioactive substances in sea

``26a. (1) Subject to sub-section (3), if any discharge of a radioactive substance, or of a mixture containing a radioactive substance, being a substance or mixture carried as cargo or part cargo in bulk, occurs from an Australian ship into the sea, the master and the owner of the ship are each guilty of an offence punishable, upon conviction, by a fine not exceeding-
(a) if the offender is a natural person-$50,000; or
(b) if the offender is a body corporate-$100,000.
``(2) For the purposes of sub-section (1), `radioactive substance' means a substance having a specific activity greater than 350 becquerels per kilogram.
``(3) Sub-section (1) does not apply to the discharge of a radioactive substance or a mixture from a ship-

(a) into the coastal waters of a State as defined in the Coastal Waters (State Powers) Act 1980 or the coastal waters of the Northern Territory as defined in the Coastal Waters (Northern Territory Powers) Act 1980;
(b) for the purposes of securing the safety of a ship or saving life at sea;

(c) if the substance or the mixture, as the case may be, escaped from the ship in consequence of damage, other than intentional damage, to the ship or its equipment, and all reasonable precautions were taken after the occurrence of the damage or the discovery of the discharge for the purpose of preventing or minimising the escape of the substance or the mixture, as the case may be; or

(d) if the discharge was for the purpose of combating specific pollution incidents in order to minimise the damage from pollution and was approved by a prescribed officer and, where the discharge occurred in the jurisdiction of the government of a country other than Australia, by that government.

``(4) For the purposes of sub-section (3), damage to a ship or to its equipment shall be taken to be intentional damage if, and only if, the damage arose in circumstances in which the master or owner of the ship-
(a) acted with intent to cause the damage; or
(b) acted recklessly and with knowledge that damage would probably result.''.'.

This amendment seeks to insert proposed new clause 10A, which adds the provisions of the London Dumping Convention to the principal Act and ratifies that Convention. The provisions impose very high penalties on people dumping radioactive material into the sea. Admittedly, the provisions relate to operational radioactive substances and currently we do not have nuclear ships. The Australian Democrats are totally against our having nuclear-powered or nuclear-armed ships in Australian waters. There have been enormous problems with radioactivity from American ships in a Japanese port. It was found that the radioactivity levels next to an American submarine were 60 times the levels which should be allowed. The American submarine, which was the only vessel in that area, was nuclear powered, and its captain claimed that this radioactivity had nothing to do with the presence of a nuclear submarine. We believe that it is dangerous for these vessels to enter our waters. Currently we have absolutely no way of charging them for any of the damage which their radioactivity may cause. It is extremely important that we should make certain that ships in our waters-particularly in enclosed waters such as the waters of the Great Barrier Reef and Bass Strait, which by the action of the Government and the Opposition banding together have been left open to the ravages of people dumping material-should be protected, at least from radioactive material.

The amendment we came up with resulted from considerable negotiations and discussions with the Government and was agreed to by both the Department and the Government as being acceptable. It seems very strange that the Government should suddenly change its view, simply, because the House of Representatives is not sitting or because of a change of heart. I believe that the Minister should justify his Government's change of heart, considering that a number of people in the Government's ranks, I believe, are highly supportive of this type of measure. I hope that the Government does see the light, and comes to the party and supports this amendment. If it does not, the Democrats again will be forced to ask for a division on this matter. It is extremely important for all people in Australia-both those who realise the importance of it and the silent majority who rely on the watch-dog role the Democrats are forced to play in this place-to try to protect the environment against the ravages that both the Government and the Opposition allow to happen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The dumping of radioactive wastes, of course, is a very serious issue, but it is covered by the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981. The proposed amendment seeks to cover material carried as bulk cargo which has a radioactivity level of between 35 becquerels per gram, which is the level of activity of natural potassium, and 70 becquerels per gram. I am advised that in regard to substances which have a level of radioactivity above this level, the Dangerous Goods Code imposes standards of packaging, labelling, storage and handling, and that these substances cannot be carried in bulk form. So there are very few commodities which are carried, or are likely to be carried, in ships as bulk cargo which have radioactivity of the level contemplated by Senator Vigor's amendment. It should be remembered that if this amendment were carried-this is the reason why the Government has reservations about it-it would prevent the washing into the sea of the discharge from empty cargo holds which have held cargoes such as superphosphate, phosphate rock and zircon sands. If such waste products are not discharged into the sea outside the 50 nautical mile limit, where do we discharge such waste products? The Government, having taken all those matters into consideration and having expressed its view during the second reading debate, persists with its proposal and the amendment is not accepted.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the proposed new clause 10a (Senator Vigor's amendment) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Gietzelt) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 29 May, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Copyright Amendment Bill, which will amend the Copyright Act. It is supported insofar as it goes, but I register our disappointment and criticism that the Government has not tackled the problem of audio-visual copying on a much greater scale than it has in the Bill. However, the Bill certainly tackles the immediate and critical problem of piracy or intentional infringement of copyright of audio-visual material for commercial purposes. That has been a growing problem for a number of years with increasing improvements in technology in the field. Several years ago amendments were made to the Copyright Act to increase penalties but in more recent years there has been an absolute explosion of piracy, as it is called, in this area. The Government, in this legislation, has sought to deal with the problem. The Opposition believes that the proposals are worthwhile and, hopefully, will be effective.

SPEECH.PARA: Infringement of copyright in this area has been a criminal offence for a long time. However, because of the success of modern technology it has been much more possible to reproduce copies so that no difference can really be detected between the original and the copy, except by experts. This has been a heaven-sent opportunity for the video pirates and the video piracy industry which has developed as a result of these improved techniques. The existing penalties and the existing procedures available for prosecuting these offenders have proved to be inadequate.

This legislation seeks by a series of amendments, which I do not need to detail, to improve the procedures to facilitate proof of infringements, which has been difficult; to introduce a new offence of being in possession of infringing material for the purpose of commercial gain; and to greatly increase penalties in the case of companies to $250,000 maximum and for imprisonment of individuals in certain cases. We believe that this is a worthwhile attempt at tackling this problem.

There are some other matters included in the legislation which I do not propose to go into in any detail, except the problem of broadcasting by the use of satellites. A difficulty which has arisen under the existing Act is the extent to which a broadcast via a satellite comes within the definition of a broadcast within the Copyright Act. Clearly, amendments have to be made to deal with that matter. There is a problem, which I will deal with in the Committee stage, about the way in which those definitions have been adopted by the Government. Concerns have been expressed to the Opposition by the Australian Copyright Council in that respect. However, I will not deal with that matter during the second reading debate.

The main concern of the Opposition is the inadequacy of the Government's response to the whole problem of audio-visual copy. I remind the Senate that in July 1981, when I was the Attorney-General in the Fraser Government, I established a review by the Attorney-General's Department of this particular matter. It was clear in 1981 that there was very widespread concern about the whole problem of copyright and audio-visual material. Home copying and copying for educational purposes were becoming a problem, as well as the piracy of such material for commercial purposes. There were very diverse interests-those of the copyright owners and their representatives on the one hand and those of the growing numbers in the community who want to make use of these new technologies for their own personal purposes, on the other. Home copying of material was a classic example, and still is. However, probably a more urgent problem was that of copying for educational purposes. I can remember it being put to me very strongly at that time that the existing section 202 of the Copyright Act, which permits the making of sound recordings of a radio or television broadcast for educational purposes if the recording was made on behalf of a non-profit educational institution, was a valuable educational tool but that it had become outmoded because of these technological developments and should immediately be extended to provide the same facility for video-copying of television broadcasts, not simply for sound recording. I thought that was an attractive proposition. I had established a general review of audio-visual copyright. I thought that, instead of making some amendment to that legislation ad hoc, so to speak, that would be a matter to be comprehended by this review generally.

It came as a great surprise and certainly as a disappointment that this Bill, coming forward now virtually five years after the departmental review was established in the middle of 1981, does not address this problem at all, even in that narrow sphere. For that reason the Opposition has proposed an amendment, which we will move in the Committee stage, to tackle this problem, albeit admittedly in a very narrow sphere; namely, broadcasts for educational purposes of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation or the Special Broadcasting Service where those bodies actually have the copyright in the material and that material is then used for educational purposes. I would have thought this was a simple matter that could have been dealt with by the Government on that very narrow ground. However, the Opposition believes that it is a matter which should have been dealt with by the Government on a much broader ground. We hope that, if this amendment is favoured by the Senate, the Government will take that as an indication that this Parliament wants the Government to take a more effective and broader approach to this problem than even our amendment would contemplate.

The departmental review which was established in the middle of 1981 provided a very valuable report which caused an issues paper in 1982. The Government has now had this material for four years and has also established a Copyright Law Review Committee under the chairmanship of a distinguished Federal Court judge, Mr Justice Sheppard. That Committee was established in September 1983, nearly three years ago. Armed as the Government has been for the three years it has been in office with this valuable issues paper on this subject and all the submissions that were made available to that departmental review, it is a very considerable failure on the part of this Government that it has not sought, in this legislation, to tackle the problems in any way at all. I think that is a major indictment of the Government's record in this area.

The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), in his second reading speech, made some rather pathetic references to the problem of home copying. He more or less just threw up his hands and said: `Oh well, we will wait and see how this develops in other countries'. He referred to some legislation in various European countries. Since then there has been a very major decision by the Supreme Court in the United States of America in relation to home copying which I do not think the Attorney-General referred to at all, if I recollect his speech. Whether he is aware of it or not, he has done nothing about it. He stands condemned for his failure to tackle this problem, particularly in light of the fact that his own Department did such a valuable and prompt piece of work back in 1981 and the early part of 1982, over four years ago. He has had the material, he has had the opportunities and he has had the assistance of the industry, which co-operated in a magnificent way. The industry was very anxious, of course, to have this matter tackled. It was very pleased when the Fraser Government announced that it was tackling the matter. It co-operated in a most fulsome way. However, industry efforts have been simply ignored and certainly have not had any reward at all. Even if there has been some positive step taken by the Government in regard to this legislation there may still be some justification for delay for further consideration because the subject is very difficult and complicated. I am very well aware of that.

I think that for the Government virtually to have done nothing, achieved nothing and proposed nothing as a result of all these efforts by so many people is a disgraceful abdication of responsibility in this area. Therefore, as I have said, although the Opposition believes that the Bill contains some useful measures, the measures are totally inadequate. The legislation does not pretend even to tackle the broader problems of the new technology in the area of audio visual copyright. For these reasons the Opposition will be moving an amendment, which I have circulated, in the hope that the amendment, narrow and all as it is, will provoke the Government to take some positive steps in the direction of solving these major problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats, of course, welcome this important piece of legislation, the Copyright Amendment Bill 1986, which is before us today. As Senator Durack quite rightly pointed out, the legislation not only is long overdue but also, of course, is based on the work of an internal review committee of the Attorney-General's Department which was established in 1981 when Senator Durack was Attorney-General. I agree too with Senator Durack's comments about the Bill not going far enough. I think that it was the decision of Beaumont J. in 1983 in regard to copying of computer programs that first raised some concerns in this place about that area of piracy. Of course, that has not in any real way been picked up under this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The main purpose of the Bill of course is to amend the Copyright Act to address the appalling growth in piracy of audio visual materials in particular. That is an area which is causing considerable loss to government revenue because the pirates do not contribute in any way to Consolidated Revenue through taxes. Also it is causing considerable losses in the commercial area because people are having their profits cut back by the actions of the pirates. Specific provision is made in prosecution and civil proceedings for proof by affidavit of the subsistence and ownership of copyright. It introduces in prosecutions a more objective test of the defendant's knowledge that the copies dealt with were infringing copies and it creates new offences and substantially increases and provides additional penalties. On both those issues the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills had something to say about the relevant clauses. I will be dealing with that in more detail in a moment. In other areas the Bill deals with increasing access to copyright materials for people with disabilities, for libraries and archives and their clients. It expressly extends the Act to satellite broadcasting. The Bill permits fair dealing in audio visual materials for the purpose of criticism, reviews and reporting news. There are other miscellaneous drafting amendments, of no particular consequence in the main.

This area of the law dealing with the right to own and control the use of the product of one's mind has been severely affected by the impact of technological and scientific change. Indeed, as I said a moment ago, the decision a couple of years back in regard to not being able to copyright computer programs, for example, has caused considerable consternation in the computer area. It has always appeared a little strange to me why, if one's ideas that result in a play, a novel, a short story or poetry or one's ideas that result in a concerto or some other piece of music can be copyrighted, one's ideas that result in a computer program somehow cannot be copyrighted. That seems to be the situation at the moment. It is a situation of considerable concern.

Readily available cheap equipment of course has made it easy to copy audio visual materials at high speed. This poses a threat to the rights of copyright owners. At the same time there has been a remarkable growth in the application of audio visual media material. I point out that it is much harder of course to copy a novel than it is to copy something that has appeared by way of film or documentary on television. The problem is therefore much more one in the audio visual area than it is with regard to the printed medium. At the same time there has been a remarkable growth, as I said, in the application of the audio visual media. This could well mean that schools could be disadvantaged in some ways as a result of this legislation. I refer in particular to the fact that schools are turning more and more to the use of video recorders to assist their students in learning in certain areas. The Opposition will be moving an amendment in regard to this area relating in particular to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service-the two areas to which schools turn most for educational material. Again, I will be talking about that at more length in a moment.

Commercial industry sources estimate that the percentage of Australian homes with television sets that also had video recorders jumped from 11 per cent in 1983 to about 50 per cent in 1985. Wholesale sales of video cassettes for the Australian market rose from some $30m worth to over $100m worth per annum during the same period. The dramatic increase in the number of video outlets provides further evidence of this growth. Of course, that means that piracy is becoming even more lucrative, as well as increasingly possible. The dark side of this change, if I can call it that, and the failure of the law to keep pace, is seen in the spread of video piracy. The sophisticated nature of this industry and the undoubted involvement of organised crime represents an enormous loss to the legitimate industry. As I said earlier, it represents an equally significant loss to Consolidated Revenue. Such piracy is encouraged by the present inadequate penalties and the small outlay required to reap huge profits. As a result, large-scale highly-organised ventures have moved in to exploit the situation. I will give an example of that in a moment.

The Australasian Film and Video Security Office contacted us to express some concerns about the profits inherent in piracy and the problems piracy was causing it.
