It estimated that film and video piracy in Australia represents a loss of something like 20 per cent to the legitimate industry. Not unexpectedly the industry resents that. The Film and Video Security Office gave as an example a case heard at the New South Wales Penrith Court of Petty Sessions on 22 July 1985 when one Peter Warren Consadine of Canberra pleaded guilty to charges relating to offences under the Copyright Act and the Trademarks Act. The offences concerned the selling and offering for sale of counterfeit video copies of the film Police Academy. Any honourable senator who has teenage children will know that that would have proven to have been an extremely lucrative film to pirate because it was one of the most popular for young people at the time. Of the 29 charges of infringing copyright the offender was fined $20 on each charge for a total of $580. On the seven charges relating to trademark breaches he was fined $100 on each count, totalling some $700. The grand total in fines was $1,280.

The Australasian Film and Video Security Office made some extensive investigations into the matter and it was established that well in excess of one thousand counterfeit tapes were distributed. However, even if we just settle for a round thousand tapes being counterfeited for the purposes of this exercise, we come up with some extremely interesting costing. The pirate's cost for one thousand blank tapes at $5 a tape amounts to $5,000. The selling price of one thousand counterfeit tapes of the film Police Academy at $65 each brought in $65,000, leaving at that stage a profit of $60,000. The retailers and traders outlay was $65,000. Fifty rentals at $4.50 for a thousand tapes is another $225,000. The retailer's profits from rentals amounts to $160,000, plus the sale of the tapes to secondhand dealers or to wholesalers at 20c each, which is another $20,000 and gives a total profit for the exercise of something in the vicinity of $180,000. It was pointed out by the Security Office that the secondhand tapes could be rented out at another 30 times each at $2 a time bringing in an additional $60,000. It is an area in which considerable profit is to be made at a very small outlay. On top of this is the fact that there are losses to both the film and video industries through the illegal profit taking on their market, and since the pirates pay no tax or royalties there is considerable loss, as I have already mentioned, to other revenues, and in particular to the government coffers. It is no wonder, given those sorts of profit margins, for the outlays concerned, that the problem of video piracy has proliferated to the extent that it has.

This amending Bill should go some way towards solving the problem. The problem of proof of ownership of copyright material has been addressed, whereby proof of subsistance or ownership may be given by affidavit. It remains to be seen whether this method works in cutting down on time and costs. The difficulty in establishing whether a defendant knew he had in his possession an infringing copy is also addressed. Currently, it is required that the offender knows absolutely that the copies in which he is dealing are infringing copies. Of course, they can open their baby blues wide, shrug their shoulders and assert that they had no knowledge at all and could not have been expected to have had any knowledge that the copies were infringing copies. The particular knowledge test is to be amended to `knows or ought reasonably to know' conditions. On this basis the court can have regard to the circumstances of the alleged criminal act. For example, it might reasonably be inferred that the accused ought reasonably to know if he had acquired the copy at a price considerably below commercial levels. Good fairies in this area do not normally abound. If somebody purchases something at a much lower than commercial price, it can be inferred, we would contend, that the accused ought reasonably to have known that he was dabbling in something which he should not have been involved in.

The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has expressed some concern about clause 6 which establishes a new sub-section 47a (4) with regard to the reverse onus of proof that is placed in this area. The Committee, in its tenth report of 1986 of this month, argues:

New sub-section 47a (4) would provide a defence in respect of the failure to retain records for a prescribed period if the defendant satisfies the court that he or she took all reasonable precautions, and exercised due diligence, to ensure the retention of the records. The Committee drew the new sub-section to the attention of the Senate under principle 1 (a) (i) in that by imposing the persuasive onus of proof on the defendant in criminal proceedings it might be considered to trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties.

The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) responded to this, pointing out that the Committee had taken into account the fact that the matters which the defence entails are peculiarly within the knowledge of the defendant, the regulatory nature of the offence created by sub-section 47a (3) and the comparatively low level of the fine, $500. So sub-section 47a (4) falls squarely within the policy enunciated in the Attorney's earlier correspondence to the Committee concerning circumstances in which reversal of the persuasive onus is permissible. It is nevertheless, notwithstanding that response from the Attorney, worth while drawing to the Senate's attention that this clause contains that particular reversal.

Finally, the present ridiculously low penalties have been increased and they will be up to 33 times higher than those introduced in 1981. While the penalties at the lower end of the scale might still be inadequate, it is to be hoped that the overall increases will act as a deterrent to those engaged in this particularly nasty business. Again, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has had some concern about the retrospective application of those penalties. It refers the Senate's attention to clause 17 which relates to new sub-section 133a (1) with regard to that retrospective element. The Committee states:

Clause 17 would substitute a new sub-section 133a (1), sub-paragraph (c) (ii) of which specifies a new penalty if the offender against the sub-section is a body corporate. Paragraph (c) would appear to apply the new penalty to the sub-section as it was in force before the coming into operation of clause 17. Thus a body corporate which would have been liable to a penalty of $1,500 for a first offence-
under the existing legislation-

might now be liable to a fine of up to $7,500 even if the offence was committed before the commencement of the new section. The Committee drew the clause to the attention of the Senate under principle 1 (a) (i) in that by retrospectively increasing the penalty for an offence it might be considered to trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties.

The Attorney-General responded with an argument that there had been some misunderstanding in relation to the new proposed sub-section, pointing out that sub-section 45a of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 makes clear that where an amending Act increases the penalty for an offence, the increase applies only to offences committed after the commencement of the amending provision-sub-section 45a (1). The Committee reported that the Attorney said:

There does not appear to be expressed in paragraph 133a (1) (c) any contrary intention to sub-section 45a (1) of the Acts Interpretation Act. Paragraph 133a(1) (c) is intended only to clarify `first conviction', so as to prevent a defendant, convicted of an offence under section 133a prior to the commencement of the amendment in section 17, from arguing that a subsequent conviction under section 133a after the commencement-
I so love the prolixity of all of this-
of section 17 was his or her `first' conviction. Paragraph 52 of the Explanatory Memorandum sets out-
this is the shortest sentence in the whole thing-
the intended meaning of the provision.
I trust that the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) understood all that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Were you happy with that?

—Well, the Committee argued that it could not agree with the point of view put forward with regard to the provision on the grounds that while it may have been the intention only to give a particular meaning to the expression `first conviction' as set out in the explanatory memorandum, it does appear nevertheless that the words used are sufficiently clear to displace the effect of sub-section 45a (1) of the Acts Interpretation Act. In essence, to introduce a retrospective increase in the penalty imposed for a contravention of sub-section 133a (1), the Minister may want to give some more elaborate, perhaps less prolix response, for the first time in recorded history, to this. I look forward to hearing that; but at the moment, at least, the Committee is not satisfied with the Attorney-General's response.

SPEECH.PARA: Leaving that, however, and returning to the major concerns expressed by industry, it has pressed for increased penalties for some time and it is satisfied with these increases, so presumably it believes, at least, that the offence of piracy is sufficiently dreadful for this legislation to go through even if the Scrutiny of Bills Committee interpretation of the effect of the new paragraph is correct. In passing, I think it is worth while complimenting the industry on the way in which it has sought to help itself in the face of the massive problem of video piracy. Its activities in anti-piracy investigation, legal action and public education are a credit to it even though, of course, they have been undertaken with some element, at least, of self-interest. In addition, the industry has been particularly co-operative in the way it has continued to seek legislative reform. Indeed, I would go so far as to say that it was beginning to feel not only co-operative but also somewhat frustrated in its attempts to get this going, considering that Australia is some years behind other countries in putting into place the sorts of penalties for video piracy that are necessary if it is to be stopped. For example, it is some two years since major penalties for video piracy were introduced in the United States of America and the United Kingdom. I understand that since then those penalties have proved to be overwhelmingly effective as a deterrent. I sincerely hope that the same sort of thing will happen here.

Other aspects of the Bill which are also worthy of commendation include increased access to copyright material for the disabled and the establishment of a new statutory licence which will enable radio stations catering for print handicapped people to broadcast literary and dramatic works, subject to the copyright owners' right to claim equitable remuneration. This is a clear improvement on the present situation. Similarly, the establishment of a new statutory licence for institutions assisting intellectually disabled people will allow those institutions to reproduce and adapt specified published copyright material for the limited sole purpose of use in providing assistance to the intellectually disabled. These are valuable initiatives which, of course, will benefit those people enormously, and so they should.

As the Attorney-General has pointed out, there are some major questions which are still the subject of review and consideration by the Government. In an area as important as this where advances are being made on an almost daily basis in the technology, I ask that the Government hurry up with that review or, as usual, the Government will be outstripped by it. These concerns relate to issues such as home taping, the use of copyright materials by educational institutions and the question of parallel importing. In all of these areas there is a need for urgent action and I hope that urgent action will be forthcoming. Other countries have managed to find a solution-for example, by putting a levy on blank tapes, which gets around some of the problems that still have to be resolved. One is forced to wonder why the Australian Government is taking so long to pick up these issues. It is not as if it has not been aware of them or been made aware of them because the Attorney-General referred to them during his second reading speech.

Overall, however, as I said earlier, the Bill is very welcome. The extent to which the proposed solutions work needs to be monitored, although, if overseas indications are going to be followed here, it appears that the measures in the Bill will certainly be of some assistance. It is to be hoped that a similarly constructive approach to the one taken by industry representatives that resulted in this Bill will be taken to the other outstanding matters and that we will see those problems too resolved in the near future. One of those problems, of course, relates to the use by schools of information that is broadcast on television channels and, in particular, on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service.

I do not think I am jumping the gun on Senator Puplick, but I understand that there is a proposed Opposition amendment with regard to making accessible publicly-funded information free of cost to publicly-funded institutions. As I said, that specifically relates to videotaping by schools and, in particular, I would have thought, State schools, of ABC or SBS programs on television. There are a number of problems associated with this and with the Opposition's bringing forward an amendment, which certainly we support in principle. The first problem is that, if it is passed, it is going to hold up the rest of the legislation until the Budget session begins and the House of Representatives can look at the amendment. Given the fact that the video industry has waited so long for this Bill, that would be an unfortunate result.

Other problems are caused by the fact that the ABC and, I presume, the SBS do not necessarily own the copyright to everything they broadcast, and that could cause a few hiccups in the system. Of course, there is the wider issue of whether schools should make a contribution to these sorts of videos in the same way as they do, for example, with regard to the purchase of books. While I certainly support the aim that the Opposition has in the amendment it is going to put forward, given the problems, particularly with regard to the ownership of copyright, of some of the material used on the ABC and what impact that is likely to have on the schools that use video copies of that material-whether they are aware of the fact that copyright is or is not held by the ABC-it may be better to refer this amendment to the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts for consideration of all its implications. Indeed, I will move in that direction by leave after the Committee stage.

I think it is an amendment that deserves support. However, it does require looking into further, whether with regard to the problems it could cause or, more importantly, with regard to extending it so that it goes beyond simply looking at the ABC and the SBS in schools and perhaps can be widened so that all publicly-funded information is made available free to publicly-funded institutions, or at least inasmuch as that is feasible. We support the legislation. We would like to see it go beyond the areas it has already covered. We would simply encourage the Government to get on with covering those other areas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Copyright Amendment Bill 1986 is an important piece of legislation which covers a number of areas relating to developments which have taken place in the field of audio-visual copyright and audio-visual technology in the last couple of years. I do not want to repeat the points made by my colleague the Deputy Leader, Senator Durack, in terms of the length of time the Government has delayed on this particular matter or indeed the adequacy of its general response to the whole question of audio-visual copyright. However, I do want to deal with a number of matters raised in the legislation and to say a few words about the amendment which the Opposition will be putting forward and something about the state of copyright law in general.

SPEECH.PARA: The principal purpose of this amendment Bill is to combat the growth of video piracy, which to all intents and purposes is a form of theft. There is no doubt that this is a problem of quite massive dimensions. The Australian Film Commission, for instance, in its recent bulletin on copyright law proposals, estimates that conservatively piracy has cost the industry about 20 per cent of its returns-a figure calculated by the Film Commission to be about $32m a year. It is also true that the enforcement of a new, stricter regime with heavier penalties is likely to have some considerable impact in this matter. For instance, the Australian newspaper on 29 January this year contained a report about the introduction of tougher copyright legislation in Great Britain. The report said:
When tough legislation was introduced to Britain last year the pirate video market share fell from 50 per cent to just under 10 per cent and the pirates moved into the Pacific.

There is no doubt that this region of the world has been particularly affected by the growth of video piracy. Recently major amendments were made to the law of Singapore, which previously had relied simply on the 1911-12 Imperial Act. The Singapore authorities used the Australian legislation as something of a model for their own approach to the matter. It is interesting that Singapore-based companies are believed to have earned around $US200m through exports of illegally-produced music cassette tapes alone. So when one considers the extent to which one has to add to that the whole question of pirate videos, one can see that this is a mammoth industry in the extent to which revenue is lost both to governments and to legitimate owners of copyright.

The Copyright Amendment Bill will have impact in Australia, one of the countries with the largest degree of home video penetration. In 1983 it was calculated that 11 per cent of Australian households which had television also had video recorders. By 1985 this figure had grown to around 50 per cent, and in some regional cities and country towns was as high as 80 per cent. The 1983 wholesale sales of video cassettes in the Australian market was approximately $30m, rising to $100m in 1985 and by the end of 1985 approximately 30,000 of a potential 100,000 hotel and motel rooms in this country were linked to videos to provide in-house movies.

Copyright legislation dates back a considerable period. I think the first copyright statute was in 1709 in the rein of Queen Anne. Legislation in this country has been based on that statute, on the Engraving Copyright Act of 1734 and Copyright Acts of 1905 and 1912. Copyright matters always tend to move slowly. For instance, in 1980 the Copyright Act was amended to give educational institutions a certain degree of responsibility for monitoring and controlling the use of photocopying in their facilities. It is only in the course of the last couple of months that the Copyright Agency Limited, on behalf of Australia's registered copyright owners, has been in a position to start collecting fees for the owners of copyright in a situation that was created for this purpose for five or six years ago.

The amendment Bill before us essentially seeks to do three things. First, it seeks to deal with the problems of proof of copyright ownership. Secondly, it deals with establishing in prosecutions that a defendant knew that he had in his possession an infringing copy. Thirdly, it addresses the question of penalties which, as Senator Haines has pointed out, have remained ridiculously inadequate for a prolonged period.

As Senator Durack indicated, a number of matters have not been addressed or dealt with in this Bill. I want to mention a couple of them. The first is the problem of home taping. Senator Durack referred to a decision of the United States Supreme Court in which this matter was tested involving, if my memory serves me correctly, the Disney studios in an action against the producers of video machines. I think in that instance Sony was the principal defendant. It is disappointing that the issues raised and addressed by the United States Supreme Court have not now been picked up and dealt with in this Australian legislation that has been developed some years later.

There has been lengthy debate about whether a tax should be applied on blank tape. I understand that in West Germany, France, Austria, Portugal, Finland, Norway, Iceland, Sweden, and even Hungary, there is a levy on blank tapes. Furthermore, the matter has been under consideration in the United Kingdom, where in April 1986 a White Paper was produced on the topic. The United Kingdom Government announced its intention to introduce a levy on blank audio tapes in relation to unrestricted home taping. Again, this is a matter which our Government could have addressed at this stage, but it has declined to do so.

A major problem arises from what is called parallel importing, which means, in effect, the importation for commercial purposes of legitimate copies-for example, of books, records or tapes by somebody other than the Australian territory's exclusive licensee. The magazine Encore, the trade journal of the film and television industry, in its edition of 27 March 1986, sets out a detailed discussion of the question of parallel importing. It is true that the Copyright Tribunal under His Honour Mr Justice Sheppard is having a look at this matter and the Copyright Law Review Committee will also be examining it. But again, the question of parallel importing has been before the Government for a number of years and has not been addressed. It is unfortunate that, increasingly, a large number of important areas of copyright law presumably are piling up on the Attorney-General's desk, because he is not devoid of recommendations from the industry, tribunals and reviews by his Department and others going back a number of years.

As Senator Durack said, the Australian Copyright Council has expressed some difficulties with parts of the Bill, and in particular the adequacy of the definition of the term `broadcast', which is contained in clause 3 (d) of the Bill. It has also expressed difficulty over certain questions which arise in regard to broadcasts being transmitted into Australia from a place outside Australia, and the way in which they might stand in relation to the copyright regime which is affected by this Bill. That is a matter to be taken up in the Committee stage of the Bill.

The Opposition has foreshadowed an amendment to this legislation to allow access, without some of the copyright restrictions, to educational institutions for educational purposes where they make copies of broadcasts put out by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation or the Special Broadcasting Service in a restricted area. I refer to that area where the copyright of the program concerned subsists in the ABC or SBS. I know that the Australian Film Commission has raised some difficulties on this score, and has commented on how this would affect people who primarily make educational films. We believe that problem would be overcome by the fact that our amendment is drawn in such a way as to apply only to a broadcast or a sound broadcast in which the copyright clearly subsists in the ABC or SBS. We should be able to deal with that matter in a little more detail in the Committee stage.

I conclude by making a more general point about copyright and copyright law in particular. I do so as a purely personal observation and do not attempt to ascribe my view as one that is necessarily widely held within the Opposition parties. The Berne Convention on which a great deal of our copyright law is based will, on 9 September this year, celebrate its 100th anniversary thus a great deal of the copyright law in Australia is tied to a document which is 100 years old, and which, in terms of copyright law generally, stretches back to the reign of Queen Anne. I do not know whether it is possible to continue to maintain a belief in copyright per se in the years ahead.

We must seriously address the question of whether intellectual property laws are any longer compatible with the growth in technology. I do not believe that it is clear that both are sustainable. In her comments Senator Haines mentioned the difficulty that is posed by computer programs. A number of these matters, which were addressed in the High Court when it eventually had to settle the matter in Apple Computer Australia v. Computer Edge, exposed the difficulty in the law, slow moving as it is. But even with the best intentions to keep the law moving at a reasonable pace in this area, the technology simply makes it almost impossible. When Senator Gareth Evans was Attorney-General, he announced in June 1984 that there would be a review of copyright law as it related to computers and computer programs. I understand that this has subsequently been deferred in terms of the review which is being undertaken. For instance, I know that in a number of countries, such as the United States, the United Kingdom, France and Japan, they have endorsed copyright as a preferred method of software protection, but the case is by no means clear.

If one looks at all the other bits and pieces that arise in relation to copyright law, one realises this. For example, there is the way in which the Europeans have established in copyright law access to what are called moral rights-rights of the disclosure, rights of recall on change of opinion, rights to claim authorship and rights relating to the integrity of a work-which are protected in article 6 bis of the Berne Convention. In 1979 the then Attorney-General, Mr Ellicott, announced that he was interested in some review of the status of moral rights within Australian copyright law. Support was given for the inclusion of moral rights in the United Kingdom copyright law by the Green Paper in that country in 1981. The whole question of what is called droit de suite was rejected in the United Kingdom by the Whitford Committee in 1977, and in Australia we have a problem with the Australasian Performing Right Association. The APRA case, which came before the Copyright Tribunal last year, resulted in major cost increases being imposed on the ABC and others to pay retrospective fees for the performance of certain live and sound recordings which currently might otherwise only have protection under sections 52 and 53 of the Trade Practices Act in relation to the passing off provisions. At the end of last year we had a debate about the establishment of a public lending rights scheme on a statutory basis and a number of issues were raised there.

However, I believe that the increase in technology and in the pace of technology means that the traditional way in which we have understood copyright and the whole framework of intellectual property legislation in this country is doomed. In fact, we will have to look in the not too distant future at whether copyright law and the other attendant areas of designs, trademarks and patents and so on are not in need of a very substantial revision.

I shall conclude my remarks at that point but I indicate that on some of the definitional matters and other matters relating to the Opposition amendment, we will take the opportunity to speak briefly in the Committee stage. Nevertheless the areas which the Bill addresses it addresses adequately and the Opposition is happy to support it. However, we hope that the Minister representing the Attorney-General will be in a position to indicate that matters such as home taping, parallel importing and other areas of audio-visual copyright which have been with the Government for some time will be addressed in the not too distant future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I am grateful to honourable senators for their support for the Copyright Amendment Bill 1986 and in particular its centrepiece-upgrading the piracy provisions and making them more effectively enforceable. A number of matters have been raised, particularly by Senator Puplick, with his usual conspicuous erudition. He raised some issues that are not dealt with by the Bill but which he thinks should be addressed by the Government. I will ensure that his remarks and those of other honourable senators are drawn to the attention of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) so that he can take account of them in identifying further work priorities.

SPEECH.PARA: On the particular subject of audio-visual copyright, both in the home and in educational institutions, it should be said that continuing activity is taking place within the Government to try to determine appropriate ways of dealing with these matters. The blank tape levy idea which I, as Attorney-General, was concerned to see implemented if at all possible, foundered initially on the basis of strong legal advice that such a levy would in law be a tax. That has not been called into question by competing opinion from Sir Maurice Byers, QC, this time acting for copyright owners. Accordingly, this is an issue which the Government is prepared to reconsider. Certainly there are ample precedents for this elsewhere and it is the simplest way from many points of view of dealing with this issue. Certainly I, for one, remain attracted to it.

On the point about educational copying, there is an active program of discussions proceeding at present between the Government, the copyright owners, tertiary and schools representatives and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. Commercial interests have been invited to participate in these discussions but to date they have expressed little interest in doing so. What is in issue is a statutory licence scheme of the kind which has been-for the most part successfully-implemented for written material in educational institutions. I hope that some progress can be made on that. Further aspects of this will be raised in the Committee stage and we can deal with the detail of it there.

The point should also be made that the Copyright Law Review Committee is actively looking at a number of other matters, particularly parallel importation, which was raised by Senator Puplick. However, part of that issue is addressed in the Bill before us today insofar as the question of knowledge is addressed. I do not think it should be said that the progress of the audio-visual review has in any way been delayed by the establishment of the Copyright Law Review Committee. It is operating on parallel paths but not in such a way that it has caused any of the delay that has so far occurred in implementing effective audio-visual regimes. As is always the case with copyright, the problem is very complex and difficult. I acknowledge that the law has tended to move at a pretty glacial pace in this area and it is a function of the complexity of the matters involved as well as the will, or lack of it, of governments to come to grips with these issues.

The other points that have been raised can be better dealt with in the Committee stage except, perhaps, for a couple of issues from the Scrutiny of Bills Committee with which Senator Haines demonstrated a preoccupation. The point about the reversal of the persuasive onus of proof is well made by that Committee. Personally I have never had any affection at all for reversal of the persuasive onus and I believe that there are very few instances where such provisions cannot be reduced at least to a mere reversal of an evidentiary burden, keeping the persuasive onus where, in criminal law, it generally should be-on the prosecution. The difficulty in this instance is that the clause had been drafted, as far as print handicapped radio licences were concerned, to mirror exactly the provisions elsewhere in the parent legislation governing the statutory licences for schools. It would have created obvious anomalies had the rules been different in each of those two environments. Therefore it remains to be attended to another day, as does most of the statute book. If change is to be made in this particular matter, it would have been odd and inappropriate, so the argument goes, to have made the amendment on this occasion.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PRIME MINISTER: TELEVISION ADDRESS TO THE NATION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Has a private company been involved in producing tonight's television address to the nation by the Prime Minister? What is the production cost of the address and is the Government meeting that cost? Further, as the Leader of the Opposition has sought equal time to reply on national television, will any such reply be on the same cost basis as applies to the Prime Minister?

—I am not able to help Senator Chaney entirely with an answer to this question. As I understand it, largely from the newspapers I suspect, a private company has been engaged in connection with part of the televising of the address. In so far as the cost of the address is concerned, the final costs are yet to be collated and I assume that when that is done they can be made available. With regard to the reply by the Leader of the Opposition, I understand that a request was made and, in conformity with practice, was refused. However, I am not absolutely certain in respect of the facts of that matter.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I refer to a couple of elements of the question to which I asked the Minister to address himself. Is the Government, or the taxpayer, meeting the cost of the private company involvement and, if the Leader of the Opposition does make a reply on national television, will he be afforded the same consideration?

—I thought I indicated that I was not able to answer the second part of that question. I will try to get an answer to Senator Chaney by tomorrow, at least. I would assume that, if the rules were all fair in love and war, as they usually are, the same costs would be made available to the Leader of the Opposition. But I will have to obtain an answer.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce been drawn to a series of reports on the Australian dredging industry in recent editions of the Daily Commercial News newspaper? In particular, has the Minister seen the report in the 13 May edition of the newspaper headlined `Belgium denies dredging subsidy' which points out that a representative of the Belgian Government denied that his Government had subsidised the successful tenderer, two Belgian dredge owners, for a contract to dredge a four kilometre long, 250 metre wide channel in Mermaid Sound off Dampier in Western Australia? Can the Minister confirm that the price of the successful contract was approximately $30m, some $10m lower than the other seven tenders? What action can the Government take to ensure that foreign companies are not advantaged and Australian companies are not disadvantaged by this type of activity? Has the Minister seen a further report in the same paper on 21 May which asserts that the Government is acting in a manner not in the best interests of the Australian dredging industry? Will the Minister comment on the accusations contained in the articles and will he outline what policies the Government has in place to ensure that Australian dredging companies can compete on at least equal terms with foreign companies for dredging contracts in Australia?

—I have seen some information on Senator McKiernan's detailed question but I do not have all that information with me. Perhaps I can provide the honourable senator with an answer at the end of Question Time. I apologise for not having the information here.

—My question, which I also address to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, is not dissimilar to the last question. I refer to a recent statement that Sunbeam Australia designed the cheapest in-line toaster on the market, but after an international comparison of production costs the company ordered manufacture in Hong Kong for 42 per cent less than would have been the cost in Sydney. The production cost comparisons were: Australia, $18.08; New Zealand, $15.42; United States of America, $14.23; and Hong Kong, $10.56. Has the Minister made any analysis of the reasons for the differences in costs between each country? Can he tell the Senate how much of the cost difference is due to tax, overregulation, high interest rates and unrealistic wage on-costs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I had heard the story about a Sunbeam product which, I think, is being manufactured in New Zealand as well as Hong Kong. However, I do not know that the detail of whether it was a toaster, a microwave oven or whatever is terribly important because that is not the point of the question, as I understand it.
—It is if you want to make some toast.

—If I can offer the honourable senator some advice, I think, having regard to the state that he is in, he had best stick to muesli; so he can tune out of the rest of the answer. The point of Senator Lewis's question is clearly the differences in costs between various countries and that, of course, will vary from product to product and will depend very much on what sort of natural advantage a particular country may have in respect of the production of a particular commodity. For example, Hong Kong clearly has an immense advantage over other economies in respect of labour costs. Australia has advantages over other countries in respect of a range of matters which go to the cost of production.
—What about the tax rates?

—The honourable senator makes a good point. However, perhaps I can simply explain the point to the honourable senator in this way: If the worthy citizens of Hobart enjoyed the same wages as the people of Hong Kong, the honourable senator's chemist shop would not be such a profitable business as it is now because they would not by buying the sorts of products that he undoubtedly sells in that pharmacy. As I say, the point about wage costs comparison is that costs differ from product to product. I just make the point in this way: There are now really only two major centres of production in the world for consumer electronics-that is, Japan and, to a certain extent, other economies of the Pacific basin; and the very large international company, Phillips Industries, based in Holland. That contraction has taken place because of the high labour costs involved, the labour intensivity of manufacturing commercial electronic appliances and so on.

ANSWER.PARA: The point I make is that in terms of developing products and marketing products in Australia we have to be conscious of the advantages and disadvantages which we have. Senator Lewis is trying to suggest that labour costs in areas of high labour intensivity are a disadvantage for Australia. Of course they are. They will become more so, not only for Australia but also for other Western countries, the traditional Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development members and so on, as Chinese industry develops and becomes more sophisticated. But there is a range of issues involved in the costs of production which goes way beyond simply the question of labour costs. I think it is bad for the issue of international competitiveness to be dealt with solely on the criterion of labour costs. If that were the case, we would find that some of the greatest manufacturing economies of the world, which have labour costs comparable with and sometimes higher than Australia, would go out of business. They have concentrated on a range of other activities, in terms of international competitiveness, which make all the difference. The classic example, of course, is Japan, which has very little by way of raw materials and comparable labour costs with Australia, but a whole range of other mechanisms and attitudes which are important and which have made it a highly productive and innovative economy. A lot of those issues go to good management and things of that kind. I take the point of Senator Lewis's question which, if I might say without being derogatory on this occasion, is fairly simple in its thrust; I say that the issue is more complex than that. I go back to the toaster example; I have no doubt that happened. It has happened with a lot of products in Australia. There are many other products, which of course we can make very well, to which that would not apply.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer and I understand the point that he is trying to make, but I point out that he fails to realise that the manufacturers of Australia want to know what the Government is going to do about this matter. It is very interesting to hear the Minister talk about these things, but what on earth is this Government going to do about them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose Senator Lewis is hoping for some dramatic statement that the Government will--
—The manufacturers would like one.

—I am not sure that the honourable senator speaks on behalf of the manufacturers, although he is not bad when speaking on behalf of Canberra bus proprietors. Let me say that if he is hoping for some dramatic statement that this Government will set about the task of reducing wages in this country to the levels pertaining in Hong Kong, he will not be satisfied because he will not get that statement. I want to make that point quite clear.

ANSWER.PARA: Because of the second part of the honourable senator's question, I really have to make the point that the basic problems of manufacturing in this country occurred in the 1960s and the 1970s. They occurred because of high protection and high wages which were allowed to grow by governments in the total absence of a wages policy and, of course, a total lack of attention to some of the other things to which I referred in the earlier part of my answer; namely, attention to good products, quality, design, marketing and those sorts of things. The Government is concerned about these issues, which are not just related to wage costs; they are related to a whole range of other things. Since senators other than Senator Lewis want to ask questions, I will save some of my comments for another day.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Health seen the release by the Australian Medical Association announcing the abandonment of the long-standing policy of not charging pensioners and disadvantaged any more than the patient benefit rebate? In the light of the recent announcement by the Government of increases in benefits of up to 23 per cent in some States, does the Minister see this announcement as justified in any way or does it signal that the AMA is putting financial gain and greed before patient care?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I did see the announcement that the AMA has decided to ask its members to cease bulk billing pensioners and the disadvantaged. I find this an extraordinary decision of the AMA. I think it is very hard to justify. It is very hard to get away from the fact that it is putting self interest and greed ahead of compassion and care. I am interested in two statements that the AMA has made. It has said:

ANSWER.PARA: No other group in the community is expected to subsidise the disadvantaged to this extent.

I am particularly concerned about statements which were made in my State by Dr Peter Beaumont, who is State Secretary of the AMA. He said that doctors were being forced to subsidise the Federal Government's promise of free health care to pensioners. I think it is important that we look at who is subsidising who. No other profession has an average income as high as that of the medical profession. Almost every medical practitioner in this country has been educated at public expense, and in the future every medical practitioner in this country will have been educated largely if not entirely in the same way.

The decision to treat pensioners as subsidised patients by introducing bulk billing was made not by governments by themselves but by coalition governments and the Australian Medical Association some 15 to 20 years ago. Before that, it was a tradition amongst the medical profession that it should subsidise pensioners in this way. Dr Beaumont claimed that there has been a great increase in the number of people receiving pensioner health benefit cards. That is not so. He said that the percentage of people receiving pensioner health benefit cards is currently about 23 per cent of the population. It is currently 19.6 per cent of the population, even when the dependants of pensioners are included. In fact, that has been the figure for many years.

The most significant figure-the figure which explains the AMA's attitude-is that in the past 15 years the number of medical practitioners in this country has doubled from 16,000 to 32,000. As I have said in the past, this has had some beneficial effects, particularly in New South Wales, where one can actually find surgeries open on Saturdays and Sundays, with their red lights on, so that people can go to see doctors when they want to see them. The increase in the number of doctors has also had the effect of having the medical profession look for other means of income maintenance. Obviously, the AMA has seen this means-the proposal that its members no longer subsidise pensions-as a means of income maintenance for an ever increasing number of doctors. In fact, it has put this ahead of patient care. I think the reasons given by Dr Beaumont and the Australian Medical Association are patently wrong. The decision is a heartless one. It goes against the traditions of the medical profession and, in fact, against the traditions of all governments in this country from either side of the Parliament in the last 20 or 30 years. I think it should be deplored. I know that the decision will be ignored by the vast majority of general practitioners in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Leader of the Government in the Senate aware that from July 1985 to April 1986 the biggest drain on our total balance of payments current account of $12,000m was repayments of interest on private overseas borrowings and dividends to foreign owners of Australian companies, which represented $5 1/2 billion-almost 50 per cent-whereas imports exceeded exports by a comparatively meagre $2 billion? Does the Government acknowledge that this is a most serious problem and that it is getting worse each month? Does the Government realise that our export industries cannot be expected now or in the immediate future to pay for both our imports and the ever growing balance of debt repayments and dividends to foreign owners? Will the Government include legislation to stop foreign money being used for takeovers and for tax avoidance purposes as part of its solution to the problem of reducing Australia's foreign debt repayments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two major parts to the honourable senator's question, and they are not entirely related except in one very substantial respect. Let me say, in answer to the first part of the question, that it is normal to have a current account deficit largely on account of the invisibles. In fact, in the last 20 years of Australia's trading relationships there has been only one financial year of surplus. The current account deficit over that period has averaged some 2.5 per cent to 3 per cent of gross domestic product. What is abnormal is the size of the recent deficit, not the fact that it exists. Throughout this period and, I emphasise, throughout the 1980s, the deficit has been in the 4 per cent to 6 per cent range, which is far too high. For example, in 1981-82 the deficit was 6 per cent of GDP-slightly higher than it is now.

ANSWER.PARA: The large build-up in debts is primarily a consequence of this string of deficits throughout the 1980s which has now been converted into the sizable servicing obligation to which Senator Chipp referred in his question. It is a very serious problem, and it is one which, basically, will not be overcome until Australian industry is fully regenerated. As I have said on several occasions in the Senate at Question Time and elsewhere, the process of restructuring cannot be expected to occur overnight, particularly after a decade of previous governments telling industry that it was dispensable. Nonetheless, industry for the most part is internationally competitive once again in terms of price. Provided we can achieve continued wage restraint of the sort to be outlined by the Prime Minister later today-if speculation in the newspapers is correct-it will stay that way.

Over the year to the March quarter, there were some encouraging signs in respect of trade volumes, with export volumes up by 14.1 per cent and import volumes up by only 0.9 per cent. Unfortunately, export prices were another story altogether. They were down across the board. Dramatic price reductions have occurred in major items of exports such as coal, in spite of the very high volumes of exports. Because of the poor terms of trade and the poor debt position left to us by the previous Government, both actual debt and prospective debt to be crystallised by our inheritance of the serious current account deficit I mentioned earlier, the task of turning around that position will remain long, hard and difficult. Nevertheless, I believe that the Government is fully aware of these issues and is on the right track.

As to the last part of the question raised by Senator Chipp, he will be aware that the issue of corporate takeovers occupies the minds not only of the Australian Democrats but also of many commentators and the Government. The Department of the Treasury has released a paper on takeovers and their effects in order to stimulate public discussion on the issue. It is a very substantial document which will be considered by the Government after further community discussion. The Government is certainly concerned to stop any tax avoidance in the areas of takeovers and foreign borrowings. It has already taken steps to close off the tax advantages of short term, redeemable preference shares, interest withholding tax avoidance in relation to discounted securities and further important measures which will limit or remove the tax advantages of foreign borrowing and takeovers generally. This will be achieved by the foreign tax credit system in part. The imputation system for company dividends and the capital gains tax, which have been the subject of much debate in the Senate, will also have beneficial effects in the same way.

These general and specific measures will all have their impact on gearing and takeover decisions. Whether more needs to be done or ought to be done, as was implied in Senator Chipp's question, is a matter for consideration. By saying that, I do not want to let Senator Chipp go away with the idea or the assumption that all takeovers or foreign borrowings are bad. I am not sure for a moment whether he is implying that in his question. Matters of this kind require careful judgment and competing considerations have to be carefully balanced.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. While I am impressed that the Government and Treasury have been responsible for `stimulating public discussion', I ask the Minister: Is the Government not deeply concerned that the drain on our total balance of payments current account has been $12 billion in something like 10 months and that half of that drain can be attributed to paying dividends to foreign owners and interest on foreign debts? On the basis of that, has it not reached the stage where public discussion is of secondary importance to immediate and drastic action by the Government to stop this outflow which is bleeding Australia dry?

—I tried to indicate in my answer to Senator Chipp's earlier question that this matter is of considerable concern to the Government, but I do not think one can rush out and say that we will deal with the question of foreign ownership and the repatriation of dividends by foreign-owned companies overnight. That is an enormously difficult question when one considers that enormous segments of our industry are foreign-owned.
—I am not asking you to do it overnight. Take a couple of days to think about it.
—Take a couple of days? It is a very real problem.
—I think he wants you to do a Jack Lang.

—I do not know what he wants me or the Government to do. It is part of the problem, I agree. But it is something we have to live with as a result of 30 years developments in this area. Insofar as interest on foreign debts is concerned, I guess our tax structure and foreign ownership rules have been very much responsible for debt accrual as distinct from equity investment by foreign companies. Some of the changes which have now been made go some of the way towards addressing that question. I do not pretend, by giving Senator Chipp a sort of flat answer like this, to say that this is not a matter to which the Government gives a lot of concern and attention. We do.

—Has the attention of the Leader of the Government in the Senate been drawn to the statement by a respected economist of the University of Tasmania, Dr Bruce Felmingham, that Federal Government cuts to Tasmania would pose a real threat to the existence of Tasmania as we know it? Is it a fact that Tasmanians contribute, as Dr Felmingham said, some $162m per annum to compensate secondary industry in Victoria alone for Commonwealth Government tariff protection on manufactured goods obtained from that State? Is it unfair for the Government or any of its Ministers, when commenting on the Commonwealth-Tasmanian financial arrangements, to ignore the hidden subsidies paid to States with a broad manufacturing base and the contributions which Tasmania's primary and resource industries make to export revenue? Is it also unfair to ignore the fact that Tasmania has a small and decentralised population, a low revenue base and other disabilities, for example, Bass Strait?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that I am the most appropriate person to answer this question. I am not aware of the work of Dr Bruce Felmingham, a distinguished Tasmanian economist. But no doubt if he is as distinguished as that, his views will be made known to the Prime Minister and Treasurer by the Premier of Tasmania at the Premiers Conference later this week. I am horrified by the suggestion that he makes that something might occur which might `pose a real threat to the existence of Tasmania as we know it' because I like Tasmania as we know it. I hope that, in any radio or Press release the honourable senator makes as a result of the answer to this question, he will mention that I like Tasmanians. I think they are splendid people and I like Tasmania as we know it.

ANSWER.PARA: I cannot comment on the specific figures Senator Harradine mentioned. He referred, however, to a study by the Economic Planning Advisory Council of the relative effects of protection for various industries and particularly the effects in, I think, New South Wales and Victoria, being the most intensely concentrated manufacturing States. That study was released the other day. Some of the findings have to be, if I might say so, taken with a grain of salt. I am not in a position to analyse that study in any detail at present, but I am sure that this Government, which has been characterised by munificence over the years, will be very mindful of these matters in the attention Tasmania is given at the forthcoming Premiers Conference.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Territories to the article in the Canberra Times on 29 May in which it was reported that a Brigade district officer, Mr Raymond Jones, said that discipline `had declined in the Australian Capital Territory Fire Brigade to such an extent' that its senior officers had `no power to prevent drunken fire-fighters reporting for work, drinking on duty or not wearing uniforms'. Will the Minister advise what investigations have been made into this allegation made some 13 days ago? If the allegations are correct, what steps has the Government taken to ensure that the people of the Australian Capital Territory have a fire brigade which is a reliable fire-fighting force?

—The Senate and, indeed, Senator Reid would be aware that there have been difficulties with the Australian Capital Territory Fire Brigade over a long period and that the Government has endeavoured to use its good offices to resolve some of those difficulties in the interests of fire protection for the residents of the Australian Capital Territory. The specific question Senator Reid raises obviously would be best handled by the Minister for Territories. It would probably be imprudent of me to make too many comments when a conflict exists in the administration of the Fire Brigade. I will certainly bring the matter to the attention of the Minister, Mr Scholes, whom I represent in this place, with a view to resolving what has been, as acknowledged a longstanding difficulty. I suppose the only thing I can say about it is that there seems to be an element on both sides that requires some good will if we are to resolve it in the interests of everybody concerned. I only represent the Minister. Fortunately, I do not have the problem to contend with in my portfolio that Mr Scholes has. I certainly will be delighted to refer the problem back to him.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Education been drawn to a Press report in today's Australian which quoted the Director of the Western Australian Institute of Technology as calling for the introduction of elements of free enterprise, including tertiary fees, as a method of avoiding what he describes as `anomalies in the binary system'? Can the Minister inform the Senate whether the Government has plans to reintroduce tertiary fees? Is the Minister aware of Opposition plans to reintroduce tertiary fees?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that Dr Watts seems to think that his program of expanding his institution would benefit by charging students fees, but that is not a view that the Government agrees with.
—He is right.
—On the other hand, of course, as Senator Peter Baume has just indicated, the Opposition obviously intends to impose fees on tertiary students.
—You are wrong, he is right.

—As I was saying, Senator Baume obviously agrees with Dr Watts, who wants to re-introduce tertiary fees, but neither Senator Baume nor Dr Watts will be determining these policies; the Government will. This call for fees from Dr Watts, Senator Baume and various other spokespersons for the Liberal Party has to be viewed in the context of their whole approach to privatisation of education. Not only do they want to re-impose fees on students but also they want to sell off government schools to the private sector-I think that was their coalition partner's remedy for schools in the Australian Capital Territory-they want to establish private universities, even though all responsible spokespersons from the present university system agree that that would lead to a lowering of standards, a loss of control over standards, and, in general, they want to impose totally inappropriate free market concepts on the business of developing high standard education in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: As honourable senators know, last year the Government gave serious consideration to the question of participation in higher education and the role that the abolition of fees had played in that participation and, in the context of our determination to increase participation in higher education, we decided to do a number of things. One was to maintain the present policy of no tuition fees. Another was to ensure a stable and steady growth of places in tertiary institutions and yet another was to ensure that more young people had the opportunity to finish secondary education and thus qualify for tertiary education. To do that we have rationalised and improved education allowances, giving particular increases to students from poorer families who wish to complete years 11 and 12. We have also, through various programs of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission, taken a number of steps to ensure that students from disadvantaged groups, such as Aboriginal families or families where secondary education opportunities are very poor, are given, through equity programs, the opportunity to get to a level of competence that will enable them to undertake successfully tertiary studies.

In contrast to our very comprehensive, worked out policy of improving participation at all levels of education and of ensuring that higher education is available on the basis of merit and not on the basis of ability to pay-I believe that we are delivering to the community what the community has clearly indicated that it wants in terms of education policy-the Opposition, whose approach to this subject is as threadbare as it is to anything else, can think only of privatisation of fees and selling off government schools in the fond hope that it will attract some sort of support for its cause. Members of the Opposition and any other people who argue these propositions would be absolutely thrown out by the electorate if ever they got the chance to put them into practice.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Finance to the wilful and extravagant answer he gave to the Senate yesterday concerning the Tasmanian Premier's concern at the prospect of cuts to Tasmanian funding-fears which are shared by the State Labor Opposition. Is the Minister not aware of the fact that the Commonwealth Grants Commission, even after its exercising of the principle of fiscal equalisation between the States, argued that Tasmania should receive financial assistance grants 37.6 per cent per capita more than the six-State average, having already taken into account the burdens on some of the other States of their business undertakings? As the figures produced by the Grants Commission and the principle of fiscal equalisation are obviously not to the liking of the Minister, will he inform the Senate whether his Government intends to disregard them, change the Grants Commission methodology or, alternatively, abolish the Commonwealth Grants Commission on the ground of its incapacity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have noted Senator Newman's figure. As far as I can remember it is correct-that is, the Grants Commission recommended that Tasmania should get 36 per cent more per capita. But the figures I quoted yesterday showed that Tasmania was getting nearly 50 per cent more per capita than the six-State average.
—And contributing more, too.

—In other words, using Senator Newman's own information, one cannot do other than arrive at the conclusion that Tasmania has been treated too generously in the past. Of course, that is the case. That was the very clear finding of the Grants Commission during its last review of relativities. It recommended that Tasmania should have its payments reduced by, I think, $60m in one hit. This Government, being very reasonable-indeed, in this case I believe it was probably much too reasonable in dealing with someone like Mr Gray-decided that, instead of imposing that Grants Commission recommendation on Tasmania in the one year, it would allow a phasing-in period. It is precisely that sort of phasing-in, bringing Tasmania back to its proper entitlement as assessed by the Grants Commission, which Mr Gray's present squeals are about.

ANSWER.PARA: I heard an interjection from Senator Archer, I think it was, that Tasmania pays a lot more than the other States. I also noted Senator Harradine's question concerning an alleged finding by some obscure economist about the hidden subsidy which Tasmania paid to the rest of Australia. Taking that figure at its face value, I point out to all the Tasmanians who may be interested that Western Australia makes a much larger per capita contribution in that way and it does not get the per capita Commonwealth payments that Tasmania gets, nor does it have a State government public sector of the relative size of Tasmania. I would like to know what contribution the highest per capita State government public sector work force in Australia makes to producing the export income which seems to so fascinate several Tasmanians. I can tell Senator Newman that I am sick and tired of having to sit in this Senate, as I did last week, and listen to her colleagues Senator Walters and Senator Townley whingeing and demanding that Commonwealth Government expenditure be reduced while Senator Newman and the rest of her cronies insist that the feather-bedding of Tasmania, which the Grants Commission has identified as feather-bedding, be continued in perpetuity.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SOUTH PACIFIC NUCLEAR FREE ZONE TREATY

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs will be aware of the content of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill which is currently before the House of Representatives. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the impact which the renunciation of the nuclear weapons option by Australia, as embodied in the Bill, will have on the prospects for peace in our region? Will the Minister indicate whether the Bill will be readily obtainable at a low price and in sufficient numbers to allow the widest possible community discussion over the winter recess? Will the Foreign Minister's speech on the Bill also be widely available so that those in the community with a keen interest in the debate may have the benefit of his remarks on the content of that Bill?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill is intended to give effect to obligations that Australia will have as a party to the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty, the Treaty of Rarotonga. That Treaty contains important and substantive provisions regarding the acquisition, testing and stationing of nuclear explosive devices and the dumping at sea of nuclear waste. It also contains provisions concerning safeguards on peaceful nuclear activities and a control system to provide confidence in compliance with the provisions of the Treaty. The renunciation of nuclear weapons by Australia, within the context of that Treaty and the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, can only strengthen the security of this country and of the South Pacific region. As the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, said when introducing the Bill, the Treaty is widely recognised around the world as a significant measure. It has been welcomed by the international community, especially at a time when the world has little to point to by way of progress on arms control and disarmament. At the same time the Treaty does not seek to undermine the factors that have created and sustained the very favourable security environment which the South Pacific enjoys. It does not in any way conflict with Australia's defence arrangements, notably ANZUS. It does not impede in any way our ability to co-operate militarily with our allies. On the contrary, it seeks to build on those factors by, for example, the provisions against nuclear weapons, which will help to ensure that the South Pacific, unlike other parts of the world, does not in the future become a theatre for nuclear confrontation.

ANSWER.PARA: The Bill is available to the public through normal parliamentary and government outlets, especially the Australian Government Publishing Service bookshops in the capital cities. I am advised that the treaty Bill is available for $2.50 and the explanatory memorandum accompanying it for $1. I hope that many interested Australians will take advantage of this opportunity to inform themselves of its content. I certainly commend it to the widest possible community discussion. Similarly, I commend to people the Foreign Minister's speech on the SPNFZ Bill for the illumination it provides on the objectives of the Treaty and on the Government's implementing legislation for it. If honourable senators encounter difficulty in obtaining sufficient copies of the Bill and the speech for distribution, I suggest that they contact parliamentary officers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney- General. In view of the fact that the Government has postponed further consideration of the Australian Bill of Rights Bill in the current sittings of the Senate, does the Government intend to persist with this Bill during the present Parliament or will it give the people an opportunity, which was denied them at the last election, to express their attitude to the Bill of Rights Bill at the next election?

—The Attorney-General advises me that he has every intention of proceeding with the Bill, and so he should. It is an admirable piece of legislation which, despite the campaign of idiot harassment to which it has been subjected by the forces of darkness around the place, in particular those opposite, will contribute a great deal to guaranteeing values which all Australians hold democratically dear. If the Opposition had not engaged in what has been clearly the most extravagant, self- indulgent and destructive filibuster in the history of this Parliament, in a debate that has so far occupied some 36 hours of parliamentary time-the longest debate in our history since Federation, or at least since records have been kept-it would have been possible for the Bill to have passed this House by now. It is the Attorney's intention to take up the matter again-hopefully with a slightly greater sense of realism on the part of others in this chamber as to the appropriate time for debate-in the hope that we can get it through early in the next session.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF VETERANS' AFFAIRS: FREEDOM OF INFORMATION REQUESTS

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to an item in today's Australian Financial Review which is critical of the cost of processing freedom of information requests by his Department. What is his response to the claim that his Department has been extravagant or wasteful in its handling of FOI information?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Freedom of Information Act approved by the Parliament provides an opportunity for many people to get access to information. When one considers that, for example, in World War II almost one million persons served in the armed forces and that currently we have 700,000 veterans receiving pension entitlements, it stands to reason that considerable numbers of them will take advantage of the Freedom of Information Act to get access to their service records. In fact that is what has happened. Some 10,000 persons have taken advantage of the legislation in order to examine their service records. I imagine that in the overwhelming majority of those cases that was for the purpose of evaluating whether the records are true in every respect and also whether they provide information that might assist veterans in their pension applications or in their assessment for an increase in benefit.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true that the consequence of that is that the Department of Veterans' Affairs has the largest number of applicants of all government departments for access to records. Neither I nor the Government make any apology for that. However, of the total of $19.2m, which I am informed is the cost of providing information generally to all those people who have applied for it under the legislation, only 7.7 per cent is attributable to the Department of Veterans' Affairs. That means that in any comparable sense the cost to taxpayers of applications through my Department compares very favourably with that of many other government agencies. We are in that position because our costs have been very considerably reduced owing to the fact that service records are kept in such a fashion as to make them readily accessible to those people who wish to look at them. The report in the Australian Financial Review has taken a one-sided view and makes the charge appear excessive, whereas, in comparison with others who have taken advantage of the freedom of information legislation, my Department comes out very favourably indeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. Is the Minister aware that a number of people in the community regard as an anomaly the different application of income and assets testing to blind people receiving a pension and to people receiving other categories of pensions and benefits? Does the Minister acknowledge that other severe disabilities, such as total deafness, can be as devastating and restrictive as blindness? If he does, can the Minister say whether the Government will consider examining the problems facing the deaf in particular, with a view to according to totally deaf people seriously disadvantaged by their disability the same status as is granted to totally blind persons as far as access to pensions and benefits is concerned?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am obviously aware of the difference in the treatment of blind people and of other disabled people. I am also well aware, having been Minister for Social Security, of the strong feelings that some people with disabilities have about this. In this case Senator Haines mentions totally deaf people who also have considerable difficulties. At various times other disabled members of the community have drawn attention to what is apparently an anomaly in that favoured treatment is given to blind people. My attitude to this has not changed since my days in opposition or the days when I was Minister for Social Security. Although there is no logic or reason for the treatment of blind people in the way they are treated-it was obviously a decision made many years ago, for I dare say, as much political reasons as for social or economic reasons-I do not think we should remove the advantages that blind people have. I know that Senator Haines is not suggesting this. What we should do is to improve our assistance to those people with other disabilities so that their privileges are at least equal to those given to blind people at the moment. We then run into budgetary problems and problems of definition. There are some, I dare say, who would argue vigorously that the problems of the profoundly deaf are not the same as the problems of the profoundly blind. As some people have not experienced either of those disabilities, I can understand there being discussions about that.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to my attitude and the Government's attitude, we have been endeavouring, and will continue to endeavour, to improve the lot of those with disabilities. Part of that aim would be to bring the rest of the disabled community up to at least the level of those who are blind, as far as income support is concerned. However, I am the first to admit that that is very much a budgetary decision at the moment, as well as a definitional decision, in dealing with the disabled. We will continue to have it under consideration-as, I am sure, all previous governments have had it under consideration. I will seek further information on the income support aspects from the Minister for Social Security.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Treasurer seen an advertisement in this morning's Australian headed `Capital Gains Tax and Investment' and attributed to Mr L. Ian Roach, Chairman of the Stock Exchange of Melbourne Ltd? If so, can the Minister provide a Government response to Mr Roach's claims about the effect of the capital gains tax on investment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the advertisement. I am surprised that an institution such as the Stock Exchange of Melbourne would indulge in such an opportunistic attack on a critical element of the Government's tax reform package. I also note that the advertisement, amongst other things, states: `A capital gains tax which inevitably discourages investment', and so on, leading to the general conclusion, of course-as did the same sort of nonsense we heard last week from most of the people on the other side of this chamber-that a capital gains tax would destroy the economy. The estimated level of revenue is $25m by the fifth year of operation, which is hardly a serious tax imposition. Of course, it probably will not raise much money directly, but it will put an effective net under the income tax system. It is that, primarily, which it was designed to do; at least, in my view, that is the primary justification for it. The advertisement also makes the same sorts of claims which were falsely made by assorted members of the Opposition last week about the high and allegedly punitive rates of the capital gains tax. No specifics are given-for the very good reason, of course, that if the specifics were given, the claim would collapse.

ANSWER.PARA: The basic assertion is made, without any empirical verification from the real world, that a capital gains tax will be in some way damaging to the economy. The fact is that for decades every country in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development with an economic record which has shamed Australia's record in recent decades, has had a capital gains tax. The overwhelming majority of them have a more severe capital gains tax than has Australia, because they make no allowance for indexation or inflation. In other words, they tax nominal gains, whereas the capital gains tax which was passed here last week will tax only real gains. In clarifying the point, I quote a short piece of a text which I think will be of great interest to assorted members of the Senate. The following statement appeared at page 590 of the Senate Hansard, dated 9 September 1981:
It-
`it' being Australia's taxation system-

taxes income to the extent that it increases wealth but not capital gains or windfall gains and results in a heavy bias towards the taxation of income. In 1978, 43.7 per cent of our total tax revenue was raised through personal income tax compared with an Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average of 38.5 per cent. Thus those whose wealth is increased by capital gains rather than by income do not share in the taxation burden. No other highly developed country has our almost complete absence from some form of taxation of capital gains, net wealth taxes or death duties.

The taxation system is inequitable in that a taxation of income has largely become a taxation of wages and salaries. Those whose income has been derived from property or business have been afforded opportunities for avoidance through income splitting and the like not available to the recipients of wages and salaries.
It was also stated:
It can be argued that our taxation system is inequitable, complex and inefficient and does not have sufficient flexibility.

That was part of the maiden speech of Senator Robert Hill, and a very good speech it was.
