In closing, I observe what a tragedy it is that the ruthless discipline of the Liberal Party has forced an honourable senator who, in 1981, displayed such intellectual clarity and moral integrity, to vote against his convictions in 1986 when he voted against the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax legislation last week.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question-if I can contain my amusement at the previous answer concerning people voting against their convictions, having regard to the treatment of Senator Georges by the Australian Labor Party-is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. Does he endorse the view put in the House of Representatives by the Minister for Social Security on 2 May this year that any move to require either work or entry into training programs as a condition of receiving the unemployment benefit would amount to conscription in relation to the payment of the unemployment benefit?

—I remember when Mr Howe made that statement. What he said at the time-and I remember it well; he said it both inside and outside the Parliament-was that any effort to prevent people in receipt of the unemployment benefit from receiving that benefit by forcing them into work which was artificial work, work which was not of use or work in the community which was not satisfying to them, would be akin to conscription. That is a view which I share. There have been many proposals to ask young people to do this. Some were fair; some-such as the one which Mr Howe was talking about at the time-were unfair. I dare say it is possible to introduce such programs which are fair and which do not involve, as he pointed out at the time, making people work for less than award wages or taking the jobs of others. I think any such system must be judged on that basis, not just by having carte blanche dismissals of proposals and taking words of that type as though they mean a complete dismissal of such a proposal under any circumstances.

—I ask the Minister for Veterans' Affairs: Is he aware that staff at the Repatriation General Hospital in Hobart are worried about their future because of rumours that the hospital may be disposed of, either to the Tasmanian State Government or, since that Government apparently is not interested in taking it over, to a private profit-making hospital chain? Will the Minister give assurances to those concerned staff and to veteran and community patients, that the Repatriation General Hospital will not be disposed of in this way, that the public resources involved will be protected, and that jobs are not under threat?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no proposal to dispose of the repatriation hospitals administered by the Repatriation Commission. I give the assurance for which Senator Coates asks-that staff employed in the repatriation hospitals have nothing to fear from the decision of the Government to begin a process of consultation with the States about the future-and I stress `the future'-of the repatriation hospitals. Two months ago, in response to a question, I pointed out that there had been unanimous agreement at the Commonwealth-State Health Ministers Conference that there should be established an inter-departmental committee which would involve the Commonwealth and the States, with a view to rationalising the services provided by the Commonwealth to repatriation beneficiaries and community patients, on the basis of providing an option for repatriation beneficiaries to be admitted to public hospitals in the area of their choice.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has accepted the recommendation of the Brand Review of the Repatriation Hospital System. There have been two such reviews of the future of repatriation hospitals, one in 1979 by the previous Government and one by this Government in 1983-84. The Government has accepted the recommendations of the Brand committee to begin the process of rationalising the services but in no way will that affect the operation of the hospitals in the foreseeable future. Many years down the track some changes to repatriation hospitals will obviously need to be planned for, but the hospitals currently are in their busiest period ever as the majority of veterans are now approaching 70 years of age and, therefore, having a preference to go to repatriation hospitals, will do so. But the Government is interested in providing the option for veterans who live far away from repatriation hospitals-and there is only one such general hospital in each State-to go into a hospital nearer their own home, for the convenience of not only the patient but also the spouse, who often is of the same age as the patient.

On agreeing to that process, the repatriation hospitals will take additional community patients on a quid pro quo basis with the State hospitals. For example, if 100 patients go into the Hobart or Launceston public hospitals an additional 100 community patients will be taken into the Hobart Repatriation General Hospital on an equity basis in terms of charges. That is what is proposed so that this side of the turn of the century there will be a clear future for those involved in repatriation hospitals. If we lose repatriation patients we will take more community patients. There is no possibility of the hospitals losing staff or their career positions being affected by the proposed changes. Because of the way that Commonwealth-State relations are conducted it will probably be several years before an equitable system will be worked out. The objectives have been set by the adoption of the Brand committee's recommendations. They will be in the interests of everybody concerned, including staff.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today in Question Time Senator McKiernan asked me a question about the dredging industry in Australia and Government assistance for it. I undertook to try to provide him with a more detailed reply than I was then able to give. The article in the Daily Commercial News about the dredging industry contains an allegation that the Belgian Government has subsidised the successful tenderer for the Woodside project. That tender has been awarded to a joint venture of the Australian company John Holland Constructions Pty Ltd and two Belgian companies for a contract price of some $30m. The Government has no evidence that such a subsidy has been paid to these companies. The Belgian Trade Commissioner has given assurances that that is not the case.

ANSWER.PARA: Regarding the various other matters raised, I offer the general observation that the dredging industry and other maritime service industries, such as oil drilling, are suffering because of a fall-off in development projects world-wide and excess capacity in supply. One can sympathise with the problems of local contractors. I can also understand that the cost savings from the large and technologically advanced vessels brought in from overseas, such as the one in question, can offset the costs of transportation and make the vessels very price competitive. That is an advantage to Australia in one way in that resource development projects are more likely to get off the ground or be expanded, thereby creating exports and jobs which might otherwise be lost. The production process of dredging employs Australians irrespective of whether a locally-based or foreign dredge is operating.

The second part of the honourable senator's question deals with other accusations against foreign dredging companies in the newspaper articles and the issue of Government policy on protective measures for locally-based companies. It is very difficult for me to comment on the allegations of delays and cost overruns on dredging contracts by foreign companies. I point out that such allegations are made frequently, whether foreign or locally-based companies are performing a contract. The point is that the managers of the development projects involved should have the responsibility for assessing tenders and letting contracts. This should not be subject to intervention by government.

On preferences, it has not been this Government's policy to interfere with commercial projects. To do so would be inconsistent with the Government's industry policy objectives. The thrust of those objectives is to reduce or eliminate the reliance of individual industries on protective measures and to apply general and positive programs aimed at enabling industries to become more internationally competitive. It is my view that major resource development projects must be free to acquire the supply of dredging services which are optimally suited to the project at hand. To sum up, I consider that locally-based dredging contractors are not being treated unfairly and should continue to be subject to open competition for efficient operations and technical capability.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Yesterday, Senator Puplick gave notice of motion condemning me for being absent from the Senate on Thursday, 5 June. I wish to make it clear to the Senate that I was absent that day due to pressing personal commitments and have been absent on only two other occasions this year. The amendment to which Senator Puplick referred had been left with staff of the Australian Democrats to be circulated at the appropriate time. I find it difficult to understand how Senator Puplick can condemn me for being absent for one day when his Victorian colleague, Senator Short, has been absent for 10 days this year, Senator Walters for 10 days and Senator Kilgariff for 11 days. I could go on. As far as I am concerned, Senator Puplick's attack on me is the worst kind of mud-slinging and brings no credit to this Parliament.

—by leave-I want to say very briefly that Senator Puplick only quoted Senator Haines's notice of motion. The point which was made in quoting Senator Haines was that the honourable senator was absent on commercial business. There is a very considerable difference between that and being absent on parliamentary business and on matters which are of general public concern. It was not the Opposition which raised this matter. It was brought into the Senate by way of explanation. All that the notice of motion did was draw attention to it. It is rather extraordinary that Senator Siddons should wish to draw further attention to the matter by making another statement today.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Puplick proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's failure to protect the interests and guarantee the future of regional television in Australia.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I submit the following matter for discussion in the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's failure to protect the interests and guarantee the future of regional television in Australia.

Throughout its history the Hawke Government has faced the dilemma of whether to look after the interests of the nation or the interests of its mates-great and small, little or powerful. In every instance the Government has preferred its mates to the nation, whether the mates happen to be the Australian Council of Trade Unions or, as in this case, the media magnates of Australia. This discussion deals with the future of regional television and the push by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) over the wishes of his Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) to increase the power of the networks and to destroy the viability of regional television. The great media magnates in this country-Kerry Packer, recently appointed by this Government to the board of the Australian Sports Foundation, and Rupert Murdoch-are closely allied with the Prime Minister and his factional bosses. The National Times report of 16 May 1986 states:

Graham Richardson, numbers man and senator from NSW, in a neo-punk slickback hairdo, lunched a few days ago in the boardroom of Channel 9, Sydney, with current affairs executives of the Packer network.
He asked: `If Laurie Brereton seeks to become Premier of New South Wales, have you forgotten Botany?'. The article continues:
Richardson's question was far from reassuring for Neville, but the answer was no comfort to Laurie. He was told: Botany is not forgotten.

In the race to succeed Neville Wran as Premier of New South Wales the original favourite, Mr Brereton, has found himself with his wings pulled off just like one of Barry Unsworth's butterflies. If one looks at the National Times report of 6 to 12 June 1986 dealing with the way in which media policies are made in this Government one reads in relation to Mr Peter Barron, one of the Prime Minister's favourite minders:
Sources say that all Cabinet submissions from Duffy are subject to Barron's scrutiny and that Cabinet consideration of at least one policy decision was held up while Barron examined the submission.
We know that there is now a ministerial council, a gang of four, who are in charge of television policy in Australia. The article continues:

At one meeting the Industry Minister, Senator John Button, reportedly asked Hawke, `Just tell us precisely how you want us to help your mates?' Hawke is reported to have replied, `Remember they're the only mates we've got.'
The mates referred to are Kerry Packer and Rupert Murdoch, owners of the Nine and Ten networks.
Barron has close links with Channel 9 executives, including the president, Sam Chisholm . . .

I venture to suggest that Mr Chisholm is shortly to be paid off with an appointment to the Australian Film Commission and that Channel 9 in the meantime is being looked after in terms of the expenses for tonight's broadcast by the Prime Minister. Not content with giving his mates jobs, not content with the Labor Party giving them jobs, lotteries, football pool arrangements and the like, the Labor Party now wants to give them regional television. To his credit, the Minister for Communications, Mr Duffy, wanted to allow regional television to grow and develop and to take advantage of the new methods of broadcasting throughout Australia, particularly those which arise from the launch of Aussat. But unfortunately for regional television, and unfortunately for the Minister for Communications, this would have meant ever-growing power of regional television at the expense of the increasing power of the media magnates upon whom this Government is becoming increasingly dependent.

Since the Minister for Communications could not prevail in Cabinet against the Prime Minister, a gang of four Ministers was established-Mr Hawke, Mr Keating, Mr Duffy and Senator Button. They are the ones responsible for bringing into the Parliament a statement on 20 May in which the Minister for Communications announced Labor's new policy for the future of regional commercial television services. That policy spells the potential death knell of regional television in Australia. It seeks, first, to bring about what is called equalisation of services. Nobody has any objection to equalisation of services; that is to say that people who live in regional Australia should be entitled to access to the same level of television broadcasting and the same number of channels as those who are fortunate enough to live in the major metropolitan markets.

There are a number of ways in which equalisation of television services could have been provided. However, the Government has adopted a particular method called aggregation, and indeed aggregation by a particular method. It will work on this basis: The Minister for Communications will unilaterally decide which areas of regional Australia are to be aggregated for the purposes of broadcasting law. There will be no reference to the Parliament on this matter; it will be done by fiat by the Minister. Those areas will include at least three television stations. Those stations will be forced to aggregate their market to blend and aggregate their programs, not by the choice of the majority of them or, indeed, even the unanimous choice, but by the choice of any one of them. Any one of the three may force all three into an aggregation.

Let me indicate to honourable senators one of the consequences that will flow. The plan to allow aggregation is vividly exposed if one looks at the position of Sunraysia's STV-8 in Mildura, a market for that station which covers 14,100 homes according to the Department of Communications report. The two adjoining markets most likely to be joined by Mildura are Associated Broadcasting Services BTV-6 in Ballarat with 176,000 homes, Southern Cross television's GLV-8 in Traralgon and BCV-8 in Bendigo with 119,600 homes. According to one broadcaster, all regional viewing markets would be split on the basis of a 40 per cent share for the indigenous broadcaster with 30 per cent for each new entrant. Based on these assumptions, Associated Broadcasting Services would show a 66,000 fall in the number of homes covered; Southern Cross would be down 14,000 homes, while Sunraysia would gain 84,400 homes in the market-not by the consent of the people concerned, not by the consent of those who are having markets taken away from them, not by the consent of the boards of those who are adversely affected, but simply by the decision of the smallest operator in the market to use the Minister's fiat to gain for himself a larger share of the market, a larger degree of revenue and to do it at the expense of existing broadcasters.

If one looks at the way in which this will operate, one can see numerous examples around Australia of companies and stations which will be adversely affected. My colleague Senator Parer has drawn my attention to the considerable difficulty that will be faced by Telecasters North Queensland Ltd in Townsville and Cairns. It will be unable to protect its regional market from penetration by programming from Brisbane; it will be unable to protect its uniquely regional services. My colleague Senator Michael Baume has drawn my attention to the position of TVW WIN-4 which broadcasts from Wollongong. It will, in fact, be forced to abandon a large part of its regional and local market to the penetration of the Sydney metropolitan market. Honourable senators from Tasmania should be aware that they are likely to find themselves aggregated in a service which includes Melbourne broadcasting; in other words, decisions about television broadcasting in Tasmania, particularly on the north coast of Tasmania, will be made subject to the dictates and to the whims of people supplying programming and services, not from within Tasmania but, indeed, from Melbourne.

There are two other major losers in the statement of 20 May to which I wish to refer briefly. The first is that country radio has been told that the Department of Communications will be so tied up with this aggregation arrangement for the next two years that there will be no extension of country radio services and there will be no dealing with the problems of country radio. Country radio will now have to wait for at least two years until the Department of Communications is ready to deal with it.

Secondly, there has been an abandonment of the system of supplementary licences. People who have invested millions of dollars throughout Australia in preparing applications for supplementary licences, people who have invested time, effort, research and expensive legal fees in putting forward their case for supplementary licences have been told by the Minister: `I am now cancelling the entire process'. It is no wonder, therefore, that there is a threat that the Government will be sued by Canberra Telecasters Ltd for a sum of up to $500,000 to recoup the money that that individual operator alone has lost by the abandonment of the supplementary licence system, with no indication that this was likely to happen and with no compensation offered for what amounts to one of the largest retrospective rip-offs of the economic position of any private operator of any business in Australia.

Mr Macphee, the shadow Minister for Communications, has indicated his strong opposition to the way in which the Government is proceeding in this fashion. He has drawn attention to the increasing concentration of media ownership and the reduction of localism in regional television. He made the point which I made earlier that the Government does not need to proceed in a legislative fashion to introduce the aggregation of existing service areas because service areas under legislation which this Parliament passed a year or so ago may be determined unilaterally by the Minister. In other words, the process of aggregation, the process of changing the whole basis upon which television policy and broadcasting policy in Australia is to be dealt with has been changed not by the Parliament deciding that it wanted a new system, but by the Minister deciding that he will impose a new system and not by the Minister who actually wants to protect regional television, but by the Prime Minister who wants to make sure that his powerful mates, the network operators, are allowed penetration into regional markets which previously have served a distinct and unique community and who, under the policy this Government is now pursuing, are absolutely doomed.

Just to make sure that the whip is cracked, that people know who the boss is, that they know what the potential cost of defiance is, we read in the statement of 20 May that the Government is reviewing the ownership and control provisions of the Broadcasting and Television Act. It has been reviewing these for a considerable time. The review was announced some years ago. Breaking up media concentration of ownership has been a matter about which the Labor Party traditionally said it was going to do something. We now read that it is looking to provide a system where there will be greater concentration of media ownership. But just so that everybody knows that the review will not simply be one which is ongoing, the Minister promises in his statement that the ownership and control issue will be addressed publicly and resolved by 31 October of this year. In other words, all of those who have an interest, particularly in the major media networks, are on clear notice. After tonight's speech to the nation by the Prime Minister and after the Budget which is to be brought down in August, the Prime Minister and his colleagues the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button)-three of the four members of the gang of four who are laying down their strategy, whether it happens to be for an early election or whether it is for some political stunt-should be on notice that, although they may criticise us in that period, they may well find that the ownership and control rules which we are currently reviewing and intend to have reviewed by 31 October may well come down in an entirely unsatisfactory fashion from their point of view. But I say: `Behave yourselves and not only will you get access to regional television markets and accessing to networking which you have sought for years and which has been denied to you by previous governments of both persuasions, but also the Labor Party's traditional policy of limiting ownership and control in broadcasting will be overturned'. One has to feel sympathy for the Minister for Communications. He was desperate to avoid this. As a result, there are a wonderful couple of throw-away lines in his statement in which he said to regional broadcasters: `Do not come to Cabinet for protection, but please let me draw your attention to the sections of the Trade Practices Act under which you may be able to protect yourselves from networking, and you may be able to protect yourselves from the media magnates and from the friends of the Prime Minister. I cannot do anything for you, but please look carefully at the provisions of the Trade Practices Act because you may be able to get some protection there. I cannot give it to you as the Minister because I am on the short end of the gang of four'.

Three of the four members have decided that looking after their great and powerful mates and sacrificing regional television in the process is the way in which they intend to go. If ever there were a sellout of people living in regional Australia, if ever there were a sellout of the local communities and of local broadcasters, this statement of 20 May 1986 proves once and for all that the Hawke Government, given a decision between protecting its mates and serving the nation, will opt for its big mates on every single occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend Senator Puplick for bringing on this matter of public importance in this neglected field of broadcasting. If the track records of the Department of Communications and the Government are any indication, there are many unfulfilled expectations ahead of us in this area and many more disappointments. What has emerged after years of bureaucratic manipulation and in-fighting is certainly a most disappointing result for regional Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Essentially, we have an election gimmick designed to secure marginal seats next time round. But will it? It is also a gimmick to offer, as Senator Puplick has said, patronage to the big and powerful friends of the Labor Cabinet. These things have a habit of backfiring and I am sure that this one will because none of us in this Senate will be silent and let it happen unchallenged. Clearly, the people of regional Australia have not been considered at all in this exercise. Nobody has really been asked what he wants. Three metropolitan networks will be thrust upon those people in some way or other. Maybe this is just another trilogy example. It seems that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) can only count up to three. Nothing will be done about the Sydney-Melbourne imbalance within the networks, despite the excellent arguments which have been put by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in its 1984 satellite program services report. I remind the Senate that the Tribunal raised the continuing process of centralising Australian media output. It said in its report:
The Sydney and Melbourne stations hold a position of dominant economic strength and influence within the system, quite out of proportion to the populations of Sydney and Melbourne.
There is a lack of opportunities for new television enterprises and for new companies to enter television.
There is a lack of opportunities for expansion and growth in television by companies based in such places as Brisbane, Adelaide, Perth, Newcastle, Wollongong, Canberra, Hobart and in regional areas.

The Tribunal suggested that the fundamental imbalance of economic power be addressed; that certainly has not been done. In fact, we are being moved in exactly the reverse direction. The regional areas are being handed over, holus-bolus, to the large networks in this area which will have complete control over the information in this country to use as they please. One of the reasons this is happening is that communications has been an area where there has been very little parliamentary scrutiny. There has been very little scrutiny of the broadcasting and information service. I hope that this matter of public importance marks a turning point. We will certainly be co-operating with the Opposition in scrutinising that area. The parliamentary scrutiny is a point which the Tribunal adverted to in its 1984 report.

What is the upshot of the Government's announcement in relation to regional television? Basically, the upshot is the aggregation of services in the regional areas at all costs. We are supposed to have a draft indicative plan for a carve-up of regional Australia into larger more viable markets by the end of July. It remains to be seen whether that can be done within the time. Certainly, the Department of Communications has had problems attracting and retaining the necessary engineering staff in the past, and apparently it has a shortfall now. The Government probably will have to look at the conditions of employment which are available in the frequency planning branch. The Government proposes that there be three months for public and industry comment before a final indicative plan of approved markets is published. If any licensee within an approved market chooses the path of aggregation, all licensees in that area have to make the adjustment to serve a broader region. They would, of course, be completely at the mercy of the three large commercial networks unless they start a rapid program of tapping alternative film sources within Australia and getting their own representatives to buy from overseas. The Government intends to allow one licensee to make the decision for the whole region and that is to be regarded as prima facie evidence that aggregation is viable. This is the sort of nonsense that could only be dreamt up in Canberra and the sort of nonsense that brings this place into disrepute.

The Australian Democrats have certainly had feedback on this proposition from various regional licensees. My colleague in the South Australian Legislative Council, Ian Gilfillan, has been approached by very concerned operators of the commercial television station in the Riverland area. Senator Chipp has forwarded to me a copy of a letter sent to him by the General Manager of WIN-TV, which is known throughout the country for its strong involvement in community matters in the Illawarra area. As Senator Puplick has said, WIN-TV faces the risk of being aggregated with a much larger and more powerful urban area to its north. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the letter written from WIN-TV, which I think is illustrative of the problems.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
3 June 1986
Senator The Hon. D. L. Chipp MP
Leader of the Australian Democrats
Parliament House
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Senator Chipp,

The Minister for Communications' (The Hon. Michael Duffy) policy statement on the future of regional commercial television has been considered by our board and by our industry body-Regional Television Australia.
I feel it is important that you be made aware of our feelings on this policy statement.
We strongly oppose the method by which the Government proposes to equalise commercial television services in regional Australia.

Our principal objection to the Government's plan is in regard to the intention to force all licensees in an approved market to aggregate if just one licensee chooses the aggregation path to equalisation-i.e. the ``one in, all in'' rule.
We totally reject the notion (and I quote from paragraph 20 of the Minister's statement) that there is ``prima facie evidence that the aggregation involved is viable''.
This is an absurd notion that is unprecedented in the free enterprise business environment.
The Government claims that its policy announced on 20 May, 1986 will give regional licensees a choice between MCS and aggregation.
For the majority of regional licensees no such choice exists.
The future of our companies will be determined not by our boards or management, but by a decision to be taken by another licensee.
This decision making process, not by majority, but by minority, is undemocratic and against all principles of natural justice.

We find totally abhorrent a situation whereby a corporate policy decision by one business enterprise automatically at law imposes the same policy on other enterprises irrespective of whether it is commercially viable for those other enterprises to operate under that policy arrangement. The Government's policy encourages this to happen.

We recognise that some small stations, that might struggle to survive under the burden of providing additional services, may see long term strategic advantages in aggregating immediately because it will give them a substantial share of larger licensees' revenue. This would have the effect of either forcing the other licensees into a loss situation if they were to attempt to maintain their current standards of service or alternatively force the larger stations to scale down their television operations and lower the standard of their services to that proposed by the smaller station.
Either way the result will be the abandonment or very significant reduction of localism, reduction in production and employment and a general lowering of the standards of regional television.

It appears to us that the two key Government broadcasting objectives, namely the encouragement of production and employment, together with localism in regional areas, have been ignored in this policy statement.

We oppose the concept of an Indicative Plan which, when finalised, will dictate how regional markets may or may not be aggregated. This is a matter that should be left to the commercial judgment of those licensees involved in negotiating to move from operating services under the MCS scheme to operating competitive services.
These are our principal objections to the Government's policy.

We, through Regional Television Australia, intend to meet with the Government at the earliest opportunity to assert our opposition to those parts of the policy that we believe prejudice the prompt but orderly growth of additional services in regional areas.
WIN TV has for many years supported additional choice for regional viewers, first under the supplementary licence scheme and subsequently through the multi-channel service concept.

We intend to reaffirm our commitment to the provision of additional services through MCS. This will meet the Government's objective of three services in the majority of regional areas by 1990 and competition by 1996.

TWT Limited has developed positively over the past twenty years to become a significant employer and a respected corporate citizen serving the Illawarra, South Coast and Southern Tablelands. This policy of forced aggregation, coming on top of the possibility of being forcibly transferred from VHF to UHF is a catastrophic blow to WIN TV.
Yours faithfully
JOHN I. RUSHTON
General Manager

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Rushton, the General Manager, pointed out how abhorrent it is that corporate policy made by one business enterprise automatically at law becomes policy for other enterprises. He pointed out that stations will go into a loss situation if they attempt to maintain their current standards of service or they will no longer be able to maintain those standards-they will have to lower their standards to a lower common denominator. Either way, Mr Rushton said, the result will be the abandonment or very significant reduction of localism, a reduction in local production and employment, and a general lowering of the standards of regional television. He is saying that additional advertising revenue will not cover the additional expenditure required of the stations under this new regime.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government acknowledges that, though the tax carrots it is offering in its equalisation exercises do look quite attractive, it is forcing the issue. All UHF television transmitters purchased specifically for equalisation purposes are to be exempt from sales tax. That is useful. For those licensees who opt for aggregation, all of the television licence fees are to be rebated in the 1986-87 year. For the next three years the rebate level drops 25 per cent each year. The Government estimates that the total subsidy in this area will be $10m on the equipment and $22m on the fees forgone. In return, we will get infrastructure which will be more or less superseded technologically. Indeed, it will be completely superseded by the time it comes into use.

The alternative to aggregation will be the issuing of one or two supplementary television permits to the current licensee in a particular area. These permits are to be issued for one year and to be renewed annually for a maximum of 10 years. No real indication is available of the procedures for renewal. This leads to possible instability in the area. I do not believe it will improve the quality of services. It just means that these are ripe plums to be gradually picked by the large networks as the ownership requirements are relaxed more and more in the course of time. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal will need extra resources to implement these procedures. One of the things I will come to a bit later is what is happening with the current level of resources. The Tribunal should have been given these extra resources some time ago. I am pleased to see that at last it has approval to move all of its operations to Sydney. That should make it a more efficient organisation.

There is certainly a need to improve the attitude of the Department of Communications in relation to providing services to people. The supplementary licence scheme, with all of its deficiencies, certainly was not given a fair go. The Department could have moved to undo some of the log-jams of which it has complained. It has not faced up to its responsibilities in this matter. For instance, it could have easily examined the New Zealand approach of setting population levels as prima facie evidence of the necessity for at least one new licence. It could have sought to truncate hearings into a single process instead of the two processes that are necessary in considering whether a supplementary licence or a new licence is to be introduced. None of this streamlining has been provided.

As well as this, we have the problems that have been raised in the Canberra and Mildura areas, where the introduction of this new policy has resulted in severe commercial disadvantage to particular firms that were offering to provide a good service in those areas. These firms had taken very seriously previous offers by the Government within the framework of the existing legislation. Suddenly, many applicants for licences were completely devoid of any future. Their future was denied them. I believe that this is typical of the ad hockery we have been getting from this Government in this area of communications.

Another relevant matter arises from Estimates Committee hearings. The answers relate to the statement on equalisation. They relate both to the Department's failure to deliver the expectations that it creates and to the Department's inability to deal with some of the issues surrounding the licence-hearing process. In 1981 and 1982 Senator Teague probed representatives from the Department of Communications about delays in licence application processing. The Committee was given a very rosy picture of what the streamlined procedures would mean in relation to expressions of interest in a licence. In those days, the Department was able to fill all the engineering positions available to it, which apparently is not the case now. On 19 April 1982 Mr Westerway of the Department made these comments:

At the last Senate Estimates Committee, I did talk about the new planning procedures which we are introducing and those are well underway. Everyone who is on our list of people who are interested in new licences has been contacted in the last few weeks or will be contacted in the next couple of weeks. We hope as a result of the working party which I mentioned last time to increase our productivity in that area from 70 a year to 100.
By that he meant an increase in the number of licences being processed in a year from 70 to 100 licences. He continued:
But that is not as a result of the increased resources; that is as a result of introducing streamlined planning procedures.

Senator Teague immediately established that the 70 new licences applied only to 1981 and included national stations-the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and such like-which were expected in that year.

I now wish to look at that answer in the light of the Department's actual performance. I obtained answers last year about the 800-odd expressions of interest which the Department had outstanding on 20 August 1985. At that stage, the Department was working on 25 proposals for new radio licences, 12 proposals under the self-help television reception scheme, 65 supplementary radio proposals and 31 supplementary television proposals. There were 33 proposals for translators or variations to operating conditions for stations and 20 other matters relating to self-help television. Last August there were 27 proposals and 800-odd expressions of interest with the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. I did not seek updated figures at the recent Estimates Committee hearings because I am aware of the policy vacuum that has existed in that area and of the problems the Department has had in attracting and keeping first-rate engineering staff. The rewards of commercial industry and Telecom Australia are very much more lucrative than those which are offered within the Department, and there is not the constant drain of a lot of work to be done with seemingly very little progress in the sense that only a few new licences are being granted on a yearly basis. I repeat that there have been 800 expressions of interest, and only 27 cases were before the Tribunal. In fact, very few notices are going up to the Tribunal even now. It is not at all clear just how the Government expects all of its indicative planning in this area and in response to its new policy to be carried out. How will this aggregation actually work? How are things to be in place by the end of the year, let alone by the end of July, as claimed?

I would like to know what the Government will do to increase the number of planning staff on deck to at least the current ceilings or whether it intends to recruit people over and above that figure to try to meet the deadlines. Will the Government be improving the terms and conditions in an attempt to recruit more experienced and technical staff? One could go on with this. I do not believe that the Department is in a position currently to fulfil the Government's needs in this area. It may just be an election offer. It will be very useful to know what delays are expected in implementing any of these policy items, and whether proper thought has been given to the program quality implications of this policy. We need to think about new proposals for the restructuring of the medium. We need to take an intelligent look at these areas. We need new proposals, not just this type of aggregation and the handing over of our regional areas to the city operators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak in this debate, because I consider that I am much more representative of regional Australia than is either Senator Puplick or Senator Vigor. Despite the doom and gloom, fear and smear tactics we have heard as usual in the Opposition's attack this afternoon, I am not aware of many of the dire predictions they have made. Certainly, to acknowledge the concern of the regional television operators, I would say that a great deal more consultation can take place. From the general community I have heard nothing but congratulations to the Government for giving the community, at long last, a choice. It is that kind of direct contact that I have had with people in regional areas, who want to know only whether they will have equal services with the people in city areas.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Puplick, as usual, took this debate as an occasion on which to be negative, to criticise the Government, and to indicate that there was no merit whatever in the Government's proposal. I consider that his regional interest-a new-found regional interest, I might add-is somewhat suspect, given his Party's absolute commitment to privatisation. I also find it somewhat suspect when it is considered that in 1982 the then Minister for Communications was Neil Brown, who was about to hand over the satellite without strings to the networks. Yet in this debate Senator Puplick and Opposition spokesmen on other occasions have spoken out as if they have never had such a close relationship with the networks. It was only after a delegation representing broader broadcasting and television interests went to Mr Brown in 1982 that certain modifications started to be thought about by the then Opposition, which were then taken up completely when the present Government had to consider Aussat and other matters we are debating today. Furthermore, I remind honourable senators to look at the original membership of the board of Aussat, which indicates that the Opposition was very close to the networks in choosing appointees to the Aussat Board at that time.

I turn to some other points made by Senator Puplick. First, he made no acknowledgement of any positive factors associated with the Government's-and particularly the Minister's- patience in the extensive consultations and negotiations to try to bring forward what is acceptable to all interests. I pay tribute to the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) for the extensive consultation that has gone on, and is still going on. Senator Vigor talked about maps being drawn and everything being in place in July. I do not know where he gets that idea from because consultation is an ongoing process.

Judging by Senator Puplick's remarks, there is no indication that the Opposition is interested in what the people think. Do Opposition members have any evidence of what people in regional areas feel about this matter? Have they conducted surveys? Have they any evidence that the people of regional Australia do not want a choice? If they have such evidence, I would be interested to see it. I suggest that it might be a good idea for some of these city-based Opposition senators to get out into regional Australia and ask people whether they want a choice of three channels. I think they will find that the overwhelming answer is yes. Further, if those honourable senators can bear to leave the comforts of the capital cities, perhaps they would like to go into more remote areas and ask people there how they view this Government's initiatives in planning for remote areas.

Neither Senator Puplick nor Senator Vigor recognised the considerable employment benefits that will follow the Minister's announcement. I refer to jobs in supplying and installing new equipment, jobs in new studios, jobs in production, and so on and so forth, which are considerable. I would have thought the Opposition would have shown some interest in the job creation aspects of this proposal.

Finally, and probably most importantly, I point out that neither of the Opposition spokespeople has any understanding of the process that is leading up to the indicative plan, which will be going to Cabinet at the end of July and will be available for broad industry and community discussion, comment and input. Nothing has been finalised. The Minister has made a statement of broad principle but the indicative plan has yet to be brought down. I fail to comprehend how Opposition senators can come into this place and grandstand about the ending of choice for people in the regional areas when the indicative plan has not yet even been brought down.

Senator Puplick talked about penetration into regional markets and concern in regional areas, and Senator Vigor said that three channels will be imposed on regional areas. Again, I would make the point that already regional channels currently rely on their programming from those same three channels. It sounds as if Senator Puplick and Senator Vigor fondly imagine that everything to be seen on regional television is of local content. I must admit that on occasion I wish that it were. Regional commercial television does a magnificent job in pursuing localism in news, sport, weather, and the occasional local production-very occasional because the necessary resources are not available in regional areas. For the greater part of the time regional television channels have to rely on selecting their programs from the existing three major networks. While I am talking about the three major networks, I take the opportunity to say that I wish the commercial channels would place greater priority on Australian programming, particularly leading up to our Bicentenary. The Australian Broadcasting Corporation has set a very high standard for local productions and, frankly, if I must watch a crime television series I would much prefer to watch one with Australian content rather than the usual diet of American crime movies that we so often get.

I return to the issue we are debating today. It is interesting that Senator Puplick should have brought on this matter of public importance today because quite coincidentally, I am sure, Mr Peter Westerway and senior Department of Communications officials are in Sydney at the moment as part of the process of consultation with the regional television interests. They are attending the Regional Television Association conference where they will give further details on just what is involved and what the regional television networks can expect in the indicative plan. I wish to answer some of the ill-informed criticisms that have come forth today. One of the criticisms was that the Minister's announcement in some way pandered to the networks. Three commercial television services could be provided cheaply and efficiently throughout Australia using program feeds from the Sydney and Melbourne networks. The reason the Government has not opted for this is precisely that it does not want a few big companies completely controlling commercial television. Had it wanted that, it would not be going through this extensive process of consultation and negotiation with the regional networks. That is going on this very day. The equalisation policy gives the regional stations an opportunity to demonstrate that they can provide diversity of choice in commercial television.

The second argument that has been put forward is the so-called destruction of localism and local employment. Again, it is precisely because the Government values local news, sport, weather and so on that it has developed an approach whereby regional licensees can continue to play this independent role. I note that the legislation last year allowing for local origination from any transmitter is important in this regard and the amount of local programs and advertising shown by any particular station will be determined by how much support the licensee gets from that community. The multi-channel option has been called a non-option. The choice is free. If the three regional licensees in a designated area believe that only multi-channelled services will work, they have only to say so and the Government will accept that view. This afternoon we have heard gloom and doom from the Opposition, yet the Government has made that commitment and the Minister has announced it in the other place.

Finally, there has been a claim that the minority would dictate to others. There has already been nearly three years' debate on this matter. I do not know where Senator Vigor has been in the past three years, but we have already had three years' discussion on the concept of aggregation; there have been innumerable industry meetings, seminars, public conferences, articles in the Press and parliamentary debates. We have now invited both the licensees and the public to comment on the draft indicative plan. I suggest to both Senator Puplick and Senator Vigor that they watch closely for that indicative plan, travel into regional areas and get the views of the people in those areas as well as those of the regional television stations and then they can come back and see what they have to say on this matter then.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON AN AUSTRALIA CARD

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Recommendations, Government Response and Text of Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This statement has been brought forward in indecent haste and indeed it is, in all respects, an indecent statement. In the past couple of days the Government, in turning around on the question of the Australia Card, has attempted to put forward a series of false statements to the people of Australia. For instance, it is indicated that the use of the Australia Card in its revised form would be confined to public presentation in only three departments-the Australian Taxation Office, the Department of Social Security and the Health Insurance Commission. These would be the only departments to have access to the card. However, if honourable senators read the Minister's statement more closely, they will see that the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the Australian Institute of Health and the Australian Bureau of Statistics are quietly tucked into the statement already at this stage. Therefore the three have already become six.

A whole series of very false assumptions have been made by the Government about the revenue to be raised. Despite the fact that the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) in his statement clearly indicated on page 3 that he placed little reliance on the figures of the Department for savings from Immigration and Ethnic Affairs-otherwise he would not have agreed with the recommendations and the comments of the Committee-he nevertheless uses the Department's bogus figures in order to substantially boost the alleged revenue from the card and he claims that there will be greater revenue obtained from tracking down social service fraud. This is despite the fact that in the Australian on 7 June 1986, the Special Minister of State, Mr Young, said in relation to high levels of estimates of social security fraud:
These assessments could be exaggerated.
Yesterday in this very place Senator Grimes said:
It is only too easy, in the atmosphere that exists in the community now, in which people are willing to exaggerate wildly the extent of social security fraud, to look for scapegoats.

Therefore two of the Ministers in Dr Blewett's own Government have clearly indicated in the course of the last few days that the Minister for Health is misleading people in attempting to say that there will be larger revenues from eliminating social security fraud. The Minister has admitted that he has no idea what the cost will be to the private sector. However, the Director of the Government's own Business Regulation Review Unit, Dr Alan Moran, is reported as saying that the rule of thumb used by the unit was that all new regulations would cost the private sector twice the costs incurred by the Government. The Government itself is planning to spend more than $1 billion on the process; thus, the Government's own Business Regulation Review Unit calculates that the cost to the private sector will be in excess of $2 billion. Mr Alan Cullen of the Australian Bankers' Association has indicated that his Association regards the implications for the private sector as being `extremely costly'.
In its report the Joint Select Committee referred to evidence from the Australian Taxation Office when it said in paragraph 4.16:

In response to questions by the Committee, the ATO agreed that a tax file number with a level of integrity similar to that proposed for the Australia Card would produce similar revenue gains to those estimated under the Australia Card without photo option, with similar staff and equipment costs.

That statement was made in a letter to the Committee from the Second Commissioner of Taxation. The Joint Select Committee has recommended a tax file number of improved integrity which would yield, at the same cost to the Government, the same amount of revenue as the Australia Card without a photograph. This was based on figures that the Government and the Taxation Office had supplied.

As people have become more and more aware of the Government's proposal, public opinion is changing. Polls have been cited claiming that there is overwhelming support for the card, but I read in the Melbourne Herald of 5 June 1986:
Polls reveal a majority of Australians are now opposed to the introduction of a national identity card.

I also look at a report in the Daily Mirror of 6 June in which the Real Estate Institute of New South Wales has said it is prepared to fight the introduction of a national identity card. Senator Tate will undoubtedly be very interested in an article in the Australian on 10 June headed `Anglicans get ready to fight the card' referring to the diocese of Perth. The whole proposal is being put forward in a dishonest and disrepu- table fashion by the Minister for Health. He is exaggerating the gain to revenue and minimising the cost to the private sector and to State and local governments. He is deliberately obscuring the number of departments which will have access to the card and he is deliberately misrepresenting the claims and recommendations made by the majority of committee members, including a member of the Australian Labor Party, in their report that use of the tax file number system with improved integrity will yield the same amount in revenue as the Australia Card option without the photograph. He is deliberately misrepresenting the claims and the recommendations in the report by the majority, including a member of the Australian Labor Party, that the tax file number system with improved integrity, which is what the Joint Select Committee actually recommends, will yield the same amount in revenue as the Australia Card option without the photograph. Under these circumstances, I believe that the Minister stands condemned for having tried to rush into this Parliament in record time a response to a major joint select committee report in order to prevent the required degree of public debate taking place on this subject.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. On at least five or six occasions in the last long breathless paragraph of his speech, Senator Puplick accused a Minister, a member of another place, of deliberately misleading the Australian public. I regard that as quite different from merely misleading, which could be done in good faith from a lack of sufficient comprehension of the subject matter. To `deliberately mislead' is the equivalent of lying to the public. I therefore ask that that be withdrawn.
—I am sorry, there is no point of order.
—What a lot of nonsense.
—Does the honourable senator wish to dissent from the Chair's ruling?
—I would be very tempted to.
—Well, the honourable senator can do so in writing, if he wants. I have been given advice that there is no point of order. I do not like the attitude. I call Senator Haines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly have to agree with Senator Puplick to the extent that the misinformation that has been allowed to make its way into the community about this proposal is probably second only to the misinformation put forward by Holinshed and Shakespeare that allows the blame for the murder of the princes in the tower to be laid in the hands of Richard III. Certainly the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) has allowed the general public to believe that this card will be able to be used to stop a number of things which have absolutely nothing at all to do with social security and tax fraud. For example, large numbers of people in the community believe that it is going to be used legitimately to put an end to things like under-age drinking. Of course, the Minister indicated recently that that is not going to be the case, that there are going to be very specific uses for the card and that the use by hoteliers to check on the age of someone who asks for a drink is certainly not going to be one of them.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, nobody in this place, or anywhere else I would have thought, objects to the Government's attempt to put an end to the sort of tax and social security fraud which is, in essence, ripping off the general public and depleting Government coffers to a quite unacceptable level. Neither does anyone in here or anywhere else reject the idea that something has to be done to stop it. However, when the Minister rejects suggestions from people like Mr Frank Costigan, who ought to have some expertise in these areas, he has to give more of a reason for doing so than the rather flip comments he makes in the paper that he has brought down as a response to the majority report of the Joint Select Committee on an Australian Card. He acknowledges at the beginning of his statement that the Committee has put in a lot of work, that it has heard large numbers of witnesses-it heard evidence from something like 168 witnesses representing 83 organisations and 18 individuals-and that it has been engaged in a large number of public hearings, and still argues that the considered majority report, which was signed by a member of each political party represented in this place, is wrong. One can only suggest that in that stance he is being nothing short of obdurate, that he is acting like a child who is not getting his own way when playing cricket and is simply being rude to the umpire. That essentially is what is happening in this case. His rejection of the majority report's findings with regard to the use of the tax file number is trite, to say the very least.

There is no doubt at all-and Senator Puplick has just mentioned this-that the Australian Taxation Office did say to the Committee that the use of a tax file number, if given sufficient integrity, would bring in the same amount of revenue as would be raised by the proposal that the Government put to the Committee last year. That the Taxation Office did it under duress does not, of course, do anything at all to the validity of its comment except, perhaps, to make it more believable since it did not want to make that sort of statement at all.

One is forced to ask why the Minister is persisting in going ahead with a system, starting from scratch, which in the first instance will require, of course, the upgrading of birth, death and marriage record systems; which is then going to cost something like $600m to establish; which will involve another $100m to $110m a year in running costs; and which does not even look like making a profit for at least five years. The proposal put forward by the Australian Taxation Office, under questioning from the Committee, was that a fiscal identification system can be established quite adequately by using as a base the current tax file system; that documentation concerning proof of identity that needs to be brought forward by people who are applying for a new tax file number be upgraded; that people who have had a tax file number for less than five years would be expected to go through the same process; and that those who have had tax file numbers for more than five years be gradually caught up with. That at least would avoid the expenditure of large amounts of money by the Government. It would be used in the same manner that the current Government is expecting the Australia Card to be used; that is, for bank account applications, for applying for jobs and social security benefits and for engaging in other financial transactions.

If the Government, in essence, wants to operate in this country a personal identification system which can be used either now or in the future as an internal passport system, it ought to come out and say so. If it simply wants everybody who is engaging in financial transactions to be part of a fiscal identification system, it can do that quite adequately by building on a system which is already in existence, which already covers large numbers of people and which will not turn into the compulsory universal system that the Australia Card has every likelihood of turning into.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

The 1985 annual report of the Commonwealth Schools Commission gives considerable emphasis to the quite radical changes that have been brought about as a result of legislation passed in this Parliament involving the transfer of administrative functions of the Schools Commission to the Department of Education and the incorporation under the umbrella of the Schools Commission of the Curriculum Development Centre. On a quick reading of the report, which has only just been made available to us, proper weight has been given to these quite major changes to the activities of the Schools Commission. As is well known, the State governments are responsible for the curriculum in government schools-as independent schools are responsible for their curriculum-and, indeed, for most of the resources and most of the moneys that are available within the schools system. But the Commonwealth has supplemented the programs.

It has been the role of the Commonwealth Schools Commission to be the advisory body dealing with the distribution of resources among programs and with each program in each State. This report demonstrates that, under the present Government, the Schools Commission has become a much more directly an advisory body, giving directions as to how the special programs that supplement what is happening in the States should be acted upon by the Commonwealth. In this respect, it is still too early to come to a final decision about the effect of these new roles for the Schools Commission. This report will be important in evaluating that effect once we have had more time to read it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1985 annual report of the Commonwealth Schools Commission is interesting for those people in the community who believe that government should restrain and cut back its expenditure and yet who rarely have any idea of the types of functions that a variety of commissions and boards are expected to carry out and do carry out. They should take the trouble to read a number of the reports that are released each day. When one talks to individuals in the community, it is interesting that there is very little dispute as to whether or not governments should be involved in this or that activity. If one asks, `should governments be doing this or should governments be doing that?', by and large one gets an affirmative answer from members of the community. They say: `Yes, it should. That is excellent expenditure of taxpayers' money'.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw the attention of the Senate to a couple of items in this report. In their case only a small amount of money is involved. I refer to enrichment programs which are vitally necessary to the people they affect. The two items in the report are on page 21 and page 22. I refer to the $3.75m which is expended on severely disabled children. This money goes out to government and non-government organisations and to individual parents to provide opportunities for severely disabled children who might otherwise receive little or no formal schooling. The amount involved is very small; yet the way it is currently administered by the Schools Commission gives a great deal of help and assistance to many parents-I know that because I have met many of those parents who have received money under this program-and to many organisations who are able to provide enrichment to those severely disabled children around Australia. I believe this activity has the support of all members of the Senate and it would have the support of the majority of people in the community if they were able and willing to voice an opinion on this issue. Likewise, the item on page 22, which relates to children in residential institutions, receives a very small amount-$2.34m. This money is provided to children in Australia who are still living in institutions, although the numbers of such children are not very high. In fact, the bulk of those children are now living in institutions of a penal variety of one kind or another. I do not necessarily mean that they are living in prisons, but they are in institutions operating under some type of order from a court. Those institutions now house the vast bulk of the children. There are still some institutions which look after children in a care situation, although, with the movements in foster-parenting in this country, that number is decreasing. I think we are all thankful that that is the case.

However, I draw to the minds of those listening and to honourable senators the fact that this is taxpayers' money which is being expended to assist in giving those children in residential institutions and under other types of institutional care some type of family background inasmuch as it can be provided by money-of course, very little can be provided-or additional resources to give them the kinds of experiences which are enjoyed by children who live at home and go to normal schools and operate in the ordinary wider community. Again, a small amount of money is involved in providing for a very enriching experience. I hope that, as the community debate extends as to whether or not government should expend money and whether we should have smaller government, at some stage people will get down to the nitty-gritty and start to say why they believe those types of programs should be cut. If we do not do that, I am fearful that disabled children and children in institutions are likely to be the first victims of the ideological approach.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission's review of technical and further education funding is the first major examination of technical and further education funding for 12 years. In the last 12 years there has been a massive increase in TAFE resources. Additional Commonwealth moneys, in particular, have helped students in many TAFE colleges undertake courses of technical and further education. I say rather partisanly as a Liberal senator from South Australia that this expansion occurred during the period of the Fraser Government. This report spells out very carefully, looking back on those 12 years, the 6 per cent growth in real terms in the moneys that have been made available to TAFE and the similar increase in enrolments for each year as an average over the last decade. The task given to the committee of review, which was chaired by Mr Hugh Hudson, the Chairman of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission, was to consider the most appropriate role for the Commonwealth to play in giving such supplementary grants to TAFE.

Broadly speaking, the report urges that the present variety of flexible funding mechanisms continue and that the Commonwealth continues to supplement the States, but on precise grounds. The first principle of funding that the Committee has resolved upon is that the framework of financial arrangements for TAFE be maintained in terms of the existing Commonwealth-State partnership. This partnership is based on the States continuing to be responsible for ongoing recurrent and equipment costs and the Commonwealth continuing to be responsible for supplementary recurrent and equipment programs designed to meet specific Commonwealth objectives and a shared Commonwealth-State responsibility for capital development.

As anyone in Australia who has been involved with the TAFE sector of education will know, over the last decade many new buildings have been established to provide facilities to technical and further education students more comparable with those which have been available for a much longer period to students of universities and colleges of advanced education. And why not? I was proud of being associated in the last Government with the priority given to technical and further education because, in our economic and social development, we have much to gain from ensuring that our technicians are as well trained as our doctors, engineers and teachers. The tasks that have been given to TAFE have now been made more achievable because of the quite enormous capital that has been newly injected into TAFE.

This report, which reviews a period of more than a decade, confirms that there is still an important role for the Commonwealth to play in supplementing the States in a similar way to that of recent years. The report contains a profile of 15-year-olds to 19-year-olds as they will be at the end of this decade and in 1992. At the end of the next six years there will be approximately the same number of 15-year-olds to 19-year-olds as there are now-1.3 million. During the coming six years, unemployment is projected to decline massively as a result of increased enrolments in TAFE, higher education, secondary schools and apprenticeship and trainee programs. This is a welcome profile. It reinforces the view of the Opposition which is that the worst activity for 15-year-olds to 19-year-olds is to be unemployed. I welcome the profile and hope that it can be achieved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I was concluding my speech in reply on the Copyright Amendment Bill 1986 before the suspension of the sitting for lunch. The final point I wanted to make was about the second objection of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills which raised the question as to whether or not there was some element of retrospectivity in a provision exposing people to liability for a first conviction after the coming into force of this Act. It is my unquestioned belief that the proper interpretation of the clauses in question is that the new increased penalty scale is applicable only to a first conviction which occurs after the date of the coming into effect of the new provision. The particular clause that has provoked the concern is clause 133a (1) (c) which, in relation to a person being guilty of an offence punishable upon conviction, states:

SPEECH.PARA: Where it is the first conviction of the person of an offence against this sub-section (including this sub-section as in force before the commencement of section 17 of the Copyright Amendment Act 1986) . . .

Then it sets out the fine, which represents a substantial increase on the present levels. The point is simply that it is written in this way to ensure that someone who has been convicted under the previous law and is convicted again after the present law comes into effect cannot claim that his most recent conviction is his first conviction. It is written in such a way to ensure that, if he is being convicted for the second time, it will be acknowledged to be a conviction for the second time and, accordingly, one in respect of which higher penalties apply. It will not be a situation where he will be exposed to the higher penalty for a genuine first conviction. That is not the way it can be read on any reasonable interpretation of the clause.

If there is any further argument about this, no doubt we can have it in the Committee stage. I simply wanted to respond to Senator Haines's suggestion that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) had in some way not fully appreciated the point of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee in his reply which Senator Haines read into the record. I simply say that I have had a careful look at it. I believe that the Attorney-General's reply very accurately stated what is the law and what it would be interpreted to be by the court. There is no question of someone being inflicted with a higher penalty based on an offence committed before the coming into effect of this law. It is simply not a possible interpretation and, to the extent that the Committee believes that it is, it is on the wrong horse. With those remarks, I commend the Bill to the Senate and look forward to an interesting debate in the Committee stage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
