TALK.START.PARA: —I have distributed two amendments to the Copyright Amendment Bill but before I proceed to move those amendments, I would like to raise a matter with the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), representing the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), concerning the provisions in clauses 3 and 5 which deal with the new definitions relating to broadcasting from satellites. I think I will have to deal with those two clauses together because the concern that has been expressed seems to cover both areas. The Minister seems to be unassisted at the moment and I do not know whether he will get very far with those clauses.
—They are on their way; try your luck.
—Would the Minister rather that I moved my amendments first?
—I would prefer you to go on with the amendments because I am in a position to respond to them. I may not be able to help you at this stage with the other matter.
—I think that might be better in the circumstances, but I want to come back to those clauses, of course. I shall now move the first amendment. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 9, after clause 13, insert the following new clause:
``13a. After section 112 of the Principal Act, the following section is inserted in Division 6 of Part IV:
`Use of certain broadcasts by educational institutions

`112a. (1) This section applies to a television broadcast and a sound broadcast in which copyright subsists in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation or in the Special Broadcasting Service or in both of those bodies jointly.
`(2) The copyright in a television broadcast or a sound broadcast to which this section applies is not infringed by-
(a) the making of a cinematograph film or a sound recording of the whole or part of the broadcast; or
(b) the rebroadcast of the whole or a part of the broadcast,

where the making of the film or recording or the rebroadcast is undertaken by or on behalf of an educational institution and is reasonably required for the teaching purposes of that institution or of any other educational institution.

`(3) For the purposes of sub-section (2), and without limiting the generality of that sub-section, the making of a film or recording or a rebroadcast shall be taken to have been undertaken for the teaching purposes of an educational institution where-
(a) it is undertaken in connection with a course of instruction provided by the institution; or
(b) it is undertaken for the purpose of including an item in a library of the institution.

`(4) Where a cinematograph film, a sound recording or a rebroadcast is made in the circumstances referred to in sub-section (2), copyright in that film, sound recording or rebroadcast subsists in the body, or the bodies jointly, in which the copyright subsisted in the television or sound broadcast of which the film, recording or rebroadcast was made.

`(5) At the commencement of each television broadcast and each sound broadcast to which this section applies, and in any announcement or advertisement relating to such a broadcast, a statement shall be made, and, in the case of a television broadcast, sub-titles shall be displayed, in the form set out in sub-section (6).
`(6) A statement and sub-titles referred to in paragraph (5) shall be in the following form-

``Copyright in this broadcast subsists in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation [or the Special Broadcasting Service or the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service, as the case requires].

``Copyright is not infringed if this broadcast is copied or rebroadcast by or on behalf of an educational institution for the teaching purposes of that or any other educational institution. Only such copies or rebroadcasts can be made as are reasonably required for those teaching purposes and copyright in those copies or rebroadcasts subsists in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation [or the Special Broadcasting Service or the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service, as the case requires].

``This is not a complete statement of the copyright position in respect of the material just described. Refer to the Copyright Act 1968. Definitions of `educational institution' and `teaching purposes' may also be found in that Act.''.'.''.

As I foreshadowed in my speech in the second reading debate, this amendment relates to the use of certain broadcasts by educational institutions. I indicated that the Opposition was very disappointed with the fact that, despite the time available to the Government and despite the very useful issues paper dealing with audio-visual copying which was prepared by the Attorney- General's Department in 1981 and 1982, this Bill does not provide anything at all to cope with the very strong demand for audio-visual copying for educational purposes by educational institutions.

The Minister mentioned in his second reading speech and again in reply to the second reading debate that quite a number of negotiations have been taking place with educational institutions in relation to this matter. I am aware, from my own experience, of the complexities of copyright law and attempts to amend it, having been through the process which led to the provisions about photocopying in 1980. Nevertheless, it seems extraordinary that, four years after the departmental issues paper was prepared, these matters have not been able to be resolved. It seems to me from what has been said by the Minister in his second reading speech that the Government is seeking to develop a statutory licence for educational institutions in relation to audio-visual copying along the lines of the statutory licence for photocopying by educational institutions. I wish those negotiations well although, as I have said, I express my disappointment that they have not yet been completed. But that is a pretty ambitious sort of exercise to undertake. As I have said, I have some personal experience of the magnitude of those sorts of negotiations, following the insertion into the Act of the photocopying provisions in 1980. It may well be that educational institutions are still pretty wary of statutory licence provisions of this sort in the light of the difficulties that they were having in bringing into operation the statutory licence for photocopying. I think there is something to be said for moving somewhat more cautiously.

The Opposition's amendment, which is on a very much reduced scale, hopefully will make some progress in this direction. The scheme of the Opposition's amendment is that it will apply in the first place only to a television or sound broadcast in which copyright subsists in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation or the Special Broadcasting Service. In those cases where copyright subsists in the ABC or the SBS and something is copied for the purpose of teaching in an educational institution, that will be permitted despite it being a technical breach of copyright. That is clearly set out in the proposed new clause of the Bill, which confines it to:

. . . where the making of the film or recording or the rebroadcast is undertaken by or on behalf of an educational institution and is reasonably required for the teaching purposes of that institution . . .

Of course, it means that this would apply to any television or sound broadcast in which the ABC or SBS has copyright regardless of whether that broadcast was created for educational purposes or was what one might call a strictly educational film in a technical and narrow sense. However, it is clear that, largely because there are such specially created ABC and SBS educational programs, in effect this will have a pretty narrow application. There is a great deal of demand in educational institutions for those sorts of broadcasts, whether visual or sound. They are not always shown at a convenient time for a particular class so it is sensible that they should be able to be taped and then re-used at convenient times.

This proposal does not create for copyright owners the great problems that a statutory licence would create with the need for proper remuneration and the means of recording, assessment and all the rest of it involved in such an ambitious scheme. That is one of the attractions we see for this amendment; it is on a pretty limited scale. It seems to be even more limited than the existing provision for educational broadcasts in section 200 except that that applies only to sound and not to television broadcasts. That provision applies to a broadcast intended to be used for educational purposes. The copying can be done only by an educational institution and the recording is to be used for the instruction of that institution. So we have picked up those two aspects of the existing provision and widened them to include visual copying-in other words, for television-but, of course, it does not apply generally. It applies only to broadcasts in which the ABC or the SBS have copyright. So it does not apply by any means to all broadcasts of the ABC or the SBS, no matter how desirable they may be for educational purposes. We are confining it to the ABC and the SBS because, as I have said, although they no doubt will express an interest in being remunerated for their copyright, they are wholly government sponsored and owned bodies and do not operate commercially. We believe that they will not in any way be as sensitive to or affected by provisions of this kind as they would be by a very simple alternative provision which would simply extend the existing section 200 (2) to include television broadcasting. It is for those reasons that the Opposition has moved this amendment. It is not that we think it would be valuable in itself but we hope that it might set the ball rolling in favour of broader provisions for copying for educational purposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support in principle and in content the amendment just moved by Senator Durack for all the reasons that I put during my speech in the second reading debate. It certainly is appropriate that publicly funded information should be provided readily to publicly funded institutions. Most schools-in particular state schools, but I think it applies across the board-have a very real need to have access to some of the excellent programs that are broadcast by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service, and in particular to videos of the television programs, documentaries and films that are broadcast on those two channels. However, as I also indicated in my speech on the second reading, I am not sure that it is appropriate to proceed with the amendment at this time. I indicated that we would prefer to refer these two amendments to the Standing Committee on Education and the Arts since that Committee seems to be the appropriate committee to which to refer something that applies both to the school system and to ABC and SBS television.
—We look after broadcasting as well as education and arts.

—Certainly. The Chairman of the Committee, to whom I did refer this matter before I mentioned it in this place, informs me that the Committee does also cover broadcasting. In referring this matter to Senator Colston's Committee, I hope it will lead in due course to that Committee seeking a wider term of reference to cover the sorts of issues that Senator Puplick, Senator Durack and I mentioned in our speeches earlier today. The issue of levies on blank tapes, for example, could well be looked at by the Committee as a solution to some of the problems that remain and that the Government has not picked up for inclusion in the Copyright Amendment Bill before us. I indicate our support in principle for what the Opposition is trying to do. However, I say, that there are wider issues that could be picked up and a referral of these amendments to Senator Colston's Standing Committee on Education and the Arts would be the appropriate way to deal with them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes this amendment but would not resist reference of the issue to a Senate committee, as has been proposed by Senator Haines, in order for the matter to be looked at more closely and perhaps to be debated further by the Parliament in the Budget session. Despite the superficial attractions it may appear to have, the reasons we oppose it are, firstly, because it is opposed by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service, for good reasons that I will come to in a moment; secondly, because it is at odds with the acknowledgment we have received from the educational institutions that they are prepared to pay for the property rights that are here involved, just as they have been prepared to pay for copyright use of written material.

SPEECH.PARA: We also oppose it because it is at best only a piecemeal solution, as has been acknowledged by Senator Durack, to the perceived problems of educational institutions. Far from assisting the resolution of the overall problem of educational audio-visual copying, it is likely to make the ultimate solution, which we hope will be in terms of a statutory licensing scheme, more difficult in so far as it just adds one element in the total picture that will subsequently have to be unwound if a more comprehensive regime that deals with all aspects of the problem involving commercial channels as well as the subsidised ones is to be established.

Let me explain in a little more detail why it is that on quite rational grounds the ABC and SBS have strongly opposed this provision. It is best approached by taking the situation, which I acknowledge the amendment does not advocate, of all programs broadcast by the ABC and SBS being subject to this exemption from copyright infringement liability so far as educational institutions are concerned. If it were the case that all programs were thus exempt, the likely immediate result would be that fewer programs would be made available by external suppliers to the ABC and the SBS. Why, for example, would the British Broadcasting Corporation license the ABC to broadcast something which it-the BBC-also wanted to sell in video form? Why would it do that when it knows that the schools can copy the broadcast program with absolute impunity, so there is an immediate loss of a market potential? Alternatively, those programs which suppliers are prepared to make available could be expected to become very much more expensive insofar as copyright owners would want compensation for the lost market; in other words, either they would not supply them at all or they would supply them only on the basis that there was an increased price tag to compensate them for the loss of the video market in question, which would have the same result, of course, in practice, so far as the ABC or the SBS were concerned, with regard to their capacity to provide a diversity of programs.

I acknowledge that the amendment is not cast in those terms. But it is helpful as a lead-in, I think, to understanding the next layer of the problem, which is that the amendment does not seem to rule out-it is a matter for interpretation as to what it does mean-programs which are made by the ABC or the SBS but which employ, in the making of the program, material which is itself copyright, such as film clips, musical recordings and script material. The price of those components of the program, which are themselves subject to copyright retention to someone else, could, for exactly the same reasons, using the same logic as that which I have endeavoured to describe earlier, be expected to increase. The owners of the copyright in the component materials would know that they would be subject to compulsory copyright; that is, they would have no right to say no to the use of the material and they would have no right to recoup royalties in relation to it. So in an indirect way one would have evident much of that very same phenomenon which is more obviously perceivable with regard to programs as a whole acquired from outside sources. The associated problem is that some scriptwriters-and perhaps music composers, although the most obvious problem is likely to concern scriptwriters-could refuse to write for the ABC or the SBS, given that they are forced in effect, in writing for those particular outlets, to give away their reproduction right. Again, one could have the denial of supply as well as the making of the components more expensive.

To the extent that what the amendment is dealing with is direct production material which does not have copyright component problems of that kind but is just a program which is wholly copyrighted in the ABC-that is, it employs wholly internal resources in respect of which the organisation retains the copyright-that is still not the end of the problem, even if the amendment is narrowly construed in those terms. A further financial problem is involved, because the ABC and the SBS would immediately lose, if this amendment were in force, any post-broadcast educational sale market for their programs and would not be able to recoup any of their production costs through those sales. That is a significant source of financial return, particularly in regard to the ABC. The ABC has a very thriving and substantial marketing arm which it is trying hard to increase, not least because of the budgetary pressures that have been placed upon it by the Government. Given that so much of that marketing is directed to educational institutions, it would be cut to pieces.

For that combination of reasons, which I and the Government believe are good reasons, there is very great resistance to what, on the face of it, is an entirely well intentioned and perhaps even thoughtful proposal in this amendment. The Government believes that the statutory licence route is the one which we should follow. It is disappointing that progress on this matter has not been faster. Certainly, it is something that I was anxious to try to kick into life a couple of years ago. But there are enormous difficulties-

TALK.START.PARA: —It was alive when you became responsible for it.

—We did our best, Senator. There was not much that survived the honourable senator's dead hand in the administration of the portfolio. This was one thing, at least, that has continued to be looked at. Copyright seems to bring out the worst instincts in most of those people who deal with it. There is the anxiety to dot every `i' and cross every `t' before anything gets into the statute book. Infinitely complex procedures are then devised, and a lot of sound and fury, but not much action. I acknowledge all of those things. I simply say that it is important to try to generate some momentum on this issue. While the Government thinks that if it is referred to a Senate committee, for the sort of reasons I have indicated the committee is likely to come down solidly against this measure, nonetheless at least that forum will enable some of these issues to be canvassed and thought through, and perhaps that exercise will serve to give some necessary momentum to all the various interests that must come together for us to get a sensible statutory licensing scheme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to support Senator Durack's amendment, although I understand from what Senator Haines and Senator Gareth Evans have said that the effect of this amendment will be for the matter to be referred to a Senate committee for investigation. I am also grateful for the indication from Senator Colston that his Committee is prepared to look at this matter. I hope that if that is the decision of this place, it will also enable the Standing Committee on Education and the Arts to explore some of the wider issues involved in audio-visual copyright problems as they affect educational institutions. It seems to me that they are in a very special position. The whole purpose, one suspects, of the video industry has been to encourage the practice called time shifting; that is, essentially to allow people to see programs at a time which is of maximum convenience to them. We certainly know that most of the programs that we would be concerned about in this amendment are programs which will be shown outside of school hours. The Australian Broadcasting Corporation in recent years has been very diligent in developing programs, particularly science programs, which are extraordinarily valuable as educational tools but which clearly are not broadcast at a time of day which would be convenient for educational institutions.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to comment very briefly on a couple of points that arise from what Senator Gareth Evans said. I refer first to the preparedness of educational institutions to pay. That is all very well until one starts to define the method by which payment will be made or the rate at which payment will be made. Anybody who is familiar with the exercise which was involved between the ABC and the Australasian Performing Right Association will know that that was a matter of enormous dispute in terms of what the ABC was prepared to pay and what APRA was prepared to receive. By the time that had gone backwards and forwards, and eventually came before the Tribunal for judicial determination, the ABC had to appear before a Senate Estimates committee a few weeks ago to seek funds in excess of a million dollars to pay for the back payments of royalties which were awarded by the Tribunal as far as payments to APRA were concerned. While I am sure that educational institutions are happy to pay on the basis that they think a small amount will be involved and the process will be simple, I suspect that when they get to the nitty-gritty of the matter, they will find their willingness to pay diminishes both with time and in regard to exponential cost.

The statutory licensing scheme, which is clearly the Government's preferred option, nevertheless could be assisted by the sort of committee investigation which it appears this reference may well stimulate. Although Senator Gareth Evans characterised the problems that would arise if all programs broadcast on the ABC and the Special Broadcasting Service were subject to this amendment, that is not the intention of the amendment. He acknowledged that point. Our proposed clause 112a (1) states:

This section applies to a television broadcast and a sound broadcast in which copyright subsists in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation or in the Special Broadcasting Service or in both of those bodies jointly.

It therefore limits it to that extent. I appreciate the point Senator Evans made about the attempt of the ABC to increase its marketing arm and revenue. In this instance I believe that it amounts to a Government transfer from revenue gained by the ABC to a subsidy, as it were, of the educational system. Therefore, in terms of net cost to revenue, one suspects that one is looking either at the ABC forgoing revenue and receiving less and the schools not having to outlay as much in order to pay the ABC or at the ABC retaining the copyright, the schools having to pay the ABC and the schools having to come to the Government for increased funds in order to meet their financial commitments. I think it really is a bit of a merry-go-round within the Government's financial arrangements, which means that at some stage in fact we will be dealing with a purchase by one government-funded organisation from another government-funded organisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I'd back the schools ahead of the ABC in getting the dole.

—We had an earlier debate about relative merits of Ministers for Communications and other Ministers. I do not think I want to re-enter that particular debate. It is certainly true that the component issue is an important one. It is also true that people who actually produce educational material for broadcasting have expressed a degree of concern about the matter. Nevertheless, I believe that, even if the amendment moved by Senator Durack is not to succeed at this stage, it will have served an extremely valuable purpose in raising the issue and in providing the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts with a matter for it to look at-I understand, hopefully by the end of August or some time-table of that sort-and also will allow the Education and the Arts Committee and, through it, the Senate to obtain some further information about the problems of audio-visual copyright as they appertain to educational institutions and educational broadcasting. To that extent I think that the Opposition will be well pleased to have got the matter further advanced. Nevertheless, I believe that the more useful way to have proceeded would have been to have supported the amendment and to have dealt with the arising problems at a later stage. Nevertheless, I think that we understand what is likely to happen to the amendment. I hope that, if it is referred to the Education and the Arts Committee, that Committee will be able to produce something which will be of guidance and assistance to the Senate in future debates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say two things. Firstly, I am happy for the matter to be referred, for report, to the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts. Secondly, however, I hope that that Committee in considering this matter will not simply confine itself to this particular proposed amendment. I have conceded all along that it is a rather narrow solution to the problem and that obviously it would be desirable if a wider scheme could be agreed on, bearing in mind the concerns of so many educational institutions about the costs to be incurred by them with any form of statutory licensing arrangement, as they are still digesting the photocopying scheme which was imposed on them by this Parliament in 1980.

SPEECH.PARA: I wonder whether the point made by Senator Evans about the problems the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service would have might be due in part to the fact that this particular proposal is not confined simply to broadcasts of material strictly for educational purposes, which, of course, is the way in which the exemption in section 202 (2) of the Act is confined, and whether the objections made by the ABC would apply also to sound broadcasts or television broadcasts of any particular dramatic material which it may have created for ordinary commercial viewing. I would be interested to know whether the ABC would be more amenable if the particular exception were confined to material which was in fact created purely for educational purposes. Nevertheless, it is clear that there is a wider demand by educational institutions for material which might be broadcast on commercial stations and for which institutions or people other than the commercial stations or the ABC themselves have copyright.

That then very clearly and directly raises the problem of payment. I agree that in the end the desirable solution is some form of statutory licence scheme. I think that, even within the ambit of a statutory licence scheme, it would perhaps be in the interests of educational bodies, in respect of educational material created solely for that purpose-at least in the case of the ABC and the SBS-that such material be made available without fee, or at least a very moderate fee indeed. That seems to be a completely different case from that applying under some statutory licence in regard to unlimited copying of quite general material which may be thought to be useful-no doubt, would be very useful-for educational purposes, but which in itself is not strictly an educational film. I would like the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) to respond to that point before we complete this matter. I will not press the amendment in light of the undertakings that have been given by Senator Haines to move for reference of the matter to a committee, which I understand cannot be done at this stage but will be done later in the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation would still be opposed to the proposal on the narrower basis but would be less strenuously opposed because of its significantly narrower scope in the way in which Senator Durack has expressed it, in other words, as broadcasts specifically put together for educational purposes. I do not think we ought to try to make a judgment on the merits of that argument here and now. I think that is a matter which ought to be considered along with others in the committee exercise. I respond to Senator Durack's first point by saying that, while I think that the terms of this amendment ought to be the primary subject of the reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, I see no difficulty, from the Government's point of view, in expressing the reference as being `and matters incidental thereto' or `matters arising out of the issues raised by the amendment' or words to that effect. I think that the idea was not to place too great a burden on the Senate committee by having it wrestle with the whole of the complex problem but to have it focus specifically on the narrow issues raised by the amendment, with the capacity to do anything that it wanted to do in regard to matters associated with that.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Proposed new clause 13b.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a second amendment which will insert an additional clause in the Copyright Amendment Bill. I had suggested that it would be clause 13b on the assumption that the previous amendment would be passed. The amendment will improve the armoury against video piracy with which the Bill is primarily concerned. We have already debated and supported that matter. The Bill will increase penalties, facilitate proof and so on. One of the modern proposals to combat crime which has been given effect in some Federal legislation is to be able to strip the successful criminal of the profits of crime. The existing section 115 of the Copyright Act which enables damages or an account of profits to be obtained assumes that the person who has been guilty of the infringement has retained those profits or has the capacity to pay damages. As I said, that is a fairly old-fashioned approach to such matters. For argument's sake, such a person could simply be a straw company and thus not able to meet the payment of damages, or if there has been an account of profits, they may have been divested.

SPEECH.PARA: Our proposal is that inserted into these remedies should be a provision to enable the pursuit of a person who has received the proceeds and may hold them on a constructive trust. This matter has been discussed recently by the High Court of Australia in a well-known case Hospital Products Ltd v. US Surgical Co-op. The suggestion was made, at least by Mr Justice Deane in that case, that this would be a suitable remedy. This certainly is an old remedy, long known to the law but not used to any extent in the commercial arena. It is the way we must proceed. In the Customs Act the notion has been introduced of stripping those who have been engaged in drug trafficking of property acquired as a result of their nefarious activities. We make the suggestion that that precedent could be used for the profits obtained by video pirates. I move:
(2) Page 9, after new clause 13a, insert the following new clause:

`13b. Section 115 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting from sub-section (2) ``and either damages or an account of profits'' and substituting ``and damages, an account of profits or a constructive trust, or any combination of them, as the court thinks fit''.'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Government does not believe that this amendment is necessary. We would be prepared to consider something along these lines later if it proved necessary. The civil sanctions in the legislation are already very wide. On the Government's view, they are adequate to cover even the serious problem of getting at the assets of large-scale pirates-which is clearly the preoccupation of Senator Durack. Let us look, for example, at section 115 (4) of the Copyright Act which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Where, in an action under this section-
(a) an infringement of copyright is established; and
(b) the court is satisfied that it is proper to do so, having regard to-
(i) the flagrancy of the infringement;
(ii) any benefit shown to have accrued to the defendant by reason of the infringement; and
(iii) all other relevant matters,
the court may, in assessing damages for the infringement, award such additional damages as it considers appropriate in the circumstances.

That gives an open-ended capacity to apply penal damages in the circumstances there outlined. In addition, there is the capacity to award damages for conversion by virtue of section 116 of the existing Act. The account of profits is already in the legislation in section 115 (2). It would not appear to be necessary that that be specifically mentioned again in the way here provided for. Whether reference to a constructive trust adds anything substantial other than as a supplementary enforcement mechanism, I am not sure, but by and large it would appear that the where- withall is there to inflict the kind of genuine pain on infringers that it is everyone's desire should be the case on the civil side. There does not seem to be any argument on the criminal side that the capacity is there. The argument is only that civil sanctions need beefing up. The Government does not think that that is the case.

The Copyright Law Review Committee is examining the importation provisions of the Act which enable civil actions for breach of copyright to be brought against a person importing material into Australia without licence of the copyright owner. That subject was mentioned by a couple of speakers in the second reading debate. That area may need a bit more attention in the future. If so, the Government unquestionably will give it. Without there being an opportunity for the kind of sensible consultation and consideration that is desirably involved in these legislative exercises we do not think that any compelling need has been shown for a clause of this kind. We suggest that accordingly it be rejected.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has put this amendment forward in a constructive way. I appreciate the difficulties of actually passing the amendment in the present atmosphere when the House of Representatives is not sitting; perhaps the Government does not have enough time in the circumstances to fully process it. However, I do not think that the answer given by Senator Gareth Evans is adequate. There may be better ways of achieving the result. Perhaps the amendment could be drafted in a more detailed way but the existing provisions of the Act, in the opinion of the Opposition, do not satisfactorily enable the recovery of ill-gotten, ill-gained profits of commercial piracy particularly in the instance which I gave where the profits had been passed on to somebody else who could well and properly be regarded as holding them on a constructive trust. It may be difficult to establish that under existing law. It needs some legislative assistance. I would be satisfied if the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) indicated that the Government will look at this matter further and if, on reflection, it considers that the idea is worthwhile it will either give it to the Copyright Review Tribunal if required or it will bring forward amendments of its own.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no difficulty in giving that assurance. This matter has not been raised by the industry, but we will have another look at it and, particularly if the industry takes the view that it ought to be further pursued, we will be happy to do that.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to go back to the matter which I was about to raise at the beginning of the Committee stage debate. This is not an amendment which the Opposition has prepared or which we want to move but I want to raise the matter because it is of very great concern to the Australian Copyright Council. It concerns the problem that arises with the growing use of satellites and the extent to which the operation of satellites fits into the concept of broadcasting within the Copyright Act. It may well be that the use of satellites for broadcasting-we all know that this is growing-will defeat the provisions of the Copyright Act. Copyright owners will be unable to adequately recover their remuneration if the material in which they have copyright is broadcast in this way. I think the particular concern arises under clause 5 which inserts an additional sub-section to section 22 of the Act. The sub-section reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Where a television broadcast or sound broadcast made by a person from a satellite, wherever located, consists of material transmitted from the earth to the satellite . . . the broadcast shall . . . be deemed to have been made by the person at the time when, and from the place from which, the material was so transmitted from the earth.

The concern of the Copyright Council, as I understand it, is that if this broadcast is being transmitted from Australia to the satellite and back to Australia there is, as the Government has indicated, a problem as to whether or not copyright would apply because the broadcast must be from Australia and the satellite would not be part of Australia. On the other hand, as this section applies, it would mean that if there was a broadcast from outside Australia, that broadcast would be deemed to have been made from a country outside Australia. In the absence of any similar reciprocal legislation with other countries there may be a problem of the Australian copyright owner being able to obtain remuneration from that person in another country. I understand that to be the worry of the Copyright Council.

Despite the fact that the Minister has said that he has widely consulted with the industry, I understand that the Copyright Council apparently had not had this legislation very long after it was introduced and before it was passed in the House of Representatives. That is why it has taken the matter up with the Opposition in the Senate. I presume it has taken the matter up with the Government as well. I would like to have some explanation from the Government as to how it intends this particular provision in clause 5 to operate. It is related to other definitions of broadcast contained in clause 3. I would like the Minister to deal with the particular concern of the Copyright Council. If the Government does believe there is some ambiguity in this matter and that the rights of Australians and copyright owners in Australia would be affected by this provision, the Opposition would seek to have an assurance from the Government that it will in fact try to reach some agreement with the Copyright Council so that its concerns can be met-if necessary even by a subsequent amendment to this Act. These particular provisions do not need to come into force immediately. The purpose of this Act is to deal with piracy. The clauses dealing with that matter are quite separate and could be proclaimed without this particular area being proclaimed. It can await further consideration by the Government if that is really necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The question in issue here is a technical one as to whether what is a universally agreed intention has been successfully translated into legislative language. The general agreement is, as Senator Durack says, that the Copyright Act not apply to what are described as a point to point transmissions; that is to say, those not intended by the transmitting person to be received by the public, but just rather a direct point to point transmission. That is the intention. But in translating that some questions have arisen, in particular so far as satellite broadcasts are concerned, the particular concern being that unintentionally some forms of satellite transmission may be construed as point to point in character or in some other way excluded from the protections given by the Copyright Act, which is not something any of us would want to see.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not stop now to try to wend my way through the arguments about the particular language that is involved. I think it is enough to say that one of the points of concern by the Copyright Council is acknowledged by the Attorney-General's Department to have some possible substance. The other point is thought, at this stage anyway, not to have substance and not to be likely to give rise to any problems at all with interpretation. But to the extent that there is anything which might give rise to these problems, it is clearly an area that ought to be looked at further before these provisions are proclaimed into effect.

I am happy, on behalf of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) and the Government, to give that undertaking that these particular provisions will not be proclaimed into effect, unlike the piracy provisions which it is desired universally be proclaimed as soon as possible. The broadcasting provisions, including the matters presently in issue, will not be proclaimed into effect for some months. It was the intention anyway that regulations be drafted before that occurred which will enable us to look very carefully at the drafting points that are involved and to make any necessary corrections in the Budget session, the vehicle for that being most likely to be, I suppose, the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill, if indeed we are not ready to go by then with a full scale audio-visual statutory licensing scheme. So one way and another the points will be addressed. I thank Senator Durack for raising them. That is the Government's response.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill on motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON EDUCATION AND THE ARTS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendment relating to the use of certain broadcasts by educational institutions, moved by Senator Durack to the Copyright Amendment Bill 1986 on 11 June 1986, be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, and that the Committee report on the amendment and any other related issue arising out of its deliberations on or before 28 August 1986.

I do not think I need to add anything more to the debate on this issue than was put forward both during the Committee stage and during the second reading debate, except to reiterate and to acknowledge the comments made by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) during the Committee stage that moving this amendment to the Committee does give some scope for wider terms of reference to be picked up by the Committee should it see fit. If necessary, any application for an extension of the time limit I would have thought would have been regarded sympathetically by the Committee if the other related issues to this amendment that come out of the Committee's deliberations prove to be interesting rabbits to chase down an assortment of holes.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE FOR THE SCRUTINY OF BILLS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the tenth report of 1986 of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills concerning the Bounties Bill 1986, the Copyright Amendment Bill 1986, the Departure Tax Collection Amendment Bill 1986, the Hazardous Goods Bill 1986, the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Research and Development) Bill 1986 and the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Bill 1986. I also lay on the table the Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 11 dated 11 June 1986.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the 253rd report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, entitled `Proposed Computer Acquisition by the Australian Audit Office'.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The 253rd report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts is the first to be tabled by the Committee under the terms of its standing reference to investigate and report on proposed acquisitions of automatic data processing facilities by Commonwealth departments or authorities staffed under the Public Service Act 1922. The Committee received this proposal in January 1986 when Senator Walsh, the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters, advised the Committee that the Government had given in principle approval for the Australian Audit Office to acquire computing and communications facilities, conditional on the proposal being reviewed by the Public Accounts Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Audit Office's computer acquisition proposal involves three levels of data processing: first, a central computing facility and associated software. The Audit Office suggests that the central computer be an IBM compatible computer, equivalent to an IBM 4381. Secondly, a network to provide processing capacity, office automation and printing facilities for each State and to provide access to the central applications. Thirdly, a micro-computer facility to provide further office automation and other tools to Audit staff. This proposal was estimated to involve additional expenditure over the period 1986-87 to 1989-90 of $13m, including $6m of capital equipment.

The expected benefits of the proposed computer system are in the nature of improved management information and decisions, better priority determination for audits and, most importantly, an improvement in the quality of audits. The Australian Audit Office has argued that the benefits to the public sector generally in terms of the greater administrative efficiency which would result from the Office's increased productive capacity are real but immeasurable.

The Committee supported the basic motivation of the Audit Office's proposed computer acquisition. If the Audit Office is to be able to conduct rigorous analyses of the performance of other departments and agencies, it must have modern management and auditing tools at its disposal. The Committee was concerned that the Audit Office currently appears to be poorly equipped, at least in terms of the information technology and related expertise at its disposal, to undertake audits in some of the large and technologically sophisticated departments and agencies of the Commonwealth.

The Committee has reached the following specific conclusions: There is some doubt whether the level of additional staff support which is to be provided for this project is sufficient to secure its successful implementation; the level of absorption of the staff resources proposed for this project must be considered a measure of the Auditor-General's and his organisation's commitment to cost containment in the successful implementation of this project; and the Australian Audit Office has not made an adequate effort to define and quantify the benefits resulting from the proposed ADP acquisition and the information systems it will support. The Committee also considered that it was doubtful whether co-ordinating departments and agencies, including the Department of Finance and the Public Service Board, had seriously challenged or attempted to verify the benefits asserted for the Australian Audit Office's proposed ADP acquisition.

The Committee examined the Australian Audit Office's case for restricting tenders for its mainframe computer facility to computers compatible with IBM software and has concluded that the technical benefits to the Australian Audit Office in specifying that its mainframe must be IBM compatible are not persuasive; but there are non-technical advantages in acquiring an IBM compatible mainframe facility which would be of strategic benefit to the development of the Office's ADP capability. The main benefit appears to be the experience that its staff will acquire in the IBM compatible environment common to approximately two-thirds of its major auditees.

In addition to these and other specific conclusions, the inquiry has raised some other concerns about computer acquisitions generally. These concerns related to the apparent difficulties of some departments in identifying and presenting a comprehensive and comprehensible statement of all costs associated with their proposals; the apparent reluctance of some departments to define and quantify the benefits which will result from the acquisition of ADP facilities; and the absence of satisfactory provisions in these proposals for the performance monitoring systems and output indicators necessary to demonstrate subsequently that these benefits are achieved.

The Committee also recommended that the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services expedite its current review of the `Guidelines for ADP Acquisition' with a commitment to issue a revised set of guidelines by the end of 1986; and that all departments and other organisations with an interest submit their comments and recommendations on the contents and operation of the guidelines to the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services and to this Committee as soon as possible.

In brief, the conclusions of this report reinforced the need for greater scrutiny of ADP acquisition proposals by both senior management of the acquiring department and by co-ordinating departments involved in the approval and acquisition process. The Committee's findings also emphasise the responsibilities of heads of organisations and of the Department of Finance to ensure that the performance and benefits of these ADP facilities are monitored and periodically reviewed. I commend the report to honourable senators.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EDUCATION AND THE ARTS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts on the Government's response to the fourth report on the examination of annual reports by the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 May 1986, the Government's response to the fourth report of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts on its examination of annual reports was tabled in the Senate. The Committee's report dealt with the 1983-84 annual report of the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority. It focused particularly on the assessment procedures used in secondary colleges in the Australian Capital Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: In the report, the Committee made some suggestions about possible refinements to the methods of continuous assessment currently used in the Australian Capital Territory. The Committee also suggested that the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority should review the possibility of using external examinations as part of its assessment procedures in future. The Government rejected the latter suggestion. In an overview of its lengthy technical response, the Government stated that it:

. . . shares the Committee's concern for the maintenance of standards and the credibility of the system; however, its views on the most appropriate methods for achieving these ends differ from those of the Committee.

On 8 May, I made some preliminary observations about the response. I indicated then that after I had studied the response in more depth, I might wish to add to those observations. The Committee has now had the opportunity to study the response and has decided that a reply is warranted. What I shall say today has been endorsed by the Committee.

The Government's response is in seven sections. The first brief section deals with the Committee's comments about the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority annual report for 1983-84. There are a further five sections on assessment procedures and an overview, which summarises these sections. There are some general observations which can be made about the Government's response. The response is a more thorough and sophisticated defence of the current system of assessment than was made in evidence given by the Schools Authority during the Committee's inquiry. It is a great pity that the Authority was not as forthcoming when the Committee was taking evidence. It almost appears that the Authority kept its powder dry during the inquiry so that it could fire a broadside at the final report.

I am not sure whether I should describe the tone of the response as defensive or aggressive. In my preliminary observations, I said that the main thrust of the response appeared to be the denigration of external examinations, and further study has confirmed that observation. In this respect, the response was a defensive document, but it was written in an aggressive style. The response is also selective. It addresses some of the observations made in the Committee's report, but not others. The response does not mention the `learn and forget' attributes of continuous assessment. It does not address the Committee's concerns about the possible deleterious effects of continuous assessment on relationships between students and teachers and between students. It does acknowledge that a system of external examinations may identify poor teachers, but it concludes:
If teaching standards should be monitored, then measures more valid and reliable than external examinations could be devised.
This may be true, but this conclusion is remarkable. It seems to indicate that the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority pays scant regard to teaching standards.

In relation to the Committee's comments about the effects of continuous assessment on standards of learning, the Schools Authority chose to draw attention to the statistical methodology used in one of the tables the Committee produced for its report. Table 3.2 provided data which attempts to demonstrate whether students in the Australian Capital Territory undertake significant studies in the major subjects of English, mathematics and the physical sciences. The Committee's interest in this area was sparked by the Schools Authority's claim that almost 100 per cent of students in Australian Capital Territory secondary colleges study English; 98 per cent study mathematics and 81 per cent study science. The figures supplied by the Authority purported to show that the Australian Capital Territory system encourages more studies in these basic subjects than the higher school certificate systems in the two major States. The Authority compared its enrolment figures with figures available for students in Victoria and New South Wales who completed courses in English, mathematics and science in years 11 and 12. These figures were not comparable with the enrolment figures supplied by the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority. This spurious use of statistics attracted the Committee's attention. Because directly comparable figures between systems are not available, the Committee used data from two different tables contained in the Australian Capital Territory's year 12 report. It was aware that the figures in the tables were not strictly comparable. Nevertheless, the Committee considers that, despite this technical shortcoming, the figures produced in its report give a more accurate impression of the effects of the current assessment procedures on learning than the figures quoted by the Schools Authority.

As indicated earlier, the Authority defended the present continuous assessment system, mainly by attacking external examinations. In effect, it set up a straw man to knock down. For example, referring to the external examination, the response quoted the Campbell report on external examinations as follows:
In its traditional form it is neither effective, nor reliable, nor predictive.

The Committee's investigations of the current continuous assessment procedures indicate that they may be even less effective, reliable and predictive than the system they replaced. I should also comment that, in my preliminary observations about the response, I indicated that the Committee was not necessarily advocating a return to external examinations as they were in the early 1970s. Let me put it this way: If it became necessary to return to steam engines to power motor vehicles, I expect we could do better now than to use the Stanley Steamer. Modern technology would allow us to build a much more efficient model. Similarly, I expect that we would be able to improve on the old form of external examinations.

Despite the many shortcomings of the response, the Committee has observed that it includes brief comment on reference examinations for tertiary selection procedures. It also indicates that some form of external oversight of assessment instruments used within the colleges might be possible. I suppose the Committee should be grateful that the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority has given some attention, however slight, to the concerns raised in the report. The Committee affirms its recommendation that the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority should give consideration to including an element of external assessment in its assessment procedures for secondary colleges. Given the myopic attitude adopted by the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority, both in its evidence and in the Government's response, however, the Committee does not intend to pursue the matter further at this time. In making its report to the Senate, the Committee has fulfilled its primary responsibility.

I cannot leave this issue without saying that the Committee is concerned about certain remarks made by the Chairman of the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority, Dr Anderson. Here I do not refer to Dr Anderson's comment that Australian Capital Territory employers who do not understand the present assessment procedures are lazy. I am sure that the people of the Australian Capital Territory will be able to make their own judgments on that, and on the level of professional competence exhibited by people who make such allegations. The Committee takes issue with some other statements. Dr Anderson was quoted in the Canberra Times of 9 May 1986 as saying that the Committee's report was deficient because it had recommended external examinations but had not considered their shortcomings. If Dr Anderson has been quoted correctly, this comment shows that he had not read the report. More alarmingly, from the Australian Capital Territory community's viewpoint, it shows that he had not even read the response prepared by his own Schools Authority. Referring to external examinations, the response clearly states:
Some problems were expressed by the Committee, but the Report did not provide any data for assessing the magnitude of these problems.

Dr Anderson went on to say that it would have been difficult for the Senate Committee, given its limited resources, to come out with a balanced response. A balanced response would no doubt be one agreeing with Dr Anderson's views.

The Chairman of the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority also accused the Committee of not doing its homework. That accusation is flatly rejected. The Committee relied heavily on the evidence presented to it during its inquiry. It is highly likely, in view of the evidence presented to this Committee, that Dr Anderson did not do his homework. He obviously does not understand or accept the depth of feeling on this issue throughout the community; nor does he acknowledge that people who have opposing views to his may be right.
