DEBATE.TITLE: ADDRESS TO THE NATION ON THE ECONOMIC SITUATION AND SUPPORTING STATEMENT

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Text of Statement by Prime Minister

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the Address to the Nation on the Economic Situation and Supporting Statement delivered by the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and seek leave to incorporate them in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The address and statement read as follows-
Good evening,
As a nation we now have to do some tough and challenging things together, I want to tell you-
why we must do them,
what some of those things are,
why we will overcome the challenge facing us as a nation.
Let me first put the position as concisely as possible:
Our exports of commodities such as wool, wheat, coal and iron ore have, for a long time, been a major source of out national income.
While the prices we pay for our imports have continued to rise, the prices we get for these exports have for a considerable period been gradually, and now dramatically, declining.
This most recent turnaround in the terms of trade has slashed three per cent off our capacity to maintain existing living standards.
The plight of the farmers and other exporters is not something for them alone to bear-it must mean restraint for all of us.
The reality is that the outside world is paying us less-our standards must adjust accordingly.
As a consequence;
we have, for the time being, to accept reduced standards of living and, permanently, increased standards of effort,
we have, in the past three years, shown that we could, by working together, meet and overcome the economic crisis that confronted our country. A different crisis-the same people-we can do it again.
I now go to more detail.
What is Required
We must obtain a lower wage outcome than anticipated when the Accord was renegotiated last September.
The delay in the present case will, to some extent, produce this result.
More is required.
The 2.3 per cent which should flow from this case should be the only national wage increase in 1986.
We believe now it will be necessary to argue for a further discount in the following case.
And under the processes of the Accord we will be conveying that position to the ACTU.
In these circumstances we believe that the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission should make a positive finding on the productivity/superannuation case.
It should, however, under its control, prolong the implementation of the decision over a period of some two years.

Other non-wage remuneration-executive salaries, directors' fees and professional incomes-must be correspondingly restrained. I have been given such assurances by the relevant national business and professional organisations. We will be monitoring such compliance and will expect the States to do the same.

The community will rightly expect the business sector to keep price increases to a minimum. We will meet any requests from the Prices Surveillance Authority that improve the effectiveness of its operation.
While we have reduced our inherited inflation rate we must get closer to those of our major trading partners.
The Governments of Australia must themselves exercise more restraint. It's your money that we use for your collective purposes and welfare-and we will all have to set our sights a little lower.
This will mean some tough decisions in the Budget. We have, in the Budget process so far, identified savings of more than $1 billion.
It will mean some tough decisions at the Premiers' Conference later this week.
These decisions will be taken.
The tax cuts we have promised will be delivered as close as possible to September and certainly by 1st December 1986.
In this context, I wish to report on two other decisions we have now taken.

First, while society has a responsibility to the unemployed, this is a two-way process. The time has come, we believe, when this two-way responsibility will best be served by providing as far as possible the opportunity, particularly for the younger recipients of unemployment benefit, to undertake some community work in return for that benefit. I know from my experience with Priority One that this is the overwhelming view of our young people themselves.
Accordingly, we will be seeking, in co-operation with the States, local governments, community organisations and trade unions, to create the framework for progressively achieving this objective.
Second, under successive Governments, including my own, the federal public service has continued, inexorably, to grow in numbers.
While a good public service is essential to the well-being of our society, an increasingly efficient public service does not mean an increasingly large public service.
Among the steps we will take will be a streamlining and rationalisation of some existing functions and agencies.

Because of entrenched practices that have grown up over generations these steps cannot produce overall dramatic, immediate results. But they begin to reverse the trend-and to produce a leaner, more efficient public service.

The measures I mention, and indeed the indications of the broader approach in the detailed Government statement released tonight, are to be seen as part of our recognition that the problems with which we are dealing are more than immediate-they are long term and need long term solutions.
We must strive to broaden and deepen our export and import-competing base.

To this end, there are things the Government, industry and you can do. In the statement there are details of particular new decisions by government calculated to assist industry towards this objective. Australian management, with the co-operation of the workforce, must by increased investment and other initiatives pick up this challenge.
And we, the Australian public, must support Australian industry. We will be launching a campaign urging all Australians to buy Australian products whenever they can.

As Australians we take enormous delight in the achievements of international excellence by our fellow countrymen and women. Just think of Robert de Castella, Joan Sutherland, Ben Lexcen and John Bertrand.

I want us to get the same sense of shared pride when an Australian manufacturing or services firm wins a contract against the best international competition-and let me assure you they can do it, they are doing it.
It requires the same elements as have brought Deek, Joan, Ben and John to the top-
confidence in yourselves, your product and those around you,
readiness to work with great application and dedication,
eagerness to use the best available advice and technology,
preparedness to forgo present satisfaction for greater long term reward,
total commitment.
We have hundreds of potential de Castellas, Sutherlands, Lexcens and Bertrands out there in our manufacturing and service industries-applying the same principles we can get the same results.
Finally, I want to tell you why we can, why we will together meet and overcome this challenge.
In 1983, when I first spoke to you as Prime Minister about the economy, we were in the midst of our most serious economic crisis for 50 years.
Three years later the picture has changed dramatically.
We've had high economic growth, record employment growth-almost 700,000 jobs, profits are up, industrial disputes are down.
The challenge now confronting us is no less daunting then the one we faced successfully together in 1983.

We have the same elements for success-great resources, a Government prepared to make the hard decisions and a great people with guts and a preparedness by all sectors to pull together to make present sacrifices for future, substantial and sustainable rewards.
I give you my pledge-my Government, your Government-will again make the decisions necessary to meet this challenge.
I will not shirk the hard decisions that are necessary to ensure a bright future for us and for our children.
I would rather risk electoral defeat than take the soft options now that would mean we mortgage that great future.
My faith in you to take up this challenge is undiminished-it is unqualified.
Together Australia-Australians together-will meet and overcome the challenge before us.
Supporting Statement

My Address to the Nation sets out the responses needed from all sections of the community to the new economic situation we are in. This statement provides further elaboration of the problem and further details of Government decisions.

Our terms of trade-that is, the relationship between changes in the prices of our exports and our imports-has tended to decline at an average rate of up to 1 per cent per annum. For a long period, the economy has accommodated this without exceptional stress, assisted by transient factors such as the ``resources boom'' in the early 1980's, which allowed governments to avoid facing up to the need for structural change.

However, as Chart A in Attachment 1 illustrates, recent developments in our terms of trade have been dramatically adverse. Since the December quarter 1984 they have fallen by almost 14 per cent, with more than two-thirds of that fall coming since the June quarter last year. And there are few signs of an early reversal.

In the immediate sense, this is a development completely outside the control of the Government or the community generally. International prices for the things we export have fallen, in some cases catastrophically. Despite the large depreciation of the Australian dollar, which in more normal circumstances would have the effect of raising returns to our exporters, prices for many of our exports in domestic currency terms have risen little if at all. In some cases, such as alumina, domestic returns have fallen. Chart A and Table 1 in Attachment 1 provide further details.

One consequence is that, even though the volume of imports grew by only 1 per cent over the last year, while export volumes grew by 14 per cent (see Chart F), the improvement in the current account deficit has been much slower in coming than first expected.

In a nutshell, the economy has moved decidedly into a position where it is living beyond its means and is increasing its reliance on overseas savings to finance current living standards. Such a situation is not sustainable.

In this situation, it becomes necessary to export a significantly greater volume of goods and services and to import less. That means that we as a country must consume relatively fewer goods and services ourselves. In other words, our standard of living must, for a time at least, be lower.

I will come shortly to the things we can do to meet this unsatisfactory development over the medium term. In the meantime, the community must accept-in one way or another-lower real incomes. As Chart B shows, the loss over the past year has amounted to 3 per cent of GDP after a prolonged period in which only negligible losses were incurred. Adjustment is made more difficult because the process involves, through a lower exchange rate, an initial inflationary impetus which can threaten domestic price stability.
There are three broad ways in which the Government and the community can respond to our new situation.

The first option would be to do nothing, to allow matters to drift. In practical terms, this involves a recurring sequence of poor balance of payments results and exchange rate declines, leading to inflationary price movements which then feed into wages. This causes increasing damage to our international competitiveness, expectations, investment, growth and, in particular, jobs.
It would also increasingly give rise to diminishing consensus, strains on income shares and further pressure on prices and costs.

The second broad option would be, through a combination of contradictory fiscal and monetary policy, to slow economic activity abruptly so as to lower inflation and reduce imports through stalling economic growth-leading to higher unemployment. This would mark a return to the crude policies of contraction pursued before the Government came to office in 1983.

The Government's preferred option is to address the matter directly through prices and incomes policy, accompanied by complementary restraint in the setting of fiscal policy. This would be clearly within the policy framework we have adopted since coming to office. In conjunction with measures to address the longer term structural issues, it would permit the necessary economic adjustment within Australia on an equitable basis-a basis that preserves output and jobs, and opens the way for further growth in the future. It is an option available only because of our prices and incomes policy based on the centralised wages system.

Before proceeding to elaborate what the Government has in mind, it is necessary to recall briefly the trend of economic events in the middle part of 1985, and the degree of adjustment already achieved.

Maintenance of an artificially high dollar as a crude anti-inflationary weapon markedly eroded competitiveness in the early 1980's. This placed added pressure on the balance of payments, characterised for years by persistently large deficits on goods and services, and growing external debt. (Chart C in Attachment 1 provides further details.) Under the floating exchange rate introduced by the Government, however, a major correction in the form of substantial depreciation took place in early 1985.

In successive steps the dollar depreciated sharply, losing in all around 30 per cent of its value against the weighted index of trading partner currencies. This depreciation restored the competitiveness of our traded goods industries to levels of a decade or more earlier. (Chart E in Attachment 1 provides further details.) External adjustment, however, placed pressure on internal economic balance.

Our inflation rate had declined to about 5 per cent by the December quarter of 1984, which was close to the average of our major trading partners. But depreciation unavoidably gave a new impetus to inflation, which, in view also of the strength of economic activity, required firmer macro-economic policy. Monetary policy was tightened in successive stages through 1985 and the Government achieved a substantial degree of expenditure restraint in framing the 1985-86 Budget. In addition, in September 1985 the Government obtained the agreement of the ACTU to support adjustments under the centralised wage fixation system sufficient to neutralise the expected secondary inflationary effects arising from the higher costs of imports in 1985.

This agreement was a flexible response by the union movement to the emerging needs of economic policy. It is fully consistent with the responsible attitude shown by workers over the past three years. In recent years nominal wage increases have remained largely in line with those of our major trading partners. In 1985 Australian average earnings rose by around 6 per cent, against 5 1/2 for our eight major trading partners. This stands in sharp contrast with the very large increases in wages and costs recorded under the confrontationist policy regime of the previous Government when, in 1982, average earnings rose by almost 16 per cent.

The Government considers that a wage fixing system capable of supporting further adjustment to the new economic situation must, in the interests of the community as a whole, provide for predictable and equitable wage movements and must be set on a secure footing acceptable to major industrial parties. It is the firm view of the Government, consistent with its earlier submissions to the current National Wage Case, that it would be appropriate for the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to have regard to such considerations in its deliberations in the current National Wage Case.

For its part, bearing in mind the now long period since there has been any adjustment to nominal wages, the Government is not seeking to re-open the current National Wage Case. It reaffirms the need for discounting of the indexation increase by 2 percentage points, and its support for the principle of a 3 per cent productivity award to fund extensions and improvements to occupational superannuation over time. In particular, the Government considers there are substantial benefits to the community from extending the coverage of occupational superannuation, through including obligations in awards on employers to pay contributions on behalf of their employees into appropriate superannuation funds. As is explained below the timing of this historic step must now be temporarily deferred.
Policy Settings

On the basis of the information available to the Government last August/September-and indeed for much of the intervening period-the adjustments to fiscal monetary and incomes policy were assessed to be appropriate to the economic situation at that time.

However, in the light of the sharp decline in our terms of trade now apparent, the widening of the inflation differential with trading partners and the further 12 per cent depreciation of the exchange rate since the September 1985 agreement with the ACTU, it has now become evident that some additional modification in policy is necessary.
The adjustments must be borne by the community as a whole and must involve employees, business and governments.

In order to achieve a necessarily constrained but eligible budgetary outcome in 1986/87, as discussed later in this document, the Government will have great difficulty in delivering the personal income tax cuts scheduled for 1 September 1986 on time. Nevertheless, the Government will endeavour to introduce the cuts on the scheduled date or as close to that date as is possible, and certainly by 1 December 1986.

The Government now considers it would be more appropriate if the implementation of improvements to occupational superannuation are as limited as possible in 1986. This would apply to all occupational super- annuation schemes that are not in a position to proceed forthwith by agreement with employers in accordance with supervisory principles determined by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.
These principles, in particular, should ensure the orderly and gradual implementation of superannuation arrangements within awards phased in over a two year period.

To assist the Commission, the Treasurer is announcing separately details of supervisory arrangements to apply to occupational superannuation schemes and the timing of the various operational standards. These details will be communicated to the Commission and to parties to the current National Wage Case, together with this Statement.

But there is a need for a further response on the part of wage and salary earners who, collectively, account for much the largest portion of our-for the time being reduced-real national income. There is a brutal choice here-an equitable sharing of the income loss between job holders and the rest of the community, or the loss of jobs by some. The Government's central objective is to achieve an equitable sharing of the burden, in the interests of all who work and seek to work.

While the Government understands that the position of the trade union movement cannot be determined until after the Arbitration Commission has made its decision in the current National Wage Case, it is the Government's view that the current situation-which amounts to a significant change in economic circumstances as referred to in the September 1985 agreement with the ACTU-demands a degree of restraint beyond that envisaged nine months ago.

While the delay in the determination of the present case will help to some extent, more is required. We believe the 2.3 per cent which should flow from this case should be the only national wage increase in 1986. We believe it will now be necessary to argue for a further discount in the following case, the outcome of which should not apply before 1 January 1987.
The Government will, of course, have further discussions with the ACTU on these matters within the framework of the Accord.
A Shared Community Response
To achieve successful economic adjustment, it is essential that the business community also make a significant contribution.

First, there is a need for business to accept a commensurate measure of income discipline. It is the Government's strong view that the restraint exercised by wage and salary earners should also apply to other incomes. The Government notes that such an undertaking would be consistent with the previous support given by the business community at the National Economic Summit.

On this score, initial reactions from the Business Council of Australia, the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Australian Council of Professions have been positive. I will be writing to the heads of major corporations to obtain their personal support for an equivalent degree of restraint on directors' fees and executive remuneration. We will be monitoring developments in this area and will expect States to do the same.
I will be writing in similar terms to the Australian Council of Professions and other professional bodies in respect of fee setting.

Secondly, particularly within the framework of the currency depreciation, business has the responsibility to exploit more fully its entrepreneurial abilities to seek out new export and import replacement opportunities, to take the risks necessary to put in place new investment, to undertake greater research and development and to improve workforce training. The levels of training and research and development by the private sector are low by international standards and there is a clear need to boost efforts in these areas. For its part the Government has given the lead through its commitment to training programs and the 150 per cent tax deduction for expenditure on research and development.
Finally, business has a major role in setting prices which are a crucial factor in future competitiveness.

The Government understands the complexity of price setting as applied to the vast range of products sold in Australia. For that reason it has not and does not favour blanket price controls. In many parts of the economy, competition itself provides an effective discipline on prices. Moreover, in reviewing past trends, it must be recognised that some prices needed to increase to contribute to the essential restoration of profit margins in the recovery period.

But it is now time for business to demonstrate that it is looking keenly at its pricing performance. In 1984 the Government established the Prices Surveillance Authority with a responsibility to promote pricing restraint in business enterprises. The PSA activities are an integral part of the Accord which provides for overall income restraint to assist economic recovery. As well as undertaking surveillance and specific reviews of price changes, the PSA has issued a set of voluntary guidelines to assist business in observing the spirit of restraint. The PSA legislation and guidelines recognise the need for business to allow for maintaining investment and employment in making their pricing decisions. On the other hand the PSA seeks to prevent the exploitation by corporations of substantial market power and to discourage cost increases arising from actions that are inconsistent with the wage fixing principles.

Now is the appropriate time for major business groups to give greater endorsement to the voluntary pricing code developed by the PSA. In my letters to business organisations and major corporations I will urge maximum support for these guidelines.

In addition, in view of commonly expressed public concerns regarding price increases and the need for restraint to receive broad acceptance, the Government will undertake in the context of this total approach the following initiatives:
To enhance the profile and operation of the PSA the Minister Assisting the Treasurer, Mr Chris Hurford, will take special and direct responsibility for prices surveillance matters;

The Government will discuss with the PSA at an early date the establishment of a mechanism for advising complaints to the PSA to assist its work in identifying areas for further activity, including further categories of strategic goods possibly appropriate for PSA surveillance;
The PSA will also be asked to examine ways of improving communication with the public on its pricing guidelines, its surveillance activities and the basis of its pricing recommendations;
The responsibility for surveillance of steel industry prices will be transferred to the PSA from the Steel Industry Authority.
Governments have the responsibility to take the lead in their own affairs in meeting the new challenges posed by the changed economic situation.

In this respect there is a fundamental consideration that I should draw out. We all want to see investment growing. But if we are to reduce our resource to overseas savings by bringing down our net imports of goods and services, we must save more ourselves to fund investment. Government spending is directly relevant here because it is financed in part by drawing on the community's savings. One of the reasons why our external deficit has remained stubbornly wide is because insufficient progress has been made by our governments generally in reducing the collective public sector borrowing requirement.

For its part, my Government has already imposed upon itself the tightest fiscal discipline of any Commonwealth Government in the form of the Trilogy of budgetary commitments. Within that framework, the Government is working to achieve a constrained budgetary outcome for 1986-87 fully consistent with the new economic situation, and an outcome consistent with a further easing of the demands of the public sector on resources and credit. At this stage, savings of more than $1 billion have been identified.

At the same time, the Government will be attaching priority, as it has in past budgets, to sustaining its social welfare policies and to policies for restructuring the economy. It should also be noted that, however firmly outlays are held down, further moderation in wages will tend initially to increase the Budget deficit-especially, through lower PAYE collections.
This is a direct result of reducing inflation, and has to be set against the advantages to the economy of such a reduction.

The necessary degree of fiscal discipline needs to be accepted by all levels of Government-Commonwealth, State and local. The relatively high level of the net PSBR in the 1980's has had an important influence on the increase in the current account deficit. While the Commonwealth has successfully brought down its contribution to the PSBR, decidedly less progress has been made by the States. Chart G in Attachment 1 provides further details.

State and local government spending now represents 51 per cent of total government sector spending and this sector's borrowing requirement is approaching that of the Commonwealth's. At the forthcoming Premiers' Conference it is the intention of the Commonwealth to seek a commitment from the State governments further to restrain their own spending and borrowing requirements.

Let me at this point turn to two important initiatives the Government will pursue. As I said in my Address to the Nation, under successive governments, including my own, the federal public service has continued, inexorably, to grow in numbers. While a good public service is essential to the well-being of our society, an increasingly efficient public service does not mean an increasingly large public service. We will take steps to halt this expansion, to produce a leaner, more efficient service.

There will be a streamlining and rationalisation of some existing functions and agencies. The States will be approached to consider means of rationalising overlapping activities at different levels of government. Because of entrenched practices that have grown up over generations, these steps cannot produce dramatic, immediate results. But they will begin what is necessary to reverse the trend.

The other initiative, to which I personally attach particular importance, concerns the availability of community work to our young people. Despite the improvements we have made to educational opportunity, our developing traineeship scheme, and the large increase in employment growth now achieved, too many young people have so far been unable to find jobs. While society has a responsibility to the unemployed, this is a two-way process. We believe the time has come when this two-way responsibility will best be served by providing as far as possible the opportunity, particularly for the younger recipients of unemployment benefit, to undertake some community work in return for that benefit. I know from my experience with Priority One that this is the overwhelming view of our young people themselves.
Accordingly, we will be seeking, to create the framework for progressively achieving this objective in co-operation with the States, local governments, community organisations, and trade unions.

From the consideration we have been giving to this matter for some time, we well recognise the range of important issues that need to be taken into account in giving effect to this initiative. It is acknowledged that there are many practical difficulties involved, including probably limited community work places compared with the number of younger unemployed and the relatively short periods for which most younger unemployed tend to be without work.
Therefore its detailed elaboration will very much involve appropriate consultations with the groups I have mentioned.

However, the broad aim is to generate community-based work opportunities which can be offered, as they become available, to unemployed benefit recipients through the CES. Certainly no-one otherwise eligible will be prejudiced in his or her receipt of unemployment benefit if a community work opportunity is not readily available for that person.
These work opportunities will be in areas not normally involving paid work and will be additional to existing paid employment activities.
Since positions will be offered on a part-time basis, those participating will still have the capacity to look for paid employment in the open labour market.
I believe that both the community and the unemployed who participate will benefit substantially from this initiative.

The effort to adjust to our changed economic circumstances must engage the whole community. What is needed are changes in the intangible but fundamentally important area of community perceptions and attitudes.
The commitment of government, unions, business and the professions needs to be supported by all of us as Australians.

Looking further ahead, the scope for higher and sustained productivity growth, so basic to our longer term prospects as a nation, will be enhanced by greater emphasis on the development and encouragement of our human resources. Too much in the past we have tended to exploit our non-renewable wealth (particularly in the minerals and energy sectors).
In concrete terms that involves a more positive attitude towards the work of each person day by day-an attitude that must be sustained if we are to continue to prosper.

What we earn and enjoy in our living standards is directly linked to the thought and effort we put into the production of goods and services. Such a change in attitudes can be reflected in greater willingness to innovate, to do away with inefficient and outdated work practices and to show more creativity and enterprise at all levels of industry. The other side of the coin is a willingness to moderate our claims for increased income or entitlements, in order to limit the net claims by the household and public sectors together. In this way we will be able to generate a greater level of savings from domestic sources to provide funds for investing in our future. The development of more adequate and comprehensive superannuation is, of course, relevant to this need.
Longer Term Adjustment

The process of economic adjustment is being greatly facilitated by the depreciation of the Australian dollar. The price changes implied by the depreciation in the $A work to benefit the export and import-competing sectors relative to other sectors; this makes these sectors a more attractive investment prospect than was previously the case. Clearly, to the extent the output of these sectors increases, it will work to reduce the current account deficit. There is clear evidence that the depreciation is working to turnaround export and import volumes, despite an initial (but welcome) increase in the import of investment goods.

As I have indicated, the effort to be undertaken in coming months to re-establish the capacity of the economy to continue to grow and provide job opportunities has also to be seen in a longer term context. These issues are already being addressed by the Government, including a Cabinet Sub-Committee concerned with longer term growth issues.

The now accelerated decline in the terms of trade is a dramatic manifestation of a problem that has been developing for decades. Such long term problems require long term solutions. The economy needs to diversify, on a competitive basis, to supplement traditional export activities. This would allow a wider range of products to compete on export markets, making us less susceptible to adverse world price movements in a few commodities.

Since coming to office the Government has implemented reform of the financial sector, undertaken extensive tax reform and initiated a review of business regulation, all designed to increase the adaptability of the Australian economy over the longer term.

The Government inherited a debilitated and uncompetitive manufacturing sector. Over the last three years it has put in place a range of general programs to improve the international competitiveness of industry. A range of sectoral plans for particular industries has also been implemented to improve the international competitiveness of those industries on the basis of tripartite commitments by Government, unions and employers (see Attachment 2 for details).

Our problems in this sector have been long in the making, and have been aggravated by the absurd combination of an over-valued exchange rate and excessive levels of protection. As in other areas of economic policy there are no simple solutions or quick fixes available.

What is needed is careful and pragmatic assessment of the possibilities relevant to particular industries or particular characteristics of the export and import-replacement sectors. As a general point, it must be added that what will be achievable will also depend on how well we manage the process of shorter term adjustment discussed above.

It is essential that the Australian economy be seen as an interconnected system. In particular, I should refer to the interconnection between our education system and our capacity to produce efficiently. Just as our industry needs to adapt to structural change, so does our education system, something that needs to be more widely accepted by all. As with industry, when my Government came to office it found a run-down education sector. The Government has taken major steps to rectify this-including by long-term guarantees of funding, by additional places in higher educational institutions, through our traineeship programs and by an emphasis on the quality of educational outputs through progressive application of relevant recommendations of the Karmel Committee on the quality of education.

Education is but one illustration of the more general point: improvements in the efficiency in the traded goods and services sector should not be diminished or offset by inadequacies in other sectors of the economy, particularly areas on which the traded goods and services sector relies.

Against that background, a range of additional measures is being introduced, and others are listed for further discussion and possible development, designed to improve further investment in the export-related industries, and to facilitate and encourage exporting and the purchase of quality Australian products. The cost involved in budgetary terms would, deliberately, be small.

Individually, a number of the measures would be limited in overall impact, as they go to particular impediments to exporting in particular areas. But as a package, taken in addition to the policies already in place, they represent a significant further immediate response to our growing need to deal with our medium term structural problems. Further work on these problems will be proceeding within Government in a coordinated fashion and will be announced in coming months.

As an important further element in our approach to resuscitate our most debilitated manufacturing industries, the Government has now finalised measures to assist the heavy engineering industry. In particular, the Government will be providing a limited subsidy on loans to facilitate investment in situations where managements and unions are acting jointly to improve the efficiency of their operations. The Government will seek discussions with business and labour whether this or similar concepts could usefully be extended to manufacturing industries operating in the export sector.
`Buy Australian' Campaign

In remedying the structural weakness in our economy we must not only promote exports of Australian goods. We as Australians must demonstrate our faith in our products wherever we have a choice between local and imported consumer goods. Often Australians do not take the trouble to check whether an item has been made in Australia or abroad. And where the distinction is made, Australians sometimes attach greater prestige to the imported variety, irrespective of whether it is of higher quality.

If Australians were to choose the local product where it was competitive in price and quality they would make a contribution to the development of industry and assist in reducing our overseas deficit. To this end the Government has decided to launch a Buy Australian promotional campaign. The scheme will be a voluntary one whereby Australian manufacturers will be entitled to apply a green and gold logo to their products. The campaign is currently being developed and is expected to commence within the next few months.
Government Purchasing Arrangements

The Government will appoint an independent Committee to review Government purchasing arrangements and practices. It will be required to report to the Government within six months. The Committee will be charged with recommending action to overcome barriers affecting the ability of local industry to compete on an equitable basis with overseas suppliers as well as identifying means of utilising the forward purchasing requirements of Government agencies to identify industrial development opportunities. The review will include consideration of extending the concept of Industrial Supplies Offices, now operating in some States to the National level.
Export Drive

A National Export Drive will be conducted over the next two years. The Drive will aim to increase the practical commitment of both the shopfloor and management to exporting and achieve improvements in export investment, production and marketing.

Export strategies will be developed for each industry with significant export potential. To develop these the Australian Trade Commission (Austrade) will work with business, unions and Government Departments to examine export capability, identify potential export products, survey overseas markets and develop export plans.
Other Measures to Enhance our Export Capabilities
Export Management Education

Secondary and tertiary education can better equip Australian management for export by better addressing the need for export awareness and the development of international marketing skills. Austrade, the Department of Trade and the Trade Development Council will liaise with tertiary and secondary educational institutions, industry organisations and specialist management training bodies to develop possible initiatives in this area including short-term industry specific training courses, exerting an influence on curriculum content in secondary and tertiary institutions, and upgrading export management education provided by the Institute of Export.
New Small Exporters Scheme

A scheme is to be developed whereby new small exporters will be able to obtain from Austrade, free of charge for two years, expert assistance to develop export plans, survey export markets and make contact with potential foreign customers, as well as to participate in trade fairs, trade displays and trade missions.
High Technology Exporters Scheme

This new scheme will provide grants to help firms producing high technology products develop export markets. The grants will be available to firms with new high technology products with potential for export sales. Funds will be available for all aspects of new technology export projects, including market surveys, trade displays and trade missions, and will enable the development of aggressive market development and promotion campaigns.
Insurance

At present, State and Territory stamp duties on the specialised area of marine insurance on merchandise trade can cost up to 25 per cent of premiums. No other country appears to have comparable charges, and traders can largely avoid our charges by insuring overseas-to the extent of about $100 million a year going directly overseas to buy marine insurance cover. We will be approaching the State and Territory Governments with a view to examining the scope to remove the stamp duties payable on international classes of insurance.
Transport and Handling Costs

We must ensure that our exporters are not disadvantaged by inefficiencies and impediments to trade in these areas. The Government has moved to address this issue in part by establishing a Royal Commission into grain handling operations. This inquiry will establish where improvements can be made. More broadly, the Government has in hand a number of other studies on transport handling and related infrastructure costs. These reports cover liner shipping services, international air freight policy, shore based shipping costs and the shipping repair program. We will be examining these studies in an integrated way to determine whether any additional action can be taken to remove impediments to trade.
Pricing of Agricultural Inputs

The marketing of many of our agricultural commodities is conducted under a variety of State and Commonwealth arrangements. We need to ensure that these arrangements are not constraining the development of internationally competitive processing industries.

The Department of Primary Industry will identify those agricultural pricing and marketing arrangements that are impeding the competitiveness of domestic processing, to assist the Government to decide what action may be appropriate, including approaches to the responsible States where the arrangements fall within their jurisdiction.
Export Inspection Services

The Government has had considerable success in streamlining export inspection services to minimise the cost to industry and to the taxpayer. To date these changes have reduced in real terms the cost of inspection and inspection-related activities by some $17 million a year. The process of rationalisation will continue in consultation with industry.
Foreign Investment

Under existing foreign investment review procedures, foreign investment proposals are assessed against national interest and other criteria. These include development of, or access to export markets, technology transfer arrangements, and the presence of export franchise limitations which can impede export potential. While foreign investors do not have to satisfy or meet all the criteria, foreign investors will be given expeditious consideration in instances where proposals, particularly for the manufacturing and services sectors, demonstrate positive trade benefits.

As useful as these specific initiatives will be in addressing particular problems bearing on Australia's trading performance, it is the wages and budgetary policy adjustments which will have the dominant impact on, and do most to improve, the environment for investment and international competitiveness.
Conclusion

The measures which I have announced tonight-both short term and those which further our existing policies to promote longer term structural adjustment-will provide Australia with a firm basis on which to sustain the improvement in our competitiveness which has occurred over the past year and to begin again to pay our way in the world. There are no easy choices in this area. Either we take the hard decisions required-in which case we exercise some control over the kind of future which we have for ourselves and our children-or we just passively accept those adjustments forced on us by external conditions no matter what their consequences. The choice which I have put to you is the one which will maximise our job prospects-both short term and long term. The alternatives are unacceptable to this Government and I believe to the people of Australia.
CANBERRA
11 JUNE 1986

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the Paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has just had incorporated into its Hansard the statement to the people of Australia which is being made on the public media by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). One is not surprised that he is making it to the media and before a television camera and not in the House of Representatives. It is a statement that he would be too embarrassed to make in the presence of his colleagues.

SPEECH.PARA: This statement, coming at a time when the Government has told us that the economy is in a crisis, is a bitter disappointment to the Opposition. It is a clear failure of leadership on the part of the Prime Minister in particular, and the Government in general. We are told that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is at home sick in bed. In that sense, there is a very good parallel between Mr Keating and the economy. I can only say that there is no sign that Mr Hawke shows any ability as a doctor. There is no sign that what Mr Hawke has said today will do anything to bring the Australian economy back to recovery or to assist the people of Australia who face an ailing economy and declining living standards, as was made clear by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) in Senate Question Time only yesterday.

The statement concedes that the effect of three years of Labor rule has been a passage from what the Government describes as a crisis in 1983 to an equally bad crisis here in 1986. The Prime Minister says in the statement:
. . . when I first spoke to you as Prime Minister about the economy, we were in the midst of our most serious economic crisis for 50 years.
That is Mr Hawke's assessment of where we were three years ago, and he now says that three years later:
The challenge now confronting us is no less daunting than the one we faced successfully together in 1983.

The Hawke Government has managed to take us from our worst crisis in 50 years to our worst crisis in 50 years. It is a pathetic demonstration of the ineptitude of this Government and of its failure to face up to its responsibility that it has been prepared to put down this statement as something that warrants delivery to the whole of the Australian people.

There is no action coming from this Government on the fundamental issue of the costs that afflict Australian industry. We have present in this chamber one Labor Senator, Senator Button, who is here because he is responsible, I suppose, for tabling these papers, and he is responsible for Australian industry. He has talked incessantly of the burdens that face Australian industry and there is in this statement no action on the costs that afflict Australian industry. There is no real action on wages. Nothing is being done by the Government to do anything about the wage burden which is part of the problem for Australian industry. There is no real action predicated in this statement-it is talk. The Prime Minister summons up enough courage to say that he might communicate a view to the Australian Council of Trade Unions that at some future wage hearing case there should be discounting. There is no action on the tax problems that afflict Australian industry and investment, no action has been taken to ease the tax burdens which have been imposed, and there is no action on the size and burdens of government.

It is a simple fact that Mr Hawke has blown the opportunity to show leadership, and the big winners in this statement are the trade unions because the attempts that were hinted at by Ministers to do something about the position of the trade union movement have been totally given away in this statement. There is no action of substance at all laid down in it. We can only express the hope that this statement will not be too damaging to Australia. We can only hope that it will not do more damage to our already gloomy prospects-the gloomy prospects that have been described in this place, as they have been described elsewhere, by Mr Keating as leading us towards the status of a banana republic. There is no repair to our situation undertaken by the Government in what it describes in the statement. It is just more of what we have at present, when the Government itself has admitted that that is not good enough.

There are laughable elements in this statement. For example, the Government has suddenly produced the idea that there should be some provision for work for the dole. It is very hard to find in the statement anything definite at all as to what is intended. That is a very preliminary statement. The Government is feeling its way towards a general objective. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) has been talking about this matter for some years, but I would draw his attention and that of the Senate to the fact that in 1982 the Fraser Government announced the very same initiative. We started that initiative in 1982 and early in 1983, and it was discontinued by the present Government. The fact is that we have lost three years in trying to do something about providing work for the dole, in giving dignity to the unemployed. This Government has held off acting for three years. It stopped the Fraser Government's initiative in that area, and now we are starting again. It is a sorry admission on the part of the Government that in 1983 it let its doctrinaire approach to these matters get the better of it.

We are in a situation where the policies that have been pursued by this Government since the election in 1983 contained the seeds of the Government's destruction. We had under this Government the continued stimulus of the government sector through government spending, and we saw no effective attack on the cost structure in Australia. We had the accord locking us in as being steadily more uncompetitive on the international scene. The Government has now achieved the position where we are thoroughly uncompetitive with respect to our inflation rate, to our interest rates and to any other aspects of the economy.

What this Government had going for it was the Fraser Government's wage pause, and it had the stimulus of the Fraser Budget of 1982-a Budget that was right in the world's recessionary conditions of 1982 but which should not have been followed by the stimulatory Budgets of 1983 and 1984. The Government should have done more on wages policy and certainly should have done a lot more to restrain government spending. There is nothing new in the criticism that we make of this Government. It is criticism that we have been making consistently over the last three years, and criticism that is now being borne out in the perilous situation in which the Government and Australian economy find themselves.

This Government is becoming more and more clearly a totally dishonest Government. It adopts a veneer of economic responsibility, but even in the interview which Treasurer Keating gave to the Australian Financial Review a few weeks ago, the interview that blew the lid off the Government's economic policy and indicated that even the Government had to acknowledge the perilous circumstances of Australia, we find even in that honest interview that the Treasurer claimed:
This is our fourth Budget. We have had to cut Government outlays.

Yet the fact is that Government outlays have grown each year under this Government at twice the rate they grew under the Fraser Government. The Treasurer is claiming that this responsible Government, in its fourth Budget, is yet again cutting outlays. In fact, under this Government there has been an increase in real terms of nearly 5 per cent per annum in Government Budget outlays. It is a falsehood to suggest that this Government has been serious in the business of restraining outlays. There is no honest analysis of our problems, no honest attack on them in this statement. There is one honest line, the first line of the statement, which reads:
As a nation we now have to do some tough and challenging things together.

The Opposition would agree with that. It is a time when the Government should be doing some tough and challenging things. Instead, we have this wimpish statement, this statement of no action on the part of the Government, a statement which accepts the status quo, leaves the trade unions in their premier position and leaves the people of Australia floundering as they have been floundering in recent months under this pathetic Government.

In this statement we find a constant blaming of a decline in the terms of trade. That has become the great excuse of this Government for what is wrong-that it has a decline in the terms of trade. Any examination of the statistics will show that there has been a massive decline in the terms of trade going back to 1950. Since 1950 successive Australian governments have had to put up with the fact that what Australia sells abroad is worth less and less compared with what we buy abroad. Other governments have been able to cope with that fact but this Government simply announces that because of that change in the terms of trade every Australian will have to put up with a reduced standard of living.

We do not come to this debate as people who have been totally negative; we come to this debate having constantly urged the Government to do something about the basic problems that afflict our economy. Those basic problems are that our inflation rate is three times that of the average of our major trading partners, that our unemployment at the beginning of this recession stands at 8 per cent and youth unemployment at 22 per cent, that our external balance is in total disarray and that we have a current account deficit which is running at an annual rate of 6.2 per cent-a figure which Senator Walsh said we would not reach and about which he was so abusive when it occurred during the international recession in 1982. The reality is we are running an annual current account deficit at the rate of 6.2 per cent of gross domestic product in this financial year and that is the clearest sign of the peril that we face. Economic growth has relied heavily on government spending but private business investment has remained depressed during the recovery period. We in the Opposition have not been simply carping critics; we have told the Government very clearly what we believe it needs to do. When one looks at the recommendations that we have made to the Government and compare them with this weak, watery statement which says absolutely nothing, one sees why the Opposition is so bitterly disappointed with the failure of this Government. What we have said repeatedly-and we said it as recently as last Friday but it has been persistently put forward by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), by me and other Opposition spokesmen-is that for a start there must be an immediate assault on the Federal Government's spending through a mini-Budget in June. Yet this Government makes a weak statement saying that it will try to achieve some cuts in the next Budget. Is that not a wonderful advance on the position in which we found ourselves before this statement was made? Senator Walsh, who is sitting in the chamber, told us weeks ago, indeed months ago, that the Government would cut $1.4 billion off the Forward Estimates, yet in this statement we get absolutely no further down the track.

The Opposition has been saying that the current productivity claim before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission must be abandoned. In present circumstances it is absurd to be talking about a 3 per cent across the board productivity claim and we believe that the Australian public understands the need for those increases in remuneration to be delayed, postponed or, indeed, withdrawn. What is this Government doing? It is doing nothing about the current national wage case. It is making no move to disturb it. With respect to the next wage case the Government simply says now what it said in the last Budget-and remember it broke its word in the last Budget-that it will argue for discounting in the next national wage case. We have seen the Government make promises like that before; we know now as a result of this statement that the Government will communicate that wonderful bold initiative to the Australian Council of Trade Unions; we know that Mr Crean said last weekend that the trade union movement would not have a bar of further discounting. All we get in this statement is a reiteration of where we were yesterday. What do we find about the 3 per cent productivity rise at a time when industry in Australia is in crisis? This Government has been supporting a 3 per cent productivity rise. Do we find any relief in this statement? No, we do not. We find dressed up what was already in the Government's policy on the 3 per cent productivity rise-that it should be delivered over a period of two years. That is the precise position that was achieved under the accord mark 2 and this statement does not advance the position one iota.

This statement is the most pathetic failure on the part of the Government to come to grips with the changes that need to be made. The Opposition has also claimed that the current national wage case should be postponed, at least until September 1986 and preferably for 12 months. We have seen the weak-kneed failure of the Government to respond to that; once again we have seen nothing but a weak reiteration of the status quo. We have called upon the Government to do something about the demand for investment. It must do something about the anti-investment elements in the Keating tax package. Of course in this statement no action is taken on the Keating anti-business tax package. We are stuck with all those elements which are discouraging business in Australia today. This statement offers no change.

What we do find of course is a mild flirtation-and I emphasis a very mild one-with the idea that some interest subsidies will be provided to industry. My reading of the statement shows that the only industry that is actually being offered anything is the heavy engineering industry. In this statement there is still no definition of what assistance will be given to that industry. All we get is a reaffirmation of an announcement made by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, a month or more ago. There is nothing new in that assistance to industry. In any event, we all know that industry came here and talked to the Government last week and that it was not interested in obtaining interest subsidies. What the industries of Australia want are more competitive trading conditions-a reduction of costs and an overall reduction in interest rates. Yet none of those things were produced in this economic statement. It is a complete fizzer and it promises nothing to those who will have to make the investment decisions, except, of course, new terms of price surveillance. In the interests of apparent even-handedness the Government has made some rather weak suggestions that it will do something to increase price surveillance. This is clearly tokenism; it is clearly meant to dress up the package to entice the trade union movement into a more co-operative attitude.

The reality is that there is nothing in this statement which reflects all the proud words of Senator Button. He has been talking for three years about how to restore industry in Australia. For three years he has been making the broadest generalisations about what needs to be done. Honourable senators will find all those broad generalisations repeated in this statement. We were told that the Government would do something about education. But there is as much about education in this statement as there was in Senator Button's Playboy interview. He has not advanced the issue any further and he is still saddled with a Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, who does not believe in any of the things that he says about industry and education. There is nothing here about reducing costs of industry, about the broad industry approach, which has been put down by Senator Button and which we have endeavoured to support in order to encourage him to get into the constructive field where he does something. Nothing is being done in this statement.

We are not only seeing the failure of the Government's general economic policy in this document, we are also seeing the failure of the industry policies that have been put forward by Senator Button, because the framework that he sketched out as being necessary for the revival of Australia's manufacturing industry will not be delivered by this Government. There is absolutely no prospect of the sort of relief that is needed from the over-regulation, cost burdens and ridiculous work practices which afflict so many Australian manufacturers. None of that is dealt with in this weak statement which has been made by the Prime Minister. One can only feel sick at heart that the Prime Minister's vanity caused him to take this matter out of the hands of the Treasurer. One can only feel sick at heart that a few weeks ago, when Treasurer Keating started to admit the real problems of the Australian economy, he was cut off at the pass by a Prime Minister whose vanity was wounded and who insisted on taking over and who today has produced nothing. The Prime Minister has produced nothing which will do anything to restore Australia's economic fortunes.

We have a situation in which the Opposition has made a positive suggestion over and over again that there should be a relaxation of foreign investment controls. That is a way in which we might do something to encourage greater capital investment in Australia, a way in which we might do something about the outflow of capital and the excessive borrowings that have been so much the concern of Opposition senators and Democrats senators in recent weeks. What do we find about foreign investment? Again, a weak as water statement which basically boils down to saying that the Government will speed up some of the processes. There is absolutely no hard edge to any of the reforms or changes which are put forward in this document.
What we have is a statement full of examples of the very high level of intellect that has gone into its preparation. On page 14 of the supporting papers, the Government says:
The process of economic adjustment is being greatly facilitated by the depreciation of the Australian dollar.

One gets the feeling that when the Australian dollar is worth US1c, the Government will regard our economic problems as having been solved. I just wonder how in the world Senator Walsh and Senator Button, who are in the chamber at the moment and who have lectured us on the economics of improving Australia's situation, could be associated with this pathetic document, with this pathetic example of prime ministerial failure. I really wonder how in the world Ministers with the attitudes that they have expressed in this place can stay in the Ministry and be a party to what we have here. I suppose that Senator Walsh contributed the following words on page 2 of the statement:
we have, for the time being, to accept reduced standards of living and permanently, increased standards of effort

I will always think of Senator Walsh when I think of the reducing standards of living of the people of Australia because he is the Minister who sees the terms of trade as requiring us simply to accept that there will be reduced standards of living for the people of Australia.

What the Opposition believes, what the Liberal and National parties believe, is that if we had wise government, if the Government followed the five points that have been put forward by the Opposition for the improvement of our economy, if we got the tax man off the back of those who want to make an effort in the community, if we restored incentive in this community, if we reduced the costs of production in this community, Australia might have a chance. But, no, what we have is a government which remains in the thrall of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. We have a government which is so greedy for taxes that it continues to impose new and ever heavier tax burdens on the Australian people and on Australian business. We have a government with a penchant for regulation which will be further increased in the prices surveillance arrangements set out in this document. We have a government which has shown that it has lost its nerve and its sense of direction. Today we have seen the beginning of the end of the Hawke Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the Opposition, the Australian Democrats take a similarly disappointing view of the statement made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) although I must say that the Democrats find little agreement with the suggestions that the Opposition says should have been in the statement. However, we would be in total agreement with its condem- nation or criticism of the statement. At a time like this of national crisis-and that is what we are talking about-I believe that one should not be uncharitable or unnecessarily unkind; one would want to be bi-partisan. I am indebted to my friend Senator David Vigor who, by way of overall comment, said that this statement means that from this day forth, things will be as they were in the past. In other words, this statement unhappily contributes little, if anything, to rectify the ills of the country. In fact, my friend Senator Vigor put forward the imagery of the economy now being a runaway car rolling down a hill with the driver fiddling around with the cigarette lighter rather than doing the fundamental things to stop the car.

SPEECH.PARA: So, overall, we are disappointed with the statement. However, at the beginning, we give credit to the Government for its courage in attempting to carry out further wage discounting. We believe that is crucial. We give the Government credit for signalling its intention to try to negotiate with the trade unions to do that. However, this statement does not regard that as an achievement. It just says that that is a statement of intention. One wonders why there has been all the hullabaloo of making a statement to the nation when all the Government has to report on is its intent to do something. One would have thought that in a matter of this kind the nation would be much more interested in achievements rather than intent.

Credit must also be given for the decision to counsel the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to delay the implementation of the productivity increase over two years. This will be welcomed by employers, particularly those employers in the export oriented industries. We welcome the indication that the Government will carefully monitor prices and that a $1 billion saving will be made in the Budget. However, we must say that the means of achieving both of these aims is cleverly concealed in the statement by the Prime Minister and in the accompanying documents. We believe it would be tremendous if prices in the market-place and the professional area could be monitored. However, the means of achieving that are very vague. In the quick look that I have had, I cannot find anything to show how $1 billion can be shaved off the deficit. However, that is what the statement says. They remain vague statements of intent rather than spelling out the definitive mechanisms as to how to bring them about.

We also commend the proposed Buy Australian campaign, which again is relatively vague. But we are very disappointed with the lack of definite instructions to government departments to buy Australian. A committee will be required to inquire into this proposal and report within six months. One wonders why a committee is needed to report within six months on how and why government departments should be directed to buy Australian goods. That decision could have been made tonight and could apply as from tomorrow. This particular part of the statement led my friend Senator Janine Haines to make the rather unkind remark that obviously the Government is looking for an inquiry-led recovery. One would have thought that that is one decision that could have been made tonight. For goodness sake, we do not need an inquiry over a period of six months to look into a Buy Australia campaign.

However, we deeply regret that no action has been taken to discourage unproductive economic activity which is funded by foreign borrowings. It is here that we depart diametrically from Senator Chaney and the Liberal Party of Australia. I notice that Senator Chaney advocated in his speech the inflow of more overseas capital. This would lead to more foreign takeovers. We would say the opposite. From tonight, because of this statement, foreign capital will still be warmly welcomed into Australia by the Liberal Party and the Australian Labor Party. This will result in further takeovers of Australian industry by foreign firms. It will increase the already massive burden of repaying the interest and dividend payments. One of the chronic problems of the Australian economy surely is the increasing overseas debt. I pointed out today that, in the last 10 months, Australia has had an adverse balance of payments of $12 billion. Repayments of interest and dividends now represent half of that amount and exports are being asked more and more to fund the debt in interest repayments and dividends. The other chronic problem facing the economy is the burgeoning domestic deficit. Those two chronic problems have not been apprehended or even regarded in this statement.

The Democrats have advocated low interest loans to industries with high export potential. Nothing has been done in this statement to assist these industries. Perhaps the Government has been caught up in its own deregulatory rhetoric, which it has copied off the Liberal Party, to interfere with the market-place. The Democrats say that those industries that have the capacity and capability to export are in desperate need of being assisted by the Government with low interest loans. There was no mention in the statement of the need to negotiate with trade unions in export oriented industries in respect of writing no-strike clauses into their agreements in return for a guarantee of investment in those industries. We understand that the responsible sections of the trade union movement would be happy to agree to no-strike conditions, provided that future investment is guaranteed. The Democrats would like to see a direction to superannuation funds to invest in these export capable Australian industries.

This much heralded address to the nation will raise to a dangerous level expectations for Australia to lift its game both here and abroad. These expectations having been raised, the Democrats are quite apprehensive that, because of the vagueness of this statement, they will be dashed to the ground, with resulting damage to our economy and to our dollar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats are disappointed in the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in which very few hard policy decisions have been taken. The Government is to be commended for its stated objective to hold down wages, but unfortunately, it has looked at only one side of the equation-wages. I ask what will the Government do positively? The real problem, as we see it, has not been addressed. To remedy our balance of payments we must develop both our service industries and our manufacturing industries. There is very little direction from the Government in this statement as to how this should be done. To develop our export industries we must divert resources into those areas. Concentrating on wages alone will not solve this problem.

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing that we believe the Government should have done was to give positive direction on a Buy Australian campaign. It has said that it will move in this direction-it will set up a committee. The fact is that last year State and Federal governments spent $22 billion-$2,200m. If the Government had directed the Federal and State purchasing agencies to divert only 5 per cent of that $22 billion expenditure into buying Australian products instead of overseas products, it could have saved at least $1.2 billion worth of foreign exchange. Setting up a committee and allowing that committee to report in seven or eight months time is not tackling the fundamental problem and is not giving hard direction.

The second thing that we believe the Government should have done in this policy statement is to set out ways in which it intends to encourage investment into productive areas. It is no good relying on the newly deregulated financial markets to channel investment productively. They will not do that, and that has been shown already. It is very much easier for financial institutions to make windfall profits from dealings on the stock exchange. We only have to look at this simple fact: Over the last six months no less than $7.7 billion-$770 million-has gone into takeover bids and defences involving Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. Not one cent of that enormous expenditure has gone into increasing the productive capacity of our largest company. All of that money-the $7.7 billion-has gone purely into stock market speculation and it is sloshing around in the stock markets of this country.

We can contrast that amount of money with what was supposed to be spent by the Whitlam Government. Let us remember that back in 1973-74 the Khemlani affair was at its height. In those days Mr Whitlam wanted to spend $4 billion-$4,000m. What did he want to do? He wanted to spend it in a productive area. He wanted to develop the North West Shelf and build a pipeline across Australia. At least, that $4 billion would have gone into productive areas. That $4 billion when converted to current dollars is worth about $8 billion. We are talking about the amount of money that would have gone into productive investments back in 1974 being spent in 1986 in no productive capacity whatsoever but being spent purely in stock market speculation.

It is a great pity that the Government has not taken the opportunity to announce hard policies. We have to do something about our balance of payments. We have a deficit representing 5 per cent of our gross domestic product. We have one of the highest deficits in the Western world. We can contrast Australia with Canada, which has a very similar economy. It is essentially a trading economy. It is essentially an economy that relies on commodity exports. Canada, in spite of the drop in commodity prices, has a trading surplus of one per cent of gross domestic product, compared with Australia's deficit of 5 per cent of gross domestic product. That is a critical situation that calls for hard policy directions by the Government. Unfortunately, these are notably missing from this document.

One hopes that the directions that the Government has outlined and that its promises to move in certain directions will result very quickly in hard policies being formed by the Government. Unfortunately, on reading this document one sees that committees will be set up and that the Government will do something about trying to make the Public Service more efficient, but it has no hard policy on how this is to be done. The Government talks about the need to buy Australian goods, but it is relying mainly on the Australian people being encouraged to buy Australian. There is no hard option showing how the Government proposes that this be done. In summary, we believe that the ball is still in the Government's corner. It has to do something positive. It has to give firm directions so that Australia can take a new direction. In a word, the Government must produce goods that can be sold on international markets. If we cannot do that quickly, Australia will certainly perish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The address to the nation by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) makes an appeal to all people in Australia to face the challenge and together do something about it. The Prime Minister has an undoubted capacity to appeal to people to work together to meet and to face challenges. My concern about this document is that it will raise expectations which will not be fulfilled, because it fails to address a most crucial economic and social question facing this country today, and that is youth unemployment. The Government accepts that youth unemployment will remain high, but in order to obtain unemployment benefits youth will somehow be put to work. How will this be done? It is not stated in the document. Presumably, the type of work that is envisaged is not the type of work which will give dignity to the youth of our country. It will probably be a type of conscriptive work which will be simply boring for young people.

SPEECH.PARA: That this document does not address the real problem-that is, there are more people in or seeking paid work than there are jobs available-is a disgrace. Appendix H, which deals with the employment statistics, states that the participation rate in the work force has risen, but what it does not say is that youth unemployment stands at the unacceptable rate of 22 per cent. What it does not say is that, whereas 20 years ago, the rate of youth employment in the Commonwealth Public Service was 22.6 per cent, now it is down to an all time low of less than 5 per cent. The Government has the answer to that problem within its power; it can reverse that situation. Its Ministers are in control of their departments. Why do they not start there?

This is a document which really does not come to grips with another problem, that is the forcing of families on one income to go out and get another income because they cannot make ends meet. This is one of the problems facing the Government when it thinks about discounting wages because those persons on lower incomes will be forced to go out to try to get two incomes, thus closing off jobs for young people. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.
