SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
INSPECTOR-GENERAL OF INTELLIGENCE AND SECURITY BILL 1986

In May last year the Minister representing the Prime Minister presented to the Senate the final reports of the Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies-RCASIA-and stated the Government's initial reaction to them. Since then, considerable effort has been devoted to implementing most of the reforms proposed by Mr Justice Hope and to developing the three Bills the Acting Prime Minister and Attorney-General introduced in the House of Representatives.

Of necessity, much of the work of the intelligence and security community is conducted confidentially and goes unnoticed. This community rarely receives public commendation, but its errors, and speculation about its activities, have a way of generating lurid headlines. Much of this speculation cannot be officially debated. It is an irony that the very confidentiality of the agencies' work seems to inspire demands to expose and publicise their activities and that the trust placed in them to conduct their work in confidence creates, in some, a want of trust.

Speculation and ill-advised criticism can negatively affect public perceptions of the agencies. In recognition of this, and in an attempt to counter it, we have seen over the last decade two major reviews of the intelligence and security community pointing to the need for clearer public statements of purpose, more visibility, greater oversight and accountability-all aimed at demystifying and increasing public confidence in the agencies.

In response to the Royal Commission on Intelligence and Security in the mid-1970s, the Fraser Government took some necessary steps towards making the intelligence and security community more accountable and meshing it with the wider processes of government. For example, the charter of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization-ASIO-was clarified in legislation and a Security Appeals Tribunal was created; the existence of the Australian Secret Intelligence Service-ASIS-and the Defence Signals Directorate-DSD-was formally acknowledged; and bipartisan arrangements were put in place to keep the Opposition informed of significant intelligence and security issues. A change in Government has not altered the character of these arrangements, although we strongly believe that further steps are needed to hold the agencies more accountable and to increase public trust in their activities.

This Government has already announced some reforms, in response to the second of the royal commissions by Mr Justice Hope. These, together with the draft legislation now before the Senate, will more clearly delineate the functions of the agencies and make them more accountable.

I shall not repeat here all the measures announced in the tabling statement by the Minister representing the Prime Minister on 22 May 1985. Since then action has been taken to implement a number of the other recommendations. For example:

we have revised ASIS's Directive to exclude preparation of training for covert action in the form of special operations or special political action. This will prevent the type of training that led to the Sheraton Hotel incident.

on 27 November 1985 my colleague, the Minister for Defence, announced details of action taken in response to the Royal Commission's recommendation to improve consultation between the Joint Intelligence Organization-JIO-and its major customers.

the Office of Security and Intelligence Co-ordination has been established within the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet to provide an independent secretariat to the Security Committee of Cabinet and the Secretaries Committee on Intelligence and Security.

we have also established a National Intelligence Committee, chaired by the Office of National Assessments-ONA-and including senior representatives of policy departments and JIO. The Committee advises ONA on the development of its work program, monitors ONA's product and advises it on intelligence needs and priorities.

Additionally, the Government recognises that, under existing arrangements, responsibility for protective security is dispersed among a number of departments and agencies, and none has responsibility for co-ordinating policy in this area. In response to specific RCASIA recommendations the Prime Minister has therefore decided to allocate this responsibility to the Department of the Special Minister of State, which will convene a new high level committee to co-ordinate protective security policy and physical and administrative security measures.
There are other measures which, for security reasons, we will not be announcing.

A significant number of the key recommendations of the Royal Commission require legislation. The three Bills before the Senate today will allow considerably increased scrutiny of the intelligence and security agencies. But the Government has also ensured that their effectiveness is in no way diminished. Indeed, we are satisfied that, as a result of these measures, public confidence in the agencies will be increased and as a consequence they will become more effective.
The measures set out in the Bills are based on the Government's firm belief that the agencies should be accountable. Following close examination, they have been accepted by the agencies.

Before moving to the details of the proposals, I would like again to express the Government's appreciation to Mr Justice Hope. The Government has now considered, and in large part acted upon, all of the recommendations in the Royal Commission's reports. As we have looked more closely at his reports, which deal with some particularly sensitive issues, our appreciation of his contribution has grown.

On behalf of the Attorney-General I shall address shortly a Bill incorporating a number of major reforms relating to ASIO. These include more careful definition and limitation of ASIO's functions and activities, and the establishment of a Joint Parliamentary Committee on ASIO.

I now turn to the proposal for an independent watchdog over all the agencies, which stems from the Australian Labor Party submission to the Royal Commission, and which was further developed by Mr Justice Hope.

The Government's aims in establishing an Office of Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security include assisting Ministers with the oversight and review of: firstly, the compliance with the law by Australian intelligence and security agencies; secondly, the propriety of their particular activities; thirdly, the effectiveness and appropriateness of certain procedures; and finally, certain other aspects of the activities and procedures of some of those agencies, for example concerning employee grievances.

Our aims also include assisting Ministers in ensuring that the activities of the agencies are consistent with human rights and allowing for review of certain directions given to ASIO by the Attorney-General.

While the emphasis is on the Inspector-General's assistance to Ministers, elements of the Inspector- General's work will be available for parliamentary and public scrutiny. Provision is made for an annual report to be furnished to the Prime Minister, with a copy to the Leader of the Opposition. Edited as necessary on grounds of security, defence, international relations and privacy, the report will be laid before each House of the Parliament.

A person of exceptional skills and particular qualities will be required for the Office. Being a new position, having a pivotal role in Australia's security and intelligence machinery, its occupant will deal with highly sensitive issues and respond to a range of ministerial and public requests. In recognition of the importance of this appointment, the Bill requires that before a recommendation on appointment is made to the Governor-General, the Prime Minister shall consult with the Leader of the Opposition.

As the Prime Minister mentioned in May last year, the Office will be within his portfolio. Initially, it will comprise a small staff, but the Government will closely monitor its workload to ensure that staffing remains adequate.

Turning to the functions of the Inspector-General, honourable senators will note that the Bill distinguishes between the agencies, both in terms of the Inspector-General's functions and the mechanisms by which inquiries can be instigated.

The distinctions are consistent with the functions ascribed to the Inspector-General in the various RCASIA reports, and reflect the different purposes of ASIO as our domestic security intelligence organisation, ASIS and DSD as collectors of external intelligence, and JIO and ONA as assessors of intelligence.

These differing purposes are reflected in the mechanisms for initiating inquiries. For example, the Inspector-General may initiate his own inquiries into the legality or propriety of activities of ASIO, ASIS or DSD, but only the responsible Minister may initiate such an inquiry with respect to the activities of JIO or ONA. As Mr Justice Hope points out, questions of legality and propriety rarely arise with respect to ONA and JIO, which do not collect intelligence themselves but simply assess intelligence collected by others. Similarly the Inspector-General may initiate an inquiry into ASIO's procedures for ensuring legality and propriety, but not into those of the other agencies whose operations rarely have a direct impact on individual Australians.

Despite these differences, the Bill confers a number of important functions on the Inspector-General with respect to all of the agencies. Specifically, the Inspector-General will inquire into: The propriety of the agencies' activities; their compliance with Australian law, Ministerial directions or guidelines; human rights; and their procedures relating to grievances of employees.

In recognition of his overall responsibility for intelligence and security matters the Prime Minister, in addition to the responsible Ministers, will be able to request the Inspector-General to inquire into any one or more of the agencies.
There are two additional functions that relate to ASIO alone, in recognition of its potential impact on individual Australians.

Honourable senators will recollect that, in his report on the Combe-Ivanov affair in December 1983, Mr Justice Hope pointed out that circumstances can arise where ASIO produces a report adverse to the interests of an individual Australian and there is no existing right of review unless he or she is a public servant. His Honour recommended a statutory procedure whereby an independent body decides whether and, if so, how such a person should be provided with an opportunity to be heard. On tabling that report, the Prime Minister welcomed the recommendation; this Bill includes provision for the Inspector-General to make such inquiries.

The second additional function relates to directions given to ASIO by the Attorney-General concerning the collection or communication of intelligence about a particular individual. In the ASIO Amendment Bill which I shall address shortly, a number of changes are proposed to section 8 of the ASIO Act to clarify the nature and extent of ministerial control of the Organization. One element of those changes will provide that the Attorney cannot override the opinion of the Director-General on the question of whether the collection or communication of intelligence concerning a particular individual is justified on security grounds, except by a direction in writing which sets out the Attorney's reasons. The Inspector-General Bill gives the Inspector-General the function of inquiring into such directions, specifically into whether collection is justified by reason of its relevance to security or whether communication would be for a purpose relevant to security.

The Government agrees with Mr Justice Hope that the combination of these measures gives recognition to the paramountcy of ministerial control, whilst providing a safeguard to inhibit and bring to light any misuse of that control.

I mention that in respect of each of the agencies the Inspector-General is given the function of inquiring into matters relating to human rights. Under the provisions of the Bill, the Inspector-General is to perform the functions that would otherwise be the responsibility of the Human Rights Commission in relation to possible human rights breaches by the agencies-including privacy, and discrimination on grounds of race, sex and so on. This was not directly addressed by the Royal Commission, but the Government believes it to be an appropriate corollary to inquiry into the propriety of the agencies' activities. We intend to propose similar provisions in respect of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission once it is established. By referring possible violations of human rights by the agencies to the Inspector-General, the Bill seeks to avoid duplication and meet the need for such matters to be examined by an independent authority with unrestricted access to classified information.

With the approval of the responsible Minister the Inspector-General will be able to inquire into a matter that occurred outside Australia or before the commencement of the Act. In deciding that ministerial approval will be required to do so, the Government has taken account of the prospective workload of the Inspector-General and the fact that Mr Justice Hope has conducted two major royal commissions over recent years, both of which invited public submissions.

It is a fundamental tradition of our system of government that Ministers themselves are, and should remain, accountable to Parliament. Bearing in mind also that the Office of the Inspector-General is being created to assist Ministers in their oversight of the agencies, the Inspector-General is not to inquire into actions taken by Ministers except in relation to the specific ministerial directions to ASIO I have already addressed.

The Government also wishes to avoid establishing the Inspector-General as a further avenue of appeal on matters that can already be taken to the Security Appeals Tribunal. The Inspector-General shall therefore not inquire into a matter that can be reviewed by that Tribunal.

The clauses of the Bill dealing with complaints are in the main comparable with those in other administrative review legislation. Amongst other things, the Bill enables a complaint to be made orally or in writing; gives the Inspector-General customary discretions not to proceed with inquiries into complaints under specified circumstances; and provides special arrangements for persons in custody.

Similarly, the clauses dealing with inquiries also draw on the models provided by other administrative review legislation, subject to the constraints of national security. I do not intend to elaborate on these provisions. An important stipulation, given the sensitive national interests to be covered in this jurisdiction, is that the Inspector-General shall inform the responsible Minister and agency head before commencing an inquiry. During the course of inquiries the Inspector-General may also discuss relevant matters with the responsible Minister or the Prime Minister. We believe the maintenance of trust and good communications between all parties involved will be essential to the effective operation of the Office of Inspector-General.

The consultative process built into the conduct of inquiries carries over into the preparation of reports. Draft reports are to be provided to the head of an agency and provision is made for relevant comments by the agency head to be included in the final report. Final reports are to be provided to the responsible Minister, to the agency head, and, if commissioned by the Prime Minister, to the Prime Minister.

The Inspector-General is required to include in a report the reasons for conclusions and recommendations. In addition, where a report concludes that a person has been adversely affected by action taken by an agency, the Inspector-General may recommend compensation.

Whenever an inquiry has been undertaken in response to a complaint, the complainant is to be given a written response by the Inspector-General, subject to agreement with the responsible Minister that the terms of the response will not jeopardise security, defence or international relations.

The Inspector-General will be able to monitor action-or inaction-arising from reports. Where an agency head proposes taking action as a result of a report, the Inspector-General is to be given details. If the Inspector-General believes this action to be inadequate, he or she may discuss the matter with the responsible Minister and provide a report to the Prime Minister.

Finally, the Bill contains a number of standard miscellaneous and administrative provisions. The Bill provides for the Inspector-General's terms and conditions of appointment, remuneration, leave, resignation, termination of appointment, disclosure of interests and staff. It goes without saying that heavy emphasis is also placed on the need for the Inspector-General and staff to appropriately safeguard and maintain the secrets entrusted to them.

The creation of an Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security is a key recommendation of Mr Justice Hope and constitutes a vital component of the Government's reform package developed for the intelligence and security area. The Government embraced the concept and, having now translated it into draft legislation, is more than ever convinced that the creation of the Office is a highly beneficial addition to the machinery of Government. We believe that the legislation establishes an Office which will, to paraphrase the Royal Commissioner, provide an independent oversight of the agencies' activities, give the public a greater assurance that those activities are proper ones, and clear the agencies, or bring them to task-as the case may be-if allegations of improper conduct are made against them.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the revised explanatory memorandum.
AUSTRALIAN SECURITY INTELLIGENCE ORGANIZATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986

This Bill, and the related Inspector-General and Intelligence and Security (Consequential Amendments) Bills, stem from the Government's consideration of the report of the Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies. It is designed to clarify and define the role and powers of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization and to strengthen the arrangements for its control and accountability.
In particular, the Bill provides, very much along the lines recommended by Mr Justice Hope, for:
significant changes to clarify ASIO's jurisdiction, and an additional function in regard to the obtaining of foreign intelligence in Australia;
a strengthening of ministerial control over ASIO; and
changes in the provisions concerning the Security Appeals Tribunal.

As foreshadowed by the Prime Minister in his statement on 22 May 1985 on the tabling of the report of the Royal Commission, provision is also made for the establishment of a parliamentary joint committee to oversight certain of ASIO's activities. The opportunity has been taken to deal with a number of other matters that have come to light as a result of experience in the operation of the ASIO Act.
I turn now to the details of the Bill.
ASIO Jurisdiction and Powers

The Government has given close consideration, in the light of the report of the Royal Commission, to the statutory definition of ASIO's role and powers. It is of great importance, to ASIO itself as well as to those charged with oversighting its activities and to the community at large, that ASIO's statutory charter should be defined appropriately and as clearly as possible.

The Bill provides for a number of changes to the ASIO Act which are designed to clarify ASIO's jurisdiction, and to define more closely and precisely matters of legitimate security interest. Clause 3 proposes the following significant changes to the key definition of `security' in s. 4 of the Act:

the term `subversion' is deleted from the definition of `security' and relevant activities are more tightly defined and comprehended within the concept of `politically motivated violence'. Without detracting from ASIO's effectiveness, the definition will concentrate ASIO's attention more clearly on those violent activities, going beyond the scope of lawful advocacy and dissent, directed at undermining Australia's system of Government.

The new definition of politically motivated violence also covers terrorism and related activities, of the kind covered by the present definition of `terrorism', and makes it clear that threats of or acts causing unlawful harm to achieve a political end, are included.

the term `active measures of foreign intervention' is deleted from the definition of `security' and replaced by a more tightly constructed definition of `act of foreign interference' along the lines suggested by Mr Justice Hope. The new definition spells out more clearly the kind of activity which, because it is of foreign origin, is a legitimate matter of security concern.

Clause 9 provides for the inclusion in the legislation of a new provision-section 17A-which declares that the ASIO Act shall not limit the right of person to engage in lawful advocacy, protest or dissent, and that the exercise of that right shall not, by itself, be regarded as prejudicial to security. The functions of ASIO are to be construed accordingly. The Government regards this as an important statement of principle to guide ASIO in the often difficult exercise of its discretions under the Act.

Another change flows from the acceptance by the Government of Mr Justice Hope's recommendation that ASIO should be empowered to collect foreign intelligence in Australia: that is, intelligence relating to the capabilities, intentions or activities of foreign powers. Mr Justice Hope noted that there was no provision in Australian legislation providing for the collection of such intelligence, which it is in the national interest for Australia to acquire, and recommended that the legal authority to do so be given to ASIO. Such intelligence will only be obtained, pursuant to the new function which clause 8 will add to the statement of ASIO's functions in s. 17, under the written warrant of the Attorney-General, following a request by the Minister for Foreign Affairs or the Minister for Defence. Specific provision is made to prevent the use of the relevant powers for the purpose of collecting information concerning an Australian citizen, permanent resident or company. Strict controls will be placed on the communication of foreign intelligence under the new powers and provision is made for conditions minimising the obtaining and retention of information not publicly available concerning Australian citizens or permanent residents.

Clause 9 also proposes amendment of s. 17 to put beyond doubt ASIO's power to provide advice on matters of protective security, that is, on administrative or physical measures for the protection of people, information or property.

Mention should also be made in this context to the proposed provision, to which I shall refer again, empowering the Minister to lay down guidelines to be observed by ASIO. There will be clear scope for such guidelines to be given in regard to the exercise of its functions under aspects of the definition of `security' which necessarily are expressed in fairly broad terms. In regard to one aspect of security, that of `politically motivated violence', the Bill goes further and requires such guidelines to be laid down by the Minister.
Ministerial Control

Ministerial control is a fundamental element of the arrangements for the control and accountability of ASIO. The Organization is accountable through the Director-General of Security to the Attorney-General and through him to the Parliament. Mr Justice Hope noted in his report the importance, for the oversight of ASIO's activities in the public interest and ASIO's accountability through the Parliament to the public, of the effectiveness of its ministerial control. He also noted the need for an appropriate balance to be struck between the ability of a government to exercise control over ASIO and the highly important principle that ASIO should be politically impartial.

The Bill contains in clause 5 provisions, along the lines proposed by Mr Justice Hope, which are designed to strengthen ministerial control over ASIO and to achieve this necessary balance. An amendment to s. 8 makes it clear that in the performance of his functions under the Act, the Director-General is subject to the directions of the Minister. Any such direction shall, if requested, be put in writing. The amendment ensures that the Minister's authority over the Organization is ultimately paramount. As stated by Mr Justice Hope, the Minister, as the elected office holder accountable for ASIO and its activities to Parliament and the public, is placed in a position where he or she is able in the end to determine, and assume responsibility for, activities pertaining to the security of Australia.

There are two necessary qualifications to this provision. The first is that the Minister is not empowered to override the opinion of the Director-General concerning the nature of the advice which should be given by the Organisation. The second is that the Minister is not empowered to override the opinion of the Director-General as to whether the collection or communication of intelligence concerning a particular individual is or is not justified, except by a written direction to the Director-General setting out his reasons. This extends the area of ministerial control but, in order to guard against the possibility of mis-use for political purposes, there are appropriate safeguards. The Minister is required in such a case to give a copy of his direction, including his reasons, to both the Prime Minister and the Inspector-General. The Inspector-General is to be required by his legislation to address the appropriateness of any such direction in his report.

As already mentioned, the Act will also be amended to insert a new provision authorising the Minister to give written guidelines to the Director-General in respect of the performance by ASIO of any of its statutory functions and powers. The Minister will thus be able to play a positive role in regulating ASIO's conduct. In particular, in areas of the legislation involving broad discretion and judgment the Minister will be able to set appropriate standards. As the Prime Minister observed when tabling Mr Justice Hope's report, the areas to be covered by guidelines will include intelligence collection, targeting, review of file holdings and the extent to which ASIO should, from time to time, be involved in investigating activities relating to the hindering of Defence Force functions.

The Bill provides that the Minister is to table guidelines in Parliament, subject to the deletion of sensitive material. Where appropriate, guidelines not tabled in Parliament will be referred to the Parliamentary Joint Committee. A copy of the guidelines, without deletion, will be made available to the Leader of the Opposition.
Security Appeals Tribunal

The Security Appeals Tribunal plays an important role in the oversight of ASIO, by reviewing security assessments made by ASIO about individuals. Clauses 18 to 31 of the Bill propose a number of changes to the provisions concerning the review of adverse or qualified ASIO security assessments. Principally, they support and strengthen the present position that ASIO security assessments are advisory only, and should form only part of the information on which a security related decision is based. The amendments also include-
more precise definitions of adverse and qualified security assessments
a discretion in the Tribunal to make an order against the Commonwealth for costs reasonably incurred by an applicant who is successful, or substantially successful, in his application for review.
I mention that the Intelligence and Security (Consequential Amendments) Bill also provides for an extension of the Tribunal's jurisdiction in respect of security assessments for deportation purposes.
Parliamentary Joint Committee on ASIO

The Government believes that existing oversight and accountability measures for ASIO will be improved by involving the Parliament to a greater extent in those measures. The Bill therefore proposes the establishment of a Parliamentary Joint Committee on ASIO. Because the Committee will be required to deal on a regular basis with various kinds of sensitive information, and because of the special considerations which must apply whenever information of that sort is made available, the Government believes it appropriate for the Committee to be set up by legislation and for that legislation to specifically delineate the powers, functions and obligations of the Committee.

The Committee will comprise seven members, and will have a majority of government members and a majority of members from the House of Representatives. To achieve this result, the Bill provides that Committee members will be appointed as follows:
For the House of Representatives, four members will be appointed by resolution of the House on the nomination of the Prime Minister.
For the Senate, three members will be appointed by resolution of the Senate on the nomination of the Leader of the Government in the Senate.

Before nominations are made, the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Government in the Senate are required to consult with the leader of each recognised political party represented in the House or the Senate; and they are required in making nominations to have regard to the desirability of ensuring that the composition of the Committee takes into account the representation of recognised political parties in the Parliament. Ministers are not eligible for appointment.

Broadly speaking, the functions of the Committee are to review aspects of the activities of ASIO that are referred to it either by the Minister or by either House of the Parliament, and to report to Parliament thereon. The Bill also enables the Committee to ask the Minister to refer a particular matter to it.

It is not the function of the Committee to operate as a grievance mechanism. That is a function of the Inspector-General, whose Annual Report will, however, be available to the Parliament. Nor will it be a function of the Committee to review operationally sensitive matters, or certain other matters set out in the Bill.
The Bill makes provision for the protection of intelligence and security information.
The Bill also makes provision empowering the Committee to obtain information and documents, including from ASIO.

The Government believes that the provisions provide a proper balance between greater parliamentary involvement in the oversight of ASIO and the limits, of the Executive's ability, having in mind its responsibilities in regard to security matters, to make sensitive information more widely accessible. The Government believes that the creation of the proposed Parliamentary Joint Committee, independent as it is of the Executive Government, will, in conjunction with the other measures outlined, provide an effective and appropriate scheme of public accountability for ASIO.
Other Matters
The Bill also makes provision for-
Extension of the offence, in s. 92, of making public the identity of an ASIO officer, to cover, subject to appropriate exceptions, disclosure of the identity of former officers.
Changes to the provisions governing employment of staff by ASIO. Terms and conditions of employment will be put on a statutory basis, instead of the present unsatisfactory contractual arrangements.

A statutory requirement for the tabling in Parliament of an annual report. The Government has adopted the practice of making a report to Parliament each year on ASIO's activities. That practice will now be given a legislative base.

The Director-General to be given the power to delegate his powers relating to staff or financial management, placing him in a similar position to Secretaries of Commonwealth Departments, and assisting in the management of the Organization.
Financial Impact Statement
The creation of a Parliamentary Joint Committee on ASIO will have a minor impact on expenditure in providing a small staff, and secure premises, for the Committee.

Giving the Security Appeals Tribunal a discretion to make an order against the Commonwealth for costs reasonably incurred by a successful applicant will have a minimal impact on expenditure. This may, however, be offset by savings which will result from requiring an applicant to indicate what matters are in dispute. This is likely to result in shorter hearings.
Conclusion

This Bill results from a thorough review by the Government of ASIO's role and powers. The Government has been greatly assisted in this review by the relevant findings and recommendations of Mr Justice Hope in the Report of the Royal Commission on Australia's Intelligence and Security Agencies. The Government believes that its legislative proposals, by clarifying and stating ASIO's functions in appropriate terms, and by providing for more effective control and oversight, will facilitate the effective discharge by ASIO of its functions and will provide significant assurance to the community as to the way in which ASIO carries out its functions.

The new review mechanisms do not in any way detract from the responsibilities of the Director-General of Security, and the Minister, for ensuring that ASIO is well managed and in its activities preserves a proper balance between the security of the nation and the individual rights of its citizens.
I commend the Bill to the Senate. I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
INTELLIGENCE AND SECURITY (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1986

This Bill provides for an amendment to the Crimes Act 1914, and for the amendment of other Acts as a consequence of the provisions of the ASIO Amendment Bill and the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Bill.
Principal features of the Bill are as follows:

The Audit Act 1901 is to be amended to provide for the addition of further details to the certificate supplied by the Minister each year to the Auditor-General dealing with the Organization's exempt account. That certificate will be required to state that the exempt accounts have been subject to internal inspection and examination, and whether any irregularity has been disclosed, and resolved or rectified.

Amendment of the offence of sedition in the Crimes Act 1914 to remove anachronistic provisions and to provide that the writing etc. of seditious words is not an offence unless done with an intent to create violence or public disturbance or disorder. This implements a recommendation by Mr Justice Hope.
The exemption of documents in the possession of, or received from, the Inspector General of Intelligence and Security from the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act 1982.

Amendment of the Human Rights Commission Act 1981 to provide that a complaint about an act or practice of a security or intelligence agency is to be investigated by the Inspector-General instead of the Commission

Amendment of the Migration Act 1958 to provide that the Minister can only order the deportation of a person from Australia on security grounds when he has been furnished with an adverse security assessment from ASIO. Where, in accordance with the provisions of the Act, the person has been informed of the adverse assessment, the security assessment will be reviewable by the Security Appeals Tribunal. Where the Tribunal does not confirm the adverse assessment the Minister will not be able to order deportation. This amendment will enable the security grounds on which a deportation decision is based to be fully reviewed by an independent Tribunal.

Finally there are a number of amendments to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979, corresponding to changes made to the special powers provisions of the ASIO Act, to take account of the new ASIO function of collecting foreign intelligence in Australia.
Financial Impact Statement
The addition to the jurisdiction of the Security Appeals Tribunal may lead to a slight increase in the cost of that Tribunal.
I commend the Bill to the Senate. I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Button) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to extend the operation of the nitrogenous fertiliser subsidy and the phosphate fertiliser subsidy schemes at current rates for a further three years until 30 June 1989. The two fertiliser assistance schemes are due to expire on 30 June this year following several extensions. The current proposal for a further extension follows a review initiated by the Government in January this year of both the production and consumption of fertilisers. In deciding to continue the consumption subsidies the Government is fulfilling the commitment given in the economic and rural policy statement, released on 15 April, that the overall cost of fertilisers to farmers would not rise as a result of the Government's decisions on the review of the fertiliser industry and the review of anti-dumping legislation.

The fertiliser subsidies are the largest single item of Commonwealth Government assistance to rural industries. In 1985-86 they are expected to cost the Commonwealth some $55m. The continuation of this assistance to the rural sector is a central element in the recent package of measures announced in the economic and rural policy statement. As recognised in the statement, this sector is currently experiencing particularly difficult conditions. While these are primarily due to international factors which are beyond the Government's control, the Government has undertaken to take steps domestically to relieve the economic pressures on the sector and to assist rural industries to improve their competitiveness in world markets. The extension of the fertiliser subsidies is an important step in that process. While some have questioned the effectiveness of the subsidies they remain an important measure in providing support for the purchase of a fundamental input into rural production. In saying that, let me emphasise the importance of the rural sector as an employer and contributor to our domestic economy and, perhaps more importantly, as a generator of export income. Rural industries continue to contribute about 40 per cent of our export income and, particularly in current circumstances, we need to ensure the continued health or our rural industries.

As previously stated, the subsidy rates to apply will be the same as those currently applying. That is, a subsidy of $20 per tonne of contained nitrogen and $12 per tonne of single strength superphosphate or $138 per tonne on the available phosphorous content of other phosphatic fertilisers. This measure is expected to cost the Government about $55m in each of the three years. In relation to the production of fertilisers, the Government still has under consideration the question of short-term assistance to local manufacturers. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN WINE AND BRANDY CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986GRAPE RESEARCH LEVY BILL 1986GRAPE RESEARCH LEVY COLLECTION BILL 1986WINE GRAPES LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1986WINE RESEARCH REPEAL BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 29 April, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating cognately five Bills-the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill, the Grape Research Levy Bill, the Grape Research Levy Collection Bill, the Wine Grapes Levy Amendment Bill and the Wine Research Repeal Bill. At the outset I want to say that the Opposition does not oppose these Bills. However, we have some reservations about the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation, as have some elements of the industry. There has been a suggestion by the industry that a sunset clause should be inserted with respect to the Wine and Brandy Corporation to indicate that it should persist for five years and that there should be an examination of that body's operations at the end of that period. However, the Opposition has decided that, although there may be some merit in that, in government-hopefully that will be after the next election-the Opposition will monitor the operations of the Corporation and review its purpose and the need for its existence after those observations.

SPEECH.PARA: A cross-section of views has been expressed by the three industries affected by the legislation. I refer, of course, to the grape growers, who are the basis of the industry, the wine makers and brandy distillers, and those who import brandies and wines. The Australian-based industries are united, however, in the view that the Government's actions have put these industries at risk and have caused a serious contraction both in grape growing and wine and brandy making in Australia. The industries are also concerned about the potential for a larger and more debilitating tax on wine and brandy in the emergency facing Australia today due to this Government's mismanagement of the economy.

I intend to spend a few minutes during the debate examining the history of tax on wines in Australia. It is interesting that a Labor Prime Minister, Mr Scullin, first taxed Australian wines in 1930. Subsequently, the tax was scrapped in 1931 as being self-defeating. When the Whitlam Labor Government came to power in 1972, whisky, for example, carried a sales tax 60 per cent greater that that on Australian brandy, but by the time that Government vacated the Treasury bench in 1975, sales tax on whisky was only 5 per cent greater than that on Australian brandy. As a result, brandy production fell from 4,484 kilolitres of alcohol to 1,784 kilolitres of alcohol in 1974-75-a reduction of some 2,700 kilolitres of alcohol, or a drop in the Australian brandy production of 60 per cent. As a result of the action taken by the Whitlam Labor Administration, brandy dropped from a 35.1 per cent share of the whisky-brandy market to 26.9 per cent-in other words, a drop of 8.2 per cent.

In the lead up to the 1983 election, the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, promised that there would be no tax on wines. However, in his first Budget he introduced a tax on fortified wines which he was forced to abandon in the 1984 Budget. Then the Government saw fit to introduce in its place a sales tax on table wine. As a result of this interference in the market-place, there was a marked increase in the importation of wine, especially from the European Economic Community, whose primary industry policies are causing havoc among the primary industries in Australia and, consequently, are having a disastrous effect on our economy. In addition, the share of the brandy-whisky market now enjoyed by imported whisky is 74.6 per cent and the Australian brandy share has fallen to a mere 17.2 per cent. In other words, in the decade in which Labor governments have had an influence on the wine and brandy industry, they have succeeded in stimulating the importation of wines, mainly from the EEC, and they have halved the share of Australian brandy in the brandy-whisky market from 35.1 per cent to 17.2 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —If that is a serious statement, you seem to have been using too much of the product yourself, Senator.

—I do not drink brandy at all, as a matter of fact, except for medicinal purposes. In other words, in the decade that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), who is at the table, has been in control of the destiny of Australia, damage has been done to the wine and brandy industry and this, of course, has had wide ramifications for the grape growing sector of the industry which, after all, is the basis for the whole wine and brandy industry in this country. Of course, the Government is aware of the difficulties facing the grape and wine industries because it accepted the first recommendation of the McKay Report of the Inquiry into the Grape and Wine Industries and provided $1.6m adjustment assistance to the wine grape industry. As a result of that, it introduced a vine pull scheme. Such is the state of the grape growing industry that 600 grape growers from throughout South Australia-an area which produces a significant proportion of the wines of Australia; about 67 per cent at the moment, I think-have applied for funds to pull out some 4,000 hectares of vines, which is the equivalent of 15 per cent of the vines in South Australia and 6 per cent of the total Australian wine grape plantings.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend the Government for extending the closing date of the scheme and allocating a further $1.7m provided that the States provide $1 for every $2 provided by the Commonwealth. I recall that, when this scheme was introduced last year, I made representations to the Government and raised the matter in the Senate. I said that it seemed quite inappropriate for the Government to force grape growers to make a decision, I think by the end of June this year, as to whether to pull out their vines. The Government wisely took note of that because, as the Minister will know, once one pulls out the vines under the scheme, one is not allowed to replant for five years. So I think it was fair and generous of the Government to recognise the plight of the grape growers. They really needed to experience the results of the last vintage before they could properly make a judgment on that. So I believe the Government has acted wisely in that respect. I am glad to note that it took notice of my representations and no doubt those of other members and senators from South Australia, Victoria and the rest of Australia who have an interest in this subject.

Let us examine the effect on the wine industry of the sales tax introduced by the Hawke Government. Despite this tax of 10 per cent, the retail price of wine has risen by only 6.5 per cent, which should be compared with the total increase in the consumer price index of 12.3 per cent since the tax was introduced. The retail price has declined in real terms by 5.2 per cent since the sales tax was introduced. The sales tax has been absorbed not by the consumer but by the production and distribution chain, with the weakest links in that chain suffering the most. Of course, the weakest links are the growers and the small wine makers in a market that remains almost static. In the 12 months to March 1986 sales of Australian wine have risen in volume by on 2.7 per cent over the sales in the 12 months to March 1985. Without the phenomenal sales growth in the cooler wines-I have not tried them but I am told that they are popular amongst younger people in Australia; it is a wine-based drink-there would have been an even more marked decline in the sales of wine in Australia. The industry has appealed to the Government to follow the other recommendation of the McKay Committee, namely:
There should be no increase in the sales tax until sufficient time has gone by to measure the impact of the present tax . . .

The Committee suggests that this should persist for at least two or three years in order to make a proper assessment of the effects of that tax. What is abundantly clear is that the existing sales tax has been paid not by the consumer but by the grape grower and the wine maker. The consumers of alcoholic beverages have, of course, paid a great amount of money to the Government. Of course, this is a matter of history.

In 1984-85 the money collected by the Commonwealth in excise on domestically produced beverages was $1,299.6m. A further $200m was collected as Customs duty on imported alcoholic beverages. It is estimated that a further $200m was collected that year as sales tax on wines and spirits. On top of that, liquor franchise fees collected by the States and the Territory in the same year amounted to $321.4m. Therefore, the tax revenue of Commonwealth, State and Territory governments raised directly from the production and sale of alcoholic beverages for the year 1984-85 was in excess of $2 billion. Overall, this represents 33 1/3 per cent of the total consumption costs of such beverages, which amounted that year to about $6,196m.

Since the repeal in 1973 by the Whitlam Government of section 31a of the Income Tax Assessment Act, Australian wine makers have paid heavy tax penalties if they have kept wines in stock for more than a year. This, of course, is an essential step, particularly in the maturation of red wine, to obtain the maximum quality-the type of quality needed to obtain export orders. I was interested today to read in the Adelaide Advertiser an article from Jill Rivers in London. The heading of the article is: `Australian wines woo the British critics and merchants'. I think one or two sentences of that article bear reading into Hansard. The article begins:
Australian wines are not only the UK's flavour of the month, but of the decade, judging by the response at the prestigious London Wine Trade Fair last month . . .
Manned by a group of 19 producers and their representatives from Down Under, plus good-looking girls in smart suits, it was run under the auspices of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation.
So this article is giving the Wine and Brandy Corporation a plug.

TALK.START.PARA: —They wouldn't have suits on in Queensland.
—No, they have meter maids there. Perhaps they ought to be sent to help the Wine and Brandy Corporation at the next London Wine Trade Fair. The article continues:

SPEECH.PARA: In the same area were the independent stands belonging to Rosemount, Lindemans, Consolidated Wineries (Berri)--
from South Australia, of course-
and agents for various other wineries such as a trio from Margaret River--
in Western Australia-
of Moss Wood, Cape Mentelle and Redgate.

Represented on the Wine and Brandy Corporation stand were McWilliams, Orlando, Wyndham Estate, Stanley, Krondorf, Mildara, Tisdall, Brown Brothers, Taltarni, Waterwheel, Campbells, Delatite, Hardys, Houghtons, De Bortoli, Wynns, Penfolds, . . . Hill Smith Estate and other agents.
Merchants and critics are now tipping Australian wine to represent better value than the French. A major drawcard is the consistent quality.
That is what we are talking about. The consistent quality of Australian wines is well known. The article continued:
A major drawcard is the consistent quality. According to the editor of leading wine journal Decanter, Tony Lord (himself an Australian)--

TALK.START.PARA: —Ah, privilege.
—It is a good name. It goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: `European bottles are frequently iffy'. He is forced into always ordering two bottles for tastings to compensate for those that are bad.
I was also interested in the reference that was made in the article to the South Australian Film Corporation. The article stated:
There was much interest in a new video made by the South Australian Film Corporation, but not many questions due to the lack of knowledge of Australian wines.

But they are winning over all who try them, according to Australian Trade Commissioner in London, Jonathon Scott. It is a matter, he says, of their being less pretentious than the French with that consistent quality. There has been a 100 p.c. increase in the UK market in the past year which proves that they have moved from curio to a permanent place on British shelves.
I would like honourable senators to note that point. The article continued:

However, credit must be given to Rosemount and Brown Brothers who have been trailblazers in the UK market. Both companies have been conducting independent operations here for the past few years and gained a wide following.

Both those companies have acted independently of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation anyway. I guess that those firms, having taken that initiative, are the elements within the industry which suggest that perhaps the Wine and Brandy Corporation ought to be confining its operations to the smaller and medium wine producers in Australia. I thought that that was an interesting newspaper article. I thought that it indicated quite clearly that Australian wines are on the up and up as far as the export area is concerned and that the Government ought to give proper regard to that. Certainly, the Government ought to resist any temptation to impose further imposts on the industry in Australia because, after all, at the moment we have to encourage exports. I believe that the export of Australian wines could contribute significantly to our balance of payments in the future.

I referred to liquor franchise fees collected by the States and Territories in the year 1984-85 being worth $321.4m. The tax revenue of Commonwealth, State and Territory governments raised directly from the production and sale of alcoholic beverages for the year 1984-85 was in excess of $2 billion. Since the repeal in 1973 by the Whitlam Government of section 31a of the Income Tax Assessment Act, Australian wine makers have paid heavy tax penalties. I want to emphasise this because of the point I made in respect of the recent London wine show. Australian winemakers are forced to hold their red wines, in particular, on their shelves for a couple of years in order to maintain the quality which of course is needed to obtain export orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a lot of spirit in your speech, Senator.

—I am glad that Senator Button recognises that. The draft White Paper entitled `Reform of the Australian Tax System' published in June 1985 proposed an inflation adjustment for trading stocks. That paper stated that it:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . would comprise an additional income tax deduction equal to the general inflation rate for the year times the opening value of stock for that year.

I trust that the Government will act on that recommendation which would address an important problem facing the makers of quality wines in Australia. At the same time I believe that the Government should keep in mind the effects of the Hawke Government's policies on the increase in imported wines. In the period 1975-76 to 1984-85 imports fluctuated between seven and 13 million litres and accounted for 2.4 to 4.2 per cent of the Australian wine market. After a significant drop in 1982-83 imports increased by 32 per cent in 1983-84 and by another 34 per cent in the 1984-85 year. More significantly, imports represented 11.3 per cent in 1983-84 and 15.6 per cent of the bottled wines market.

As a result of the 1984 Budget the competitive position of imported wine improved by 10 per cent compared with the local product. Since this change the rate of growth in wine imports has increased from 27.9 per cent in the 12 months to August 1984 to 39.7 per cent in the 12 months to May last year. Finally, it should be remembered that European Economic Community wine production and exports are supported through guaranteed minimum prices.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that a good idea?

—The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce might think so but I do not think that the wine industry would. It is also supported by exports subsidies and protection against imports. For these reasons the Opposition believes that wines imported from the EEC should be made to conform with Australian standards and all imported wines should be accompanied by certificates attesting to the same requirements currently demanded by the EEC for imports from Australia. The Minister ought to have regard to that point.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us now look at the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation as amended by this Bill. It can be said that the Government has removed many objectionable aspects of the original Corporation. The larger wineries which provide the majority of funds for the Corporation have had their levy reduced. They in turn bear the expense of promoting their wine and brandy overseas. I have demonstrated two companies which have achieved results because of their own initiative. I have said previously that the Opposition as a government would look very carefully at the record of the Wine and Brandy Corporation.

I understand that the Australian Democrats will move amendments to both the Grape Research Levy Bill and the Grape Research Levy Collection Bill. However, the Opposition will not support those amendments. We believe that the delegation of authority to exempt certain goods from levy is more practicable than taking up the time of Parliament in attempting to legislate for unforseen contingencies in the future. It is very important for the Government to recognise the significance of the wine and brandy industries to Australia and, more particularly, to the grape-growing industry which after all is the basis of those important industries. I suggest that very careful consideration be given to the fragility and viability of these industries and that in future further imposts not be imposed because of the effects they could have on the industry which can contribute significantly to our export income.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —First, through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, I would like to thank the President for supplying me with a tie to replace the one destroyed by an errant staff member. In the President's normal, kind and considerate manner he was able to do that in the twinkling of an eye.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill, the Grape Research Levy Bill, the Grape Research Levy Collection Bill, the Wine Grapes Levy Amendment Bill and the Wine Research Repeal Bill will introduce wide-ranging changes to the Australian wine and brandy industry, changes which not surprisingly have been the cause of a fair amount of controversy within the industry. The functions of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation will be changed in a variety of ways. Membership will be cut from 14 to eight. Part time members will now be appointed by a selection panel. This method is in keeping with the types of propositions that the Government put forward for a whole range of corporations and committees. The eight members will be a chairman, a government member and six others drawn from one or more of the fields of wine making, grape growing, marketing, finance, administration or business management. Changes to the method of operation and the funding of the Corporation are designed to make it more cost efficient to provide for a more even distribution of funding across levy payers. Other changes are consistent with the Government's January 1986 White Paper on the reform of statutory marketing corporations.

The Chairman of the Wine and Brandy Corporation noted in the 1984-85 annual report that there was a need to define the future role of the Corporation as uncertainties had affected its performance to date. The Chairman particularly noted that differing opinions regarding the role of the Corporation from large wine makers, co-operatives and small wineries had severely limited the Corporation's ability to perform its functions. These differences of opinion have emerged again in industry responses to the Bills which are before us tonight.

Some of the largest wine makers in Australia have expressed reservations about the legislation. They argue that the proposed restructuring will impose a financial burden on them by requiring them to fund a bureaucracy to undertake co-ordination of export promotion, regulation of exports, industry statistics collection and public relations. These larger wine makers assert that these functions are best performed by the industry itself and have pressed for the inclusion of a sunset clause in the main piece of legislation we are dealing with tonight; that is, the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Bill. However, a contrasting view is put by the Australian Winemakers Forum, which represents 210 of the small and medium independent wine companies of Australia. The AWF opposes any further amendment to the legislation and the Australian Democrats find its arguments persuasive.

In brief, the AWF's arguments are as follows: Smaller wine makers lack the resources and expertise necessary to undertake export promotion and other functions performed by the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation and support the continued existence of the Corporation to fulfil these particular roles. Furthermore, they are prepared to put their money where their mouth is. Given the peculiar disadvantages of these smaller wine makers and the problems to which they would be put and given the importance of the wine industry in export terms, its seems clear that the continued existence of the Corporation in its revamped form is essential.

The new arrangements must be monitored carefully, and if any problems reveal themselves, speedy action must and should be taken. The pair of Bills covering the grape research levy impose a levy on grapes and grape juice delivered to wineries and other processing establishments. Currently most grape research is carried out by State agricultural departments and by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. This research has been fragmented and basically the funding has been ad hoc. The April 1984 report of the inquiry into grape and wine industries noted the need for a co-ordinated research program and for a secure funding environment. The Government has responded to this inquiry and the legislation before us is obviously designed to bring grape research and funding into line with other rural industries by imposing a levy on grapes and grape juice. That has basically been welcomed by the industry with the types of reservations that I have already mentioned.

Whilst supporting the intention of the two Bills, the Australian Democrats are concerned about certain aspects of each of them arising from the report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. Clause 9 of the Grape Research Levy Bill provides exemptions from the levy. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee has drawn attention to sub-clause 9 (3) which, by permitting the regulation to exempt certain goods from the levy, might be considered an inappropriate delegation of legislative power. Although the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) provided a response to the Committee's concern, the Committee continued to express the view that Parliament should not lightly delegate its power to exempt people from the payment of a tax. Accordingly, we will be moving an amendment with regard to this provision. We believe that, while the Opposition will not support it, it is long overdue that provisions such as this, which appear time and again, should, in response to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee report, cease to appear in legislation before this chamber. We hope that when amendments are moved to remove such provisions there will be support from all parties so that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee no longer sees a need constantly to raise this point.

Similarly, the Committee has expressed concern about sub-clause 12 (2) of the Grape Research Levy Collection Bill. Although this clause is standard for such legislation, it abrogates the privilege against self-incrimination. This matter has long been of concern to this chamber in terms of reports by committees, particularly the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, on an untold amount of legislation. The Democrats again will move an amendment to resolve this problem, and again, although not supported by the Opposition, we hope that the Government might finally take heed of the points raised by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee about the way it draws up its legislation so that these issues do not have to be raised constantly in this chamber.

The fourth Bill in the package, the Wine Grapes Levy Amendment Bill, revises the levy arrangements for funding the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation by imposing a levy on wine makers for the financing of wine research. At present, proceeds from a wine grape levy, imposed by the Wine Grapes Levy Act 1979, are used to finance those functions of the Corporation. The Corporation then contributes funds to the Australian Wine Research Institute. The proposed amendments will provide for a levy to consist of two separate components-a marketing amount, which I think is particularly important, to finance the activities of the Corporation, and a research amount, which will provide the industry's contribution for wine research, the funding of which will be placed on a more secure, long term basis, as a result of these Bills, under the provisions of the Rural Industries Research Act. The final Bill in the package, the Wine Research Repeal Bill, repeals the Wine Research Act 1955 and provides for a disbursement of some $300,000 which remains to the credit of the Wine Research Trust Fund. That will now go into the new Grape and Wine Research Trust Fund and the balance will go to the Australian Wine Research Institute.

Overall, this legislative package is an important and significant step, particularly as in last year's Budget a tax was imposed on the wine industry. As honourable senators will remember, the Opposition parties supported the Government in bringing in that tax. The Australian Democrats' amendment, which would have ameliorated the tax at that point and spread it over a much longer period to allow the industry time to adjust, was not acceptable to the Opposition parties. Hence we have found the wine industry in some considerable difficulty in attempting to adjust all at once to a fairly large impost. The problems are still reverberating throughout the industry as a result of that tax. It is a pity that the Opposition parties would not support our amendment because it would have enabled a much more sensible and realistic adjustment to the imposition of that tax. It would have spread it over time and cushioned the blow, enabling the industry to adjust at a steadier and more predictable pace. However, that was not to be. For whatever reasons, that imposition of the tax in one hit was supported by the Opposition parties.

The Government has now moved in a significant way, as I have said, to reorganise that part of the industry which is dependent upon government legislation. As the previous speaker said, it is absolutely vital that the Australian industry maintains its current high standards. To enable it to do this, the Government has sought, through these Bills, to provide that predictability and stability of funding. That will be an enormous boost in the short and longer terms to the industry. In hindsight, I think it is probably a pity that particular move was not made before. The Government is to be congratulated on making that move now and on putting the industry on that firmer basis in terms of its research capacities. As always, research will lead to greater rewards, and future developments will improve the quality of the product and the efficiency of the industry.

As Senator Jessop has already told us tonight, market opportunities overseas are currently excellent for our wines. Those markets remain to be exploited by better promotion, better advertising and wider distribution. This is particularly important at a time when there is uncertainty within the world wine market, and I think there are openings for Australian wines in a number of markets in which we have not yet had any reasonable penetration. The unpredictability in the market will remain, without a doubt, but I think that with a good product and with rigorous promotion our industry certainly can compete with any in the world.

I think it is worth mentioning in this debate the contribution to the Australian economy by the wine industry because its contribution is quite significant for what most people in Australia, and I think outside Australia, consider is a relatively small industry. It employs directly over 6,000 people, mostly in regional areas where it is vitally important to the health of those regions that this industry remains healthy. It is directly responsible for the creation of additional thousands of downstream jobs in supporting industries. It contributes to the economy $18.8m in foreign exchange earnings alone, and the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) earlier tonight drew attention to the vital importance to our economy of those industries which are earning overseas exchange. It also pays in direct Commonwealth taxes and charges in excess of $105m a year and it pays over $74.4m annually in wages and salaries.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does alcohol abuse cost Australia each year?

—Wine exports have increased by 70 per cent in the years from 1978-79 to 1983-84 and our wineries attract significant numbers of overseas visitors, thus boosting tourism. Senator Crichton-Browne has just raised the other side-alcohol abuse. That must be fairly faced when discussing any of these industries. Later this week we will be debating the tobacco industry, where again we have to look at the detrimental costs. There are costs to the community in these types of industries in terms of alcohol and tobacco abuse. As senators and as parents, we are aware of the significant problems that many young people have in these areas. I admit that I have had some misgivings in terms of some of the types of advertising I have seen in this area which promote and encourage young people to consume alcohol as if it were a normal part of the enjoyment of their lives and a normal part of other types of activities they may wish to enjoy.

SPEECH.PARA: Wine is probably one area in which there has been significantly less alcoholic abuse than has been caused by the consumption of beer and spirits. That is part of the image that wine has in the way in which it has been treated in general within the community. I thank Senator Crichton-Browne for his intervention, because it is an important point to remember when we are talking about the good aspects of the industry. There are, as in a whole range of industries that assist the economy, some detrimental effects, and we must always be on our guard to try to lessen such effects in any industry in our economy.

Quite clearly, policies in this area must support the domestic market and improve our international competitiveness. In general this policy package brought forward by the Government has those aims, and I congratulate the Government yet again in this area. It is tackling difficult problems and, in consultation with the industry, is coming up with what might not necessarily be a consensus package, but one which can generally be accepted by the industry, with some significant groups still standing outside and voicing a dissenting opinion.

The general wine industry's approval for these provisions is reasonably well known to those senators who have had an interest in this group of Bills as they have progressed through the Parliament. With the exception of the amendments which I will be moving and which arise from the Scrutiny of Bills Committee process, the Australian Democrats applaud this package, support it, and hope that its intended objectives will be achieved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is particularly pleasant to follow two thoughtful contributions to this debate on the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill and allied Bills, even though there are some elements in Senator Macklin's speech I do not entirely support. It is proper that an industry as important as the Australian wine and brandy producing industry should receive this kind of thorough attention. Although I support the Opposition's view that the Bills should not be opposed, what concerns me is the general question of industries running the risk of losing influence or control over their own affairs because of the intervention of government- sponsored, government-controlled, or government-regulated bodies. Before any industry is subjected to this kind of control, the costs and benefits have to be closely weighed.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Macklin in particular took the strong view, following his examination of the industry, that the interests of the small producers who make up the Australian Wine Makers Forum should be paramount. That raises a serious dilemma for those who might be concerned about the welfare of the Australian wine industry and its economic impact as a whole. Although I very much support the activities of the Forum under its very able chairman Mr Brian Croser of Petaluma-and he and his company are renowned in the wine industry, particularly on the basis of quality-and endorse the Forum's efforts, what is of major concern is that there is a real risk that, by looking after the small producers, one damages the larger ones and the industry as a whole. This is the balance that has to be reached in looking at this kind of legislation. I have a letter that has been sent to me by Lindeman (Holdings) Limited, a major producer, a company that is particularly hostile about this whole matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, they are diametrically opposed, and you can only support one.

—As the honourable senator says, they have diametrically opposed interests, and the big question in examining legislation of this kind is what is in Australia's best interests. I am inclined to the view that Australia's best interests tend to coincide with those of the bulk of the industry. Now one must decide what is the bulk of the industry-and perhaps one should not use the word `bulk' when talking about wine. Lindeman (Holdings) Ltd wrote to me saying:

SPEECH.PARA: The restructuring of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation will involve no cost to the Commonwealth. It will however perpetuate an iniquitous financial burden on Australia's wine industry. The AWBC is funded solely by a compulsory levy on Australian wine producers. The levy is calculated on the tonnes of grapes crushed.

The letter quite properly points out that there is significant opposition among wine producers to the Corporation. It also shows that a recent survey conducted by an independent firm of chartered accountants found that wine producers who accounted for 58 per cent of domestic Australian wine sales and 74 per cent of wine exports opposed the continuation of the Corporation. Clearly that is the majority in terms of production. Producers who accounted for only 6 1/2 per cent of domestic wine sales and 9 per cent of exports supported the continuation of the Corporation. So here we have a very small minority in terms of output who want this Corporation to proceed. The representatives of Lindemans claim that the Corporation has proved to be ineffective in achieving its objectives and is simply not wanted by those producers who, through the levy, supply the bulk of its funds. The Bill before us means that the wine industry will be forced to continue to fund an expensive bureaucracy to undertake the following four tasks--

TALK.START.PARA: —But Lindemans does not supply the bulk of funds unfortunately. I know the letter says that it does but it does not.

—Well, certainly Lindemans claims that it does, and I have another letter here which I will produce later which supports that. I find it hard to believe that Lindemans would deliberately set out to mislead me or the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The industry will have to fund the co-ordination of export promotion, intelligence and strategy. Clearly there is a real need for sensible support of exports, but the big question is how one goes about it. One certainly should not have the sort of system which allows ridiculous abuses that occurred under previous arrangements. On the other hand, one must have something that is related to performance. I am not convinced that the way in which we are going about it is the right way in this case. Lindemans suggests that it would best be undertaken by companies acting individually or as a voluntary group. The Corporation is not empowered to fund overseas export drives; these must be paid for by individual companies on a user-pays basis. The cost of this would be on top of the levy that has to be paid to the Corporation. As Lindemans points out, the export of wine is a purely commercial activity and therefore it is unjust to expect a compulsory levy of one company to support the commercial activities of another. I must say that I find that a fairly persuasive argument.

The second function of the corporation is the regulation of exports. Lindemans says that decisions on whether a wine is sound and merchantable are best taken by the overseas buyer. Thus there is no need for an expensive bureaucracy to intercede. Specific regulations required by the European Economic Community can be met by the Export Control Act. That is an acceptable position from Lindemans. Thirdly, there is the function of industry statistics collection. Well-established and accepted data is already collected by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the Department of Primary Industry and the Bureau of Agricultural Economics and, according to Lindemans, additional data is not needed. My view is that there is some information that could be usefully collected in addition. The fourth point is the question of public relations and media servicing. Lindemans says that comments on industry matters are best undertaken by industry associations, not by bureaucracies. For example, it is inappropriate for a statutory authority to comment on government policy.

Despite all this, the Corporation will be perpetuated by the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill. What Lindemans has sought is what the great bulk of the industry has supported-that is, the insertion of a sunset clause into the Bill to ensure an independent and thorough review of the Corporation's effectiveness within five years. Lindemans demonstrates this question of who is benefiting and who is paying the bill by pointing out that something like 30 per cent of wineries in Australia produce about 0.2 per cent of the total grape crush or less. I remind Senator Macklin that that means that 119 wineries-or 30 per cent-pay no levy whatsoever.

The great bulk of those people in 119 wineries would in fact be in the Forum which Brian Croser leads. Another 220 wineries, making up about 10 per cent of the crush and representing about two-thirds of the wineries in Australia, will end up paying about 10 per cent of the levy. This leaves only 41 wineries, which have about 90 per cent of the crush, to pay about 90 per cent of the levy. Despite Senator Macklin's earlier intervention, it is clear from that that the great bulk of the levy-90 per cent of the levy-is to be paid by 11 per cent of the wineries. I would be interested to know whether Senator Macklin could at some later stage outline why in fact the points that Lindemans has made and which are set out in the documents to which I have been referring, are in fact inaccurate.
