On top of what Lindemans complained about, the Australian Wine and Brandy Producers Association, which encompasses a great range of producers both large and small, as well as requesting a sunset clause-I must say that I join with my fellow Opposition senators, such as Senator Jessop of South Australia, in expressing interest in that suggestion, and I am glad he mentioned it is also seeking support for the self-help, user pay principle in relation to export activities, export promotion and promotions at the national level. The Association fears that the word `control' used in relation to the export of grape products from Australia is not an acceptable one. It proposes that the word `control' should be replaced by the word `regulated' and I think there is something to be said for that. The Association also says that the increased costs of the proposed statutory levy plus the wine research levy and the proposed grape research levy is a matter of great concern to the industry, and I find that an acceptable proposition. In a letter to the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), the Association said:

The proposal to exclude Presidents and members of the executive of nationally represented winemaker organisations to which the Corporation is to be directly accountable to be ineligible for appointment as Corporation members, is discriminatory and restrictive and such prohibition should be removed to allow for an open, democratic choice for the most suitable and qualified persons.

Unfortunately, the Minister has chosen not to take any notice of the points that were made. The Association also wants increased industry representation on statutory authorities and government committees. The Association says that the fact that persons within the Australian wine and brandy producing industry will not have the majority representation on these bodies is a question of deep concern to the industry, as the simplistic interpretation of that intent is that persons from within the industry may no longer be in the position to determine the destiny of their industry. The Association stated:
It is therefore earnestly requested that our industry representation on the above committees be reviewed and increased.
It also stated:

You would well realise and understand, that within our Australian wine and brandy producing industry, it is difficult and at times impossible to arrive at a consensus of opinion which pleases all industry members, or in fact has the support of all those industry members, not unlike the function and operation of governments. Our Australian wine and brandy producing industry is complex, made up of numerous corporate structures and as time progresses, trading becomes more difficult and with that comes additional pressures. It is not an easy task of a national industry organisation to please all industry members all the time.

Nevertheless, this body in fact seeks, and has properly sought, things from this Minister which the Government has failed to provide. So this is certainly a reservation that I have about accepting and supporting this proposal. The last point I want to make about this matter is that Mr Bob Hardy, the President of the Australian Wine and Brandy Producers Association, sent a telex to Mr Kerin in which he made some other points which I think are quite worth while. He said:

Firstly we would like to make it clear that despite the impression conveyed in your second reading of the AWBC Amendment Bill, not just large producers, but small and medium sized wine producers have expressed concern regarding the continuation of the Corporation and its involvement in export activities as confirmed in a recent confidential industry survey conducted by KMG Hungerfords.
I have given the outline of that report. He also said:

We welcome the inclusion of an annual general meeting of the Corporation but point out that attendance at the AGM is restricted and the industry views expressed at the meeting need not be acted upon by the Corporation.
One wonders why such a meeting is held if the Corporation does not have to take any notice of its constituent bodies.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did mention that when in government the Opposition would be carefully monitoring the Corporation with the object of reviewing that legislation.

—The point is well made that in government we would clearly take the view that it would be essential to monitor the legislation. I think even Senator Macklin agreed that there was a need to monitor it. It does not necessarily appear to be the best legislation that we could have. We will certainly be monitoring it, and in government we would make certain that it operated properly. With all those reservations and concerns expressed by the industry, I have to concede that at this stage the only thing that we can effectively do is to undertake to monitor this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I mention in passing that I thought it was a little unreasonable of Senator Macklin to castigate the Opposition for having failed to support his amendment relating to the wine tax. I remind the honourable senator that the Opposition opposed the wine tax. We were never in support of it, and the fact that we did not support his amendment does not diminish in any way the reality that we opposed that tax on wine. Having raised the question of tax, I wish to mention in conclusion that every year the Australian Brewers Association mounts an elaborate and costly campaign during the pre-Budget period in which it urges that taxes on wine be increased in the interest of equity. However, imposts on wine will not turn drinkers to beer. Wine and beer are consumed under entirely different circumstances, with wine principally accompanying meals. It is in terms of equity, however, that the brewers' case loses its validity. I ask honourable senators to consider the following differences: Wine, by law, is made from 100 per cent grape juice. It is a primary product, but beer is 96 per cent water. Beer stocks are turned over about 24 times a year. The average turnover for wine stocks is once every 1.2 years. There would be even fewer stock turns if wine makers were not forced to pay a tax penalty on aging wines. Wine can be made only once a year, immediately after a brief vintage period when the maker must determine his precise requirements. Similarly, his costly plant is used only for a short period each year; the brewer, on the other hand, can buy his raw materials at any time of the year and can regulate his production according to seasonal demand.

The beer industry is dominated by two major companies, located in urban areas, but there are some 400 wineries, large and small, scattered throughout Australia, mainly in country districts. The semi-monopolistic brewing industry can impose strict trading terms on purchasers, and seven-day payment is standard; the wine maker, on the other hand, is rarely paid in less than 60 days. The brewers' cash flow benefits are immense. They include the handling by two major companies of an estimated $1.2 billion in excise revenue for the Government-that is almost $24m a week. The interest the brewers earn in the money market would be substantially more than the total turnover of the Australian wine industry.

I have mentioned those points because it seems to me that at times the wine industry is regarded by governments as a bit of a fall guy and is certainly subjected to unfair pressure. I restate the point that, while I have reservations about the manner in which this legislation will work, the Opposition will not oppose it, but it will certainly monitor it very closely. In my view, it does not necessarily serve the interests of the industry as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity of the debate on the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill 1986, the Grape Research Levy Bill 1986, the Grape Research Levy Collection Bill 1986, the Wine Grapes Levy Amendment Bill 1986 and the Wine Research Repeal Bill 1986 to draw attention to the state of the industry in Australia and, in particular, to highlight some of the real problems that are emerging in the industry. I think it is salutary to note that this year the actual crush of grapes in the wine industry amounted to some 495,000 tonnes. This compares with the figure for the previous year of some 590,000 tonnes. So there has been a fall of some 95,000 tonnes in the crush of grapes this year. Obviously, there will still be some draw-down from surplus stocks to meet sales obligations, but the trend is becoming very evident that the grape growing industries are under a great deal of pressure as the demand for wine falls.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, employment in the industry is well down compared with the situation a year ago. The latest figures provided to me show that, compared with the situation a year ago, when some 6,000 people were directly employed by the wine and brandy industries, today there are just over 5,000 employees. So on some calculations there has been a drop of nearly 15 per cent in employment in the industry. We have to consider why this is occurring. Certainly members of the Opposition, including my colleague Senator Jessop from South Australia, and other South Australian senators, have been drawing the Government's attention to the problems and dangers involved in the introduction of its tax on wine back in 1984, and there have been other changes in the industry.

It becomes clearer every day that both employment and the crush of grapes are falling as a result of the Government's measures. We recall, in South Australia, the way in which the Government broke another election promise and introduced a wine tax in the 1984 Budget. The statistics for the period from September 1984 until March 1986 show that the average retail price of wine has risen by only 6.5 per cent. That compared with an increase in the consumer price index figure for the same period of some 12.3 per cent. So the price of wine has been increasing at only about half the rate of the normal cost of living increase for all other products and services. The industry has been forced to absorb the cost of the 10 per cent sales tax imposed at the wholesale level in 1984.

An obvious profitability problem and a lack of investment in the industry have followed the absorption of the sales tax, which means that the industry has become less viable. That has been demonstrated very clearly by the initiation of the Government's vine pull scheme. So many growers have wanted to get involved in the vine pull scheme that the Government has had to provide extra money to fund the scheme. I understand that the total cost of the scheme is now $5.25m in assistance to grape growers. This compares to the figure of about $2.4m approved only last December. So unprepared was the Federal Government for the reception of its vine pull scheme that apparently it had to top up the scheme by pulling $2.85m out of the Victorian dried fruits industry vine pull scheme to fund grape growers in the wine industry.

Clearly there is a tremendous surge of demand by growers to enter into this scheme whereby they can pull out their vines, replant with other trees or whatever, and get themselves out of the wine industry. That surely does not sound like an industry that is progressing. The wine industry and the brandy industry, which are integrally related, and the grape growing industry are under a great deal of threat as a result of this Government's wine tax, which was introduced in 1984. The chickens are now coming home to roost in the wine industry, and, to mix a metaphor, the fact is that this Government will have to pay the piper. It seems absolutely incredible that the Government should encourage the demise of an industry such as the wine industry by the imposition of new taxes, such as those that were imposed in 1984, and then turn around and subsidise people to get out of the industry at further costs to the Commonwealth and to the taxpayer. That is precisely what is happening as a result of the Government's introduction of this tax measure.

That, clearly, has a grain of stupidity in it, and we on this side of the chamber have been raising those issues on behalf of the wine growers; and the grape growers of South Australia, and the whole Commonwealth, in recent times. Having brought that to the attention of the Government, we just hope that the Government, in its straitened circumstances at the moment, will not turn around and impose a tax increase on the wine industry as a result of what it has perceived to be only very minimal effects on the industry. Clearly, the effects on the industry so far have been very great. If the Government proceeds with increased taxes, such as a doubling of the present sales tax rate, it can expect vast and greater problems of a social nature, as well as economic ones, to visit it in the future. Clearly, these new taxes will have uneven effects insofar as those industries which are forced to suffer as a result are concerned, and this will mean that regional areas will be affected. We know, of course, of the Riverland area of South Australia and its heavy dependence on the grape growing industry. We know of the Barossa Valley, the McLaren Vale districts and other districts in the south-east of South Australia that are all dependent on grape growing. Those districts will all be affected as a result of any increased tax that might be applied by this Government.

The Government has spent a great deal of time, in this chamber in particular, telling us how the industry has absorbed these taxes. Sure, it has absorbed them, but it has also shed 1,000 jobs in doing so. It is also taking far fewer grapes from grape growers than it did last year as a result, and, of course, we now face the imposition of a further tax that can only reduce the capacity of the industry to survive, remain viable, employ people and keep towns and regional areas going.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —No arguments of substance have been raised in the second reading debate which have any real relevance to the legislation. A couple of amendments are to be moved by the Australian Democrats later, about which I will speak in the Committee stage; but I want to make some brief comments on some of the nonsense that has been pouring out of the mouths of Senator Messner and Senator Michael Baume. Senator Baume put forward yet again the spurious argument that wine is an innately high cost product compared to its competing products, principally beer; therefore, the Government should design and apply a tax system which compensates the wine industry for its innate cost disadvantages. That, of course, is further confirmation of the fact that the Tories do not understand and never have understood the ethos or logic of the market economy in which they profess to believe. I should offer to make some arrangements, if I can, to get their former colleague, John Hyde, to give them some tutorials on the ethos and logic of a market economy since, very clearly, they conspicuously fail to understand either of them.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Michael Baume, who presents himself as a sometime economic rationalist and a supporter of deregulation, put forward this spurious argument tonight in which, far from being an economic rationalist and an advocate of deregulation, he sees himself as a social and economic engineer who will insist that government policies be applied in a way that compensates particular industries for their innate cost disadvantages. I wonder why he does not extend that a bit and say that we should being back the hansom-cabs because they are innately cost disadvantaged vis-a-vis the motor car for hire transport within urban areas. Of course, the trouble with members of the Opposition is that they are lobbyists and have always been lobbyists for every vested interest group that wants to sponge on the community in general. The fatal flaw that they displayed in government was the combination of intellectual mediocrity and political cowardice which precluded them from ever implementing policies compatible with their free enterprise rhetoric.

Finally, Opposition members are also wrong about the facts. On the issue of the taxation of wine, which is still taxed at a very highly concessional rate, when this Government grasped the nettle that assorted cowardly and mediocre Tory governments over several decades had failed to grasp, and made a movement towards restoring something closer to neutrality in the taxing of alcoholic beverages by imposing a sales tax on wine in 1984, the Opposition-Senator Jessop, Senator Messner, and various others whom I do not specifically recall-asserted that, as a result of that tax, there would be a 14 per cent decline in wine sales. Of course, that has not happened. In fact, wine sales have increased since then, so their analyses of market consequences are as flawed and as incompetent as their attempts to analyse and understand the underlying philosophy of the policy that they advocated. I do not propose to speak any further. The Government will not accept the requests and the amendment of which the Australian Democrats have given notice, for reasons which I will explain at the Committee stage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: GRAPE RESEARCH LEVY BILL 1986
That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments:
(1) Page 2, clause 9, leave out sub-clause (3).
(2) Page 3, sub-clause 10 (1), leave out `sub-sections 7 (2) and 9 (3)', insert: `sub-section 7 (2)'.
GRAPE RESEARCH LEVY COLLECTION BILL 1986
Page 6, clause 12, leave out sub-clause (2), insert the following sub-clause:

`(2) For the purposes of sub-section (1), it is a reasonable excuse for a person to refuse or fail to submit a return or information that the return or information might tend to incriminate that person.'.
I do not propose to speak to the requests and the amendment since I gave the reasons for them in my speech at the second reading stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not deal with these matters at the second reading stage so, very briefly, I just want to put the Government's view on the record. The requested amendments to the Grape Research Levy Bill that Senator Macklin has moved would have the effect of removing the power of the Minister for Primary Industry by regulation to exempt certain growers from a research levy if the product they were producing derived no advantages from the research. The Government believes that this provision should stay in the legislation. It is one which in the first instance would be activated by the Minister but in respect of which either House of the Parliament would have the power to disallow a regulation. The alternative would be the more cumbersome, time-consuming and resources-consuming alternative of amending the legislation itself if at some future time the present Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) or some future Minister saw a valid reason for exempting certain producers from the levy. So the Parliament retains control to disallow regulations which this Minister or some future Minister may issue. The Bill as originally presented facilitates that course of action being taken, should any Minister believe it to be justified.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment to the Grape Research Levy Collection Bill relates to the self-incrimination provisions. I am advised that equivalent provisions to those which are contained in this Bill, and which the Australian Democrats seek to remove, already appear in a wide range of Commonwealth laws. The Minister, Mr Kerin, is aware that the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has asked the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) to consider revising the customary form of the provision with a view to strengthening the protection against self-incrimination; thus that matter is in a general sense already under consideration and will be looked at in the broader context.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I noted that the Minister, during his summary of the second reading debate, suggested that the Opposition displayed intellectual mediocrity and political cowardice with respect to these measures. I thought he could have been referring to the economic statement to the nation by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) earlier this evening. I say to the Minister that we on this side were very anxious that the Government should monitor the activities of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation. We suggested that there was some merit in inserting a sunset clause to re-examine the operation of that Corporation after five years and that in government we would very carefully monitor the operation of the Wine and Brandy Corporation, in view of the comments that have been made by the industry. I thought the reference by the Minister to the Opposition was inappropriate and could well be applied to Mr Hawke who, I am sure, rolled the Minister and Senator Button in the Cabinet recently.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment and requests (Senator Macklin's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bills agreed to.
Bills reported without amendment or requests; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills (on motion by Senator Walsh) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTURE TAX COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1986[COGNATE BILL:AIR NAVIGATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 May, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak to the Departure Tax Collection Amendment Bill 1986 and the Air Navigation Amendment Bill 1986. Considering the clock, the calendar and one thing and another, I will be as brief as I can. The coalition introduced the departure tax in 1978 and charged a fee of $10. This was increased in 1981 to $20. I have always believed that it is inappropriate for the responsibility for the departure tax to be under the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. The transfer to the Department of Aviation is very sensible. I certainly concur with the treatment of funds coming from it as part of the cost recovery program under the Department of Aviation. There is no doubt that the airlines are in the best position to collect the fee. I fully understand the desirability of having an off-airport collection system. I see the problems that go with this. As we progress we will find that it will become virtually universal for people to pay either when they purchase their ticket or at the point of departure. There really will not be much room for payment at other places, although this has been canvassed by the industry and has been given some consideration by the Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris).

SPEECH.PARA: Fifty-four per cent of all tickets are actually sold outside Australia. Of those sold in Australia the majority are sold by the airlines, not agents. The move to have an exit tax payable by the purchase of stamps at post offices has some attraction but I cannot see it becoming a very large business. The airlines accept the fact that it is logical that they should collect the money. They accept that for an amount of about $1m which Consolidated Revenue would gather extra to the present $48.5m it is worthwhile-as I do. Between 2 million and 2.5 million passengers leave Australia annually. Hopefully the figure will increase. I hope that it will not increase just because Australia becomes the cheapest destination in the world due to its plunging currency. I do believe that we still should be a very attractive destination for tourists for a long time to come.

I made reference to the fact that there had been communication with the Minister over the alternatives, and I have copies of correspondence to that effect. I raise this matter now because the Minister made certain statements that I think are important. The communication was between the Secretary of the Airline Operators Committee and the Minister and it started with a letter dated 30 April. The Committee put to the Minister that in view of unplanned lightning stoppages and so on there were various difficulties that could be overcome, and it mentioned the degree of those difficulties. A total of 17 flights and 4,385 passengers were delayed, 13 of the passengers actually missing their planes. The letter then pressed the point about providing departure stamps at all post offices. The Minister responded in a letter dated 27 May:
You may not be aware that I recently advised BAR that I was agreeable to the airline using the existing tax booths at airports from 1 July to 30 September . . .

Included in the BAR's proposal is the suggestion that departure tax stamps be made available at a wide range of off-airport outlets, and consideration is currently being given by the Government to the BAR proposals, with a view to speedy settlement of these questions.

As of today, there had been no indication from the Minister that he was giving this matter speedy consideration. I hope that the Minister tonight will be able to indicate to us how speedy this consideration is or whether the decision in the negative is likely to come down about a day after the Bill is passed. I hope that, if there is bad news, we get it and, if it is good news, we might be prepared to wait for it.

The second Bill, the Air Navigation Amendment Bill, enables Australia to ratify a 1984 amendment to the Convention on International Civil Aviation. It will allow the provisions of this new aviation protocol to be given effect in Australian law by proclamation. The impetus for the Bill arose from the shooting down of a Korean Airlines Boeing airliner in September 1983. The famous flight, the KAL-007, as honourable senators will recall, strayed off course, was in Russian air space, and was shot down intentionally.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was intentionally off course.

—I hear my colleague Senator Sanders say that it was intentionally off course, as it was intentionally shot down. It was probably one of the most cold-blooded acts of murder that the world has seen in recent times. In all, 269 innocent people lost their lives as a result, five of whom were Australian citizens. That probably does not worry Senator Sanders either, but it worries me. The Russians claimed that they were not to blame, that the Korean jet should not have been there and various things like that, but it did not change the problem and it did not change the end result. The world unanimously rejected the Russian statements and Australia, for its part, announced sanctions against Aeroflot. The sanctions were possibly a little empty in that Aeroflot does not operate in Australia, but we announced sanctions just the same.

SPEECH.PARA: However, of far more value was the action taken by the International Civil Aviation Organisation. It convened in May 1984 in an extraordinary assembly in Montreal to discuss ways of preventing any recurrence. Australia was involved in these discussions, which resulted in a unanimous decision of 107 nations to amend the original Chicago Convention on Civil Aviation. Basically, the amendment requires the signatory states to refrain from the use of weapons against civil aircraft. At this stage, it is a little disappointing that only 22 countries, I think, have so far demonstrated their goodwill by ratifying the amendment. The amendment to the Convention is embodied in this Bill, making Australia one of those nations leading the way in this important international initiative. Also included in the Bill are provisions relating to the rights and obligations of pilots of civilian aircraft.

The Bill has the full support of the Opposition. We recognise that captains of civilian aircraft have a duty not to stray into unauthorised air space, but, like the Government, we recognise that the use of weapons in such cases is not a reasonable nor a civilised reaction. Qantas Airways Ltd would especially be interested in seeing the amended Convention rigorously enforced around the World. Our international flag carrier regularly flies through the Middle East, which is undoubtedly one of the more hostile parts of the world, with the Iran-Iraq war, with the Libyan Gaddafi lunatic, and the Palestinian terror groups, all of which add to the risk of the area. It is, therefore, gratifying that Australia is taking a lead in these matters and it is hoped that all Convention signatories will join it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support both the Departure Tax Collection Amendment Bill 1986 and the Air Navigation Amendment Bill 1986. The first Bill provides for a method of shifting the responsibility for the collection of the departure tax from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to the airlines. It also makes funds available as attributable revenue. According to the figures we have, there is a $170m shortfall per year on the costs attributable to aviation over the income. The departure tax, which will now be part of the attributed revenue, will bring in $48m a year, thus decreasing somewhat the pressure on the airlines and on general aviation to maintain our very expensive Department of Aviation system. The airlines are geared for the collection of this money and can do it with very little added inconvenience. I believe that this will also benefit the traveller. No longer will he have to stand around with a $20 bill in his hand-or retain a $20 bill in Australian currency-when going overseas to pay to the tax man. This will be taken out of the ticket receipts by the airlines.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue of cost recovery in the aviation industry is quite contentious. A number of people are concerned about the way in which the Federal Government is intent on raising revenue by attributing costs to aviation. I have here a letter from the municipality of King Island, which is quite concerned about cost recovery programs. This is a letter to the Minister for Transport and Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) from the Council at King Island. It reads:
Dear Sir,

The King Island Council wish to strongly object to the introduction of the new Aviation Cost Recovery system that is due to start from July 1st, 1986. As the Minister should be well aware the imposition of a further charge on our airfares and freight charges, which the airlines have no choice but to increase, would further disadvantage residents of this Island.

No doubt the philosophy behind the Government's Total Cost Recovery Scheme is that air is a luxury form of travel, not to be subsidised by the taxpayer's dollar and those who cannot afford it could travel by cheaper means i.e. by road or rail transport which are subsidised. Surely this is not applicable in a community such as ours where we have no alternative means of transport. King Islanders are totally dependent on air transport for passengers and consumer perishables (foodstuffs etc.) and are already greatly disadvantaged by this.

The proposed increases in aviation costs would initially force return passenger air services, to and from King Island, upwards of between $6 and $7, nowhere near the 50 cents per passenger as stated in the press on Saturday 31st May, 1986.
Airlines of Tasmania were subsidised by the State Government two years ago for $300,000 and the imposition of further costs must put the future of our Island's air services further at risk.
The Council implores the Federal Government not to go ahead with this, and concludes:

Council therefore request that the Minister exempt the Bass Strait Islands from Total Aviation Cost Recovery for reasons already outlined, in order that our island residents, whose only means of travel, already very expensive, should not be disadvantaged further.

All air travellers in Australia are disadvantaged by the cost recovery program pursued by this Government. Aviation in this country benefits all society and I think that all society should share in the cost. After all, the cost of railways is borne by the taxpayers, as are the costs of roads, hospitals and police, which are all services which benefit us. Aviation is an essential service as well, but, as the people on King Island have noted, aviation seems to be considered the province of the rich-a luxury. It is not; it is a necessity, especially in a country like Australia.

The Department of Aviation has been asked, in return for attributing costs, to reduce its staff. It has taken a step in this direction, but much more needs to be done. The bureaucracy is huge in the Department of Aviation. Even though there have been some cuts, there are still six times as many bureaucrats or employees per aircraft in the Department of Aviation as there are in the United States of America Federal Aviation Administration. Higher numbers of employees have been generated, but this is not a reasonable number because there are far too many bureaucrats per aeroplane. How can we save money? Certainly we do not want to decrease safety, but in the United States, where they have far higher aircraft densities, the Administration has worked out systems for controlling aircraft which are not unsafe but which are far cheaper and far less labour and equipment intensive than are the systems in this country.

I have here a chart from the Los Angeles area where I used to fly. This is a visual flight rules terminal area chart which shows a number of very important things. The control zones, even for Los Angeles International Airport, are only 10 miles in diameter. That means that, when one is outside that control zone, one does not need to be controlled by a control tower operator. All that equipment is not needed. A pilot does not need to be under radar control. This is a direct saving.

In Hobart, an airport which has some 8,000 movements a year, the control zone is 50 miles in diameter, whereas it is 10 miles in diameter in Los Angeles International Airport. Of course, this drives up the costs. Another point is the way in Australia that the Department of Aviation grabs all airspace in a control zone and controls it as if all aircraft are flying under instrument conditions, even in visual conditions. In the United States the Department there does grab great masses of airspace, but only in instrument conditions. In VFR conditions it is not controlled airspace.

Another interesting point that I think would move traffic around our more densely populated areas is that there are corridors where general aviation aircraft can fly directly over the middle of Los Angeles International Airport, with no radio contact with anybody. This is not unsafe because at that airport all the jet traffic is on the ground; therefore, one can fly overhead in perfect safety. In fact, it is necessary to have these corridors because otherwise the authorities simply could not move the aircraft that they do. I can hear mutterings that this is unsafe and that there will be air collisions. True, there was a collision between a light plane and an airliner at San Diego some years ago. However, that is the only accident that I know of on the West Coast of the United States. Certainly at Santa Barbara, where I used to fly, there was a mix of aircraft from DC-10s down to J3 Cubs, all in a 10-mile radius control zone, and there was never any kind of problem with collisions. So this is one of the areas we can look at. I think it is a highly technical area, but I think people can see the logic in it and I hope that the Department of Aviation will not just reject this suggestion out of hand as the complaints of an irate pilot, but look at it as a method of helping us all to use the system more cheaply.

I turn to another item. I have in my hand my flight crew licence in Australia. Let me suggest another way we could save money. The licence is contained in a beautifully bound, hard-cover book. Every two years I ship this book to Melbourne and there is a rubber stamp put in it. I do not know how many people there are involved in opening that envelope, opening the book and putting the rubber stamp in it and returning it to me, but I suspect that it is a considerable number. On the other hand, this pasteboard card I have in my hand, a piece of paper measuring some two by one and a half inches, is my United States commercial licence. It was issued in 1958 and it is good for life. It has on it my ratings, land, sea, glider privileges, and this is all I have to have. No bookwork is involved at all. To renew this licence I take a medical, the doctor sends a copy of that medical to the FAA and the Administration files it some place but sends me nothing. The validated medical certificate is the other half of the validation for this licence, and then I go through my flight checks which are recorded in my log book. The FAA keeps its nose out of these things and thus it is far cheaper.

I turn to another item. The general aviation area, especially recreational general aviation, is constantly being pinched in the pocket by higher prices for fuel, maintenance and air navigation charges. We are constantly being asked to pay for services we do not need but are required to use by the Department of Aviation. Many of us are quite happy with dirt strips, unpaved airstrips, minimal terminal facilities and very primitive, in airline standards, nav-aids.

There should be an opportunity for people who do not want to use the full airline system to opt out of it and regulate themselves in the manner of the Gliding Federation of Australia. That Federation flies not hang-gliders but highly developed sophisticated sail planes. I am a member of the GFA, a gliding instructor, and that body regulates itself completely. The Government has no look in, and the safety record of the GFA flying those sail planes, even in controlled air space, is as good as the safety record of general aviation. One would be well justified in asking what is the value to the recreational pilot of the Department of Aviation, when a voluntary organisation like the Gliding Federation of Australia can give the same services and furnish the same safety. I see little value to the recreational pilot in the present system operated by the Department of Aviation.

The Departure Tax Collection Amendment Bill is a major step in the right direction. It brings back revenue where it is needed to fund the aviation industry. The Bill probably goes as far as it can, but there is still plenty to be done in restructuring the Department of Aviation so that all aviation users and potential users in Australia will be encouraged to use the airways rather than discouraged as they are now.

The second Bill before the Senate is the Air Navigation Amendment Bill 1986 which, as Senator Archer said, results from the shooting down of the KAL-007 airliner in September 1983. At the time I was quite perplexed about that incident because I had a good acquaintance who used to fly the United States Air Force equivalent of 707s at Russia in electronic countermeasure exercises. They would fly across the Siberian border and fly in as far as they could until the Russians turned on their radar. Then when the Russians turned on their gun radar and missile radar, the United States Air Force would plot the positions. It sounded very much like what the KAL airliner may have been doing-I had that feeling in my bones. Over the last three years I have learned a lot more about it. One of the complete analyses of the situation is contained in a book called Shoot Down written by R. W. Johnson. This book was not written by a Russian supporter at all costs or even a regular journalist. The writer, who is a fellow in politics at Magdalen College, Oxford, spent two years researching this tragedy. As honourable senators will recall, KAL-007 was on a flight from Anchorage, Alaska, to Seoul when it was shot down by a Soviet Su-15 fighter as it was leaving Soviet airspace over Sakhalin Island in the North Pacific. The standard explanation was that the aircraft was simply off course. Well, the odds against that are about the same as being hit by a meteorite, especially when one considers what actually happened. Using records of human and mechanical error on other 747s equipped with 007's navigational devices, Mr Johnson found that there was a one in 20,000 chance of any error. This was compounded by the 22:1 odds of 007 being as far off course as it was-it set a new world record in being off course. This made the odds against the aircraft merely being off course 431,200:1 against. Those are pretty high odds. I would not know anyone who would want to take on odds like that. If one adds to that the eight individual occasions on which KAL-007's crew of three experienced pilots each failed unaccountably to make normal checking procedures, one finds that long before one has finished calculating one has arrived at the sorts of odds which make even astronomers blanch-literally billions or trillions to one against.

This in itself would be enough, but there are other observations which, incredible as it now seems, have somehow managed to escape attention. For example, 007's captain made covert and highly irregular adjustments to the aircraft's weight and fuel loads before leaving Anchorage. This was consistent with taking a longer flight path than the one originally planned. Most damning of all, he left behind in Anchorage his copy of the aircraft's computerised flight plan, in the margin of which were a series of handwritten calculations corresponding almost exactly to the route over Russian air space which KAL-007 eventually accidentally took. It is well known that as KAL-007 penetrated Russian air space, the Soviets were forced to activate virtually all their radar systems between the Pacific coast and Moscow, giving the United States an unprecedented intelligence gathering bonanza. In Johnson's hypothesis, the need for such information had become urgent in the United States as a new round of SALT talks approached.

Mr Johnson suggested that what might have happened, based on 007's movements, was that when Soviet fighters eventually caught up with the jumbo at the edge of Soviet air space, 007's captain, a former top fighter pilot in the Korean Air Force, ignored their repeated radio messages and warning tracer shots. Instead he made several evasive manoeuvres in the hope of outstripping his pursuers. The Russians, recognising these as military tactics, and unable to get close enough to see that 007 was an airliner, shot it down, accordingly-less than a minute from international air space. At the time President Reagan called the Soviet action `a crime against humanity which must never be forgotten'. He went on:
What can we think of a regime that so broadly trumpets its visions of peace and global disarmament and yet so callously commits a terrorist act?
Secretary of State George Shultz declared:
The world is waiting for the Soviets to tell the truth.
Mrs Jeane Kirkpatrick staged a famous performance at a United Nations Security Council meeting with inaccurately transcribed tapes of conversations between the Soviet fighter pilots. She said:
Violence and lies are regular instruments of Soviet policy.

They may or may not be. But the evidence indicates that this airliner was intentionally off course and was off course for military purposes. In fact, the people who programmed that airliner to do that were putting innocent people's lives at risk. With the wisdom of three years hindsight it appears that both Korea and the United States were intentionally violating Soviet air space. The Russians overreacted violently-there is no doubt about that-with the resulting tragic loss of innocent passengers' lives. This legislation may not, in itself, completely prevent such tragedies. What we need is greater understanding. We need to make it unnecessary for countries to be so suspicious of one another that they will violate each other's air space and subsequently shoot down aircraft. This legislation, however, is a statement of awareness of the problem and as such it deserves our support. The Australian Democrats support both Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senators Archer and Sanders for their contributions, which ranged a little more widely than the provisions of the legislation. However, their remarks were interesting and the Government thanks them for participating in this debate. I would simply point out that comparisons with other countries can be misleading. Of course, if one wants to make comparisons, our Government has an unparalleled record in respect of aviation cost recovery. During the last two years, the Department of Aviation has reduced its staff by 700. It will have reduced its staff by 1,000 by July 1987.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind honourable senators that the provisions set out in the Departure Tax Collection Amendment Bill will improve passenger convenience, improve airport passenger flows and pass responsibility for the collection of the tax to the airlines. The Air Navigation Amendment Bill involves the ratification of a protocol of an international treaty. I commend the Bills to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 20 March, on motion by Senator Walsh:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (EDUCATION ASSISTANCE-PARTICIPATION AND EQUITY) AMENDMENT BILL 1986STATES GRANTS (SCHOOLS ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1986STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 May, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The three Bills before the Senate-the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Amendment Bill 1986, the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill 1986 and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1986-contain cost supplementation provisions for programs in schools and tertiary education institutions that have already had determined for them by the Parliament the basic financial provisions not only for this year but also, in most cases, for 1987 and 1988 as well. Each year legislation such as the Bills before us is presented to this Parliament for the purpose of providing additional moneys for programs that are already in place to take account of inflation. In the case of these three States grants Bills-one dealing with tertiary education assistance, the second dealing with the participation and equity scheme, and the third with schools assistance-the total amount of money provided for is $144m. This involves an additional $44m for schools, $98.43m for tertiary education institutions, and some $1.6m for participation and equity programs. Those amounts are calculated on formulae about which there is little controversy.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate on education matters in the Senate often relates to what financial resources are being made available to schools, to higher education, to technical and further education, to particular Commonwealth Schools Commission programs, or to participation and equity programs. Debate does not directly concern curriculum because the responsibility for curriculum is in the hands of State governments or independent schools and is determined at the State level. Similarly, the terms of employment of teachers are determined at the State level. Even the tertiary education curriculum is in the hands of independent institutions. Universities and colleges have long had autonomy in determining curricula. So tonight in the Senate we are not debating the curricula in our education institutions or the terms of employment of their staff, we are debating what public resources ought to be made available to those institutions on a continuing basis.

The principal legislation that governs the Commonwealth's provision of financial resources provides for more than annual increments. A four-year program is determined for our schools, and the legislation to cover that program has already been enacted. We determine a triennium program for higher education, and the primary legislation for that triennium has already been enacted. So we have before us three Bills which have no new policy elements and which purely and simply set out the schedules of retrospective cost supplementation. The Opposition supports the three Bills, as they are in the normal format. However, their introduction in the Senate gives us the opportunity for a general review of the financial resources that are made available to education. I want to make some general remarks on that topic as briefly and as succinctly as I can.

At the time of the August Budget education received an increase in funding of 9.4 per cent, with the appropriation of $4,943m. With the additional appropriation of $144m proposed in these Bills before us tonight, for the first time in Australian Commonwealth education outlays will exceed $5 billion. Of that $5 billion, about $2.5 billion, or half of the Commonwealth's education spending, is provided to universities and advanced education institutions. That is because 98 per cent of our universities and colleges are now provided for almost totally from the revenue of the Commonwealth Government. Another $1.75 billion is provided in the Budget for schools and pre-schools. Nearly $600m is provided for student assistance and $70m for the administration of various education schemes-$55m to the Department of Education, $10m to the Commonwealth Schools Commission, and $5m to the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission. When these various amounts are added up, the total exceeds, for the first time in Australia, $5 billion.

However, the ranking of education compared with other areas of government expenditure remains the same. Education is the sixth biggest item in government outlays after social security and welfare, which represents 27.6 per cent of the financial year's Budget; payments to the States represent 19.6 per cent; servicing of the public debt interest is a scandalous and extraordinarily high 9.7 per cent; health also represents 9.7 per cent; and defence represents 9.5 per cent. Education comes sixth, representing 7.2 per cent of government outlays. All other areas of government expenditure represent less than two per cent of total outlays, which is a rather small percentage and may involve hundreds of thousands of dollars for the administration of some important government department. The six big Budget areas, which have been in much the same order for the last 10 years in terms of Commonwealth government expenditure, are social security and welfare, payments to the States, the public debt interest, health, defence, and education.

I draw particular attention to the fact that during the last decade education spending as a proportion of government outlays has fallen from 9 per cent to 7.2 per cent. In the last three years of the Fraser Liberal Government, education spending as a percentage of government outlays was respectively 7.9, 7.9 and 7.6 per cent. For the first three years of the Hawke Labor Government, the comparative figures are 7.2 per cent, 7.1 per cent and 7.2 per cent. Overall, the percentage is on roughly the same plateau. The plateau has been a little lower under the Labor Government than it was under the Liberal Government, but there has been a plateau for at least the last six years and, in general, for the last 10 or 12 years. Education as a proportion of Commonwealth Government spending has remained about the same.

I want to concentrate some remarks on this plateau for a few minutes. There has been no radical change. The plateau continues in regard to the Commonwealth's provision for higher education, technical and further education, schools, pre-schools and student assistance programs. The exaggerated rhetoric of the Australian Labor Party when it was in opposition about devoting a much higher proportion of public resources to education has not been fulfilled. We have seen more than three years of the Hawke Labor Government. When we consider the three Bills before us tonight, which involve cost supplementation for assistance programs, we are reminded that the present Government has not lived up to anything approaching the rhetoric of its promises for education. All sorts of expectations were given to universities, colleges and schools that the election of a Labor government would lead to a radical change in the level of financial resources for education. This has not happened. The present plateau is, as I have said, a little lower than the plateau which persisted during the period of the Fraser Government.

Faced with this plateau, the question arises as to how we are to provide for increasing demands on the education system. When I read the debate in both Houses of Parliament I do not see the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) projecting getting us off this plateau, a little lower than in the period of the Liberal Government, that he is seeing his own Government locked into. The Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) does not project any change to the general level of funding in any years that may be left to the Hawke Labor Government. Even the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, the one Minister who has raised provocative proposals for reducing education provision, has not been able to convince his colleagues in Caucus or in Cabinet to go ahead with his proposals. So we do not see even a razor gang being successful against the resistance of those many members and senators who do not wish to see cuts in education.

I noticed that recent publications and journals in advanced education and university circles and amongst education unions are already starting to warn and threaten the present Government that, should there not be a real increase in the coming Budget, there will be a breaking-off of relations by those who had looked, at least prior to this Government being elected, to some better financial deal from the Government. Their rhetoric in these various newsletters and magazines is that there should not be cuts. I have not heard any expression of view in Canberra, except from a few members of parliament, towards substantial, real increases in education. I must admit that my own assessment about the plateau persisting in the public provision for education is based on the grounds of realism; it is not my personal position.

In the eight years that I have been in the Senate I have continually urged in my Party and in the Senate greater real provision for education programs. Senator Sir John Carrick, a former Minister for Education, is another who has certainly urged greater spending on education matters. Senator Macklin, who is in the chamber, has looked for increased funding. A number of us have drawn attention to the relatively lower level of provision, especially for 15- to 25-year-olds, in Australia compared with, say, Japan, the United States of America or many advanced European countries and we have made the point that investment in education at that level is an investment in human resources and an investment for the future development of Australia, and is important. So whilst I urge on my colleagues as much as on the Government a real increase in education provision, my realistic assessment is that it will take a considerable argument to move away from this $5 billion plateau of the Commonwealth Government's provision. I point out that I have urged an increase in provision on account of a number of programs in Senate reports that I have spoken about at various educational meetings around the country, which would include projects such as increased teaching resources at the years 1 and 2 levels in primary schools. Obviously, it is an important foundation area for young children to find their feet in schools and I believe that we ought to see a more concentrated resource in those two levels of primary school.

The adapting of some year 10 and 11 school programs to be vocational colleges, to meet the needs of those students aged 14, 15 and 16 who so often lose their motivation, become dispirited and even lose out in basic skills, would be of assistance. There is a cost requirement in some of the transitions of curriculum that would meet those needs. There should be some programs for in-service teacher professional development especially in specialised areas such as remedial English and mathematics. Also, for example, there should be facilities and flexible programs for gifted children.

I also urge the Government to implement a national language policy such as is set out in the recommendations of the report of the Standing Committee on Education and the Arts with which a number of honourable senators, including me, have been associated.

I would like to see increased support for the isolated children's educational programs, including direct assistance for tertiary students from remote areas so that they can have genuine access to our universities and colleges. I would also like to see greater access for all Australians, particularly adults, who wish to take up part time tertiary education, to external courses facilitated by television, radio and videotex systems linked to the Aussat satellite.

I would like to see an expansion of both pure and applied research resources, including an extension of the centres of excellence research scheme that was set up by the Fraser Liberal Government, and additional resources for the Australian research grants scheme. My list does go on but as time is short I will mention just two more priorities. One is an increase in the level of the tertiary education assistance scheme allowance so that at least it has the same value as the unemployment benefit. This increase in the TEAS allowance is an Opposition commitment which I notice that the Government has also now professed to support. We have yet to see whether in the coming Budget there is any move towards achieving any gain in that direction.

Another, and my last, example of a priority for some additional resources is a continuing real increase in funds for technical and further education, especially in terms of the capital provision of buildings, equipment and facilities for our technical and apprentice trainees. They ought to have, and be enabled to have, the same training as we enable our university professional people to have, and more recently our teachers through our teacher training programs. Why should we give a very high level of support to our doctors, engineers and teachers but not give similar enabling support to our technical trainees and apprentices? The emphasis on TAFE over the last 10 years, principally from the Fraser Liberal Government, should continue. I note that this has been taken up in the report tabled in the Senate today, the `Review of TAFE funding' by Hugh Hudson and his committee of review which looked into the future development of TAFE. He urges a continuing of the 6 per cent real increase in provisions for TAFE especially in terms of upgrading through capital for buildings and other facilities.

So in summary, whilst we seem to be locked into this plateau which has now reached $5 billion in total Commonwealth spending on education, we have a substantial list of additional programs that are still not being met. What is the way through this frustration? What is the answer to the need for these additional programs when we have, I realistically assess, a plateau in the provision of Commonwealth support. The answer to this is in three parts. The first is that I continue to urge some real increase in educational provisions in the way that I have indicated earlier. Secondly, we can change our priorities within the budget that is already established, both qualitatively and by rearrangements, to meet higher priorities. Thirdly, we can free up the constraints on our present primary, secondary and tertiary education institutions to enable resources, in addition to those from the public purse, to be applied to education.

When I look at this three-part solution, I believe that we will only see those three parts put into effect when there is a change of government. I say that because I do not see any prospect, on the first count, of there being any real increase to get us away from the plateau that the Hawke Government seems locked into. Secondly, I do not see any track record for rearranging the policies and programs that have been established. The Minister seems to spend more time trying to deny that there are any problems at any level of our education system rather than facing up to them and trying to find solutions to them. The Minister, I believe, has locked herself in to this plateau mentality as if all she can do is tack bits around the edges-a margin here, an increment there-but the system itself, in her mind, seems to be set in concrete. It is in regard to this third part of the solution, in terms of freeing constraints, that I believe there is the most need for a complete change to our approach to tertiary, secondary and primary education. Let me give an example.

TALK.START.PARA: —Spare us, for God's sake.

—I have three examples, Minister. The first concerns higher education. In Australia we have some 45 colleges of advanced education and about 19 universities. But the advanced education and university sectors have about the same number of equivalent full-time students; that is, about 140,000 each. Universities receive half as much again per student as do colleges of advanced education. This situation, whatever its partial merit, does seem to be set in concrete. There does not seem to be any prospect for change. Whatever a college of advanced education may argue as being its public merit for a course or a department, it seems banished from ever being involved in research, from ever having post-graduate students, from ever being a centre of excellence, from ever being able to acquire from the public purse an increased proportion that would meet its aspiration.

SPEECH.PARA: The bureaucracy stifles accreditation of new courses or the expansion of a department, even to meet a real need that is demonstrated by students who would enrol in a course. Any of our higher education institutions are tied hand and foot, and all of this is done on the ground that we are locked into a plateau of government provision. When we add the general state of the economy, the $5 billion deficit, the pressures to restrain government expenditure, we find that we have a government that, through its Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, all the time wants to deny that there are problems and wants to say that we cannot have additional real increases in financial provision. Therefore, we must be content with the structure as it is-with higher education divided into its binary sectors, as they are, and not allow them to be enterprising, to take initiative, to be creative, or to develop research and teaching programs that are of real benefit. Another example concerns the pressure for enrolment in higher education institutions. However many applications there may be, however many qualified persons there may be to go to our universities and colleges, the bureaucratic constraints that are on the system and the plateau of funding that is available do not allow more than a certain level of enrolments to be successful, so that many applicants are turned away from our educational institutions. The Opposition is not happy with this state of affairs and with these constraints. We are looking at options for a new freedom for our educational institutions.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Queensland Economy-Australian Capital Territory: Plumbing Trade-Fringe Benefits Taxation-Australian Government Printing Office: Industrial Dispute

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Wednesday, 28 May, I made a speech in the adjournment debate concerning the Queensland economy. In the course of that debate I used some Australian Bureau of Statistics figures. While citing those figures I added an interpretation as to those figures and put that down as a statement in the ABS figures. In the case in point this was incorrect as the interpretation was someone else's and I now wish to put the Hansard record straight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to a letter which I have received from the Master Plumbers and Sanitary Engineers Association of the Australian Capital Territory-the Association also sent this letter to other senators, to Ministers and to members of the House of Representatives-drawing attention to the deplorable situation which exists in relation to the training of plumbers in the Australian Capital Territory. In that letter the Association stated:

SPEECH.PARA: It has been brought to our attention that the proposed new facilities at Fyshwick may be deferred indefinitely.

The building at Fyshwick, which is to be an adjunct of the Canberra College of Technical and Further Education at Reid, has been completed. That building is in place. It is the building where these courses are to be taught. The letter points to the severe shortage of qualified tradesmen which exists in the Australian Capital Territory and to the possibility that a ballot system will have to be adopted to enable people to gain entry to the plumbing trade course. The Association believes that as many as 20 to 36 students may have to be turned away. The Association refers to the fact that contractors in the Australian Capital Territory are permanently forced to recruit tradesmen in New Zealand, fly them here and return them to New Zealand for holidays while there are young people in the Australian Capital Territory on the dole who would welcome the opportunity to gain apprenticeships and learn the trade and so have jobs and careers for the future.

The letter is somewhat lengthy and deals with all aspects of the problem as the Association sees it. Let us face it, the members of the Association are the people who are likely to know exactly what is going on and the exact difficulties that are being faced. They canvass the fact that the present facility was built in the early 1960s when the population of the Australian Capital Territory was less than a third of what it is today. As I said, a building is available to enable the facility to expand but somehow there do not seem to be funds to enable it to be established and start training students.

Honourable senators will be surprised to learn that when the 1986 first year apprentices reach second year the teaching program will be forced to revert to the 1954 syllabus, involving bench work only, due to safety and overcrowding concerns. Honourable senators might think, of course, that the year 1954 mentioned in the letter is a misprint, but that is not the case; it is because the present facility is so crowded that young people cannot be trained. It is incomprehensible that use of a facility available to train young people as plumbers may be deferred indefinitely. Young people in the Australian Capital Territory need opportunities to train, especially in areas in which jobs are available for them. It is hypocrisy when a Government that concentrates its efforts on make work schemes and artificial job schemes ignores the real opportunities that are available for training young people as master plumbers, gas fitters and sanitary engineers who could obtain jobs in the Australian Capital Territory. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the letter to which I have referred from the Master Plumbers and Sanitary Engineers Association of the Australian Capital Territory.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Senator Margaret Reid,
Parliament House,
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Senator Reid,
It is with serious concern we write to you to summarise the unacceptable situation with regard to the plumbing trade facilities at Canberra Technical And Further Education College, Reid, ACT.

It has been bought to our attention that the proposed new facilities at Fyshwick may be deferred indefinitely. This we believe would be an unfortunate step in the advancement of this industry in the ACT. Currently there is a severe shortage of qualified tradesmen and with the possibility of a Ballot system being adopted to gain entry to Plumbing Trade Course will only exacerbate the present circumstances. It is estimated that 20-36 students maybe turned away in the coming year.

This fact is of considerable concern when you realise that contractors are permanently being forced to recruit tradesmen in New Zealand, fly them in then return them for holidays, while Australian young people are going to be denied places to gain equivalent trade training. It makes one wonder where the Government priorities lie. The trend to recruit overseas tradesmen is likely to continue while we cannot provide well trained journeymen graduates from our own training system.

Unfortunately, there is no easy way around the situation. Short courses and other expedients are not possible as it is a statutory requirement of all Plumbers, Drainers and Gasfitters licensing authorities that journeymen plumbers must have completed an acceptable course of study i.e., a plumbing trade course.
In recent years a National Common Core Curriculum has been developed to provide a basic uniformity of training standards across the nation.

Australian Capital Territory Apprentices cannot be trained to the standard required of this Curriculum due to the complete inadequacy of the present facilities at Canberra Technical And Further Education College. The progressive decline in standards of training will only achieve a disadvantage for Australian Capital Apprentices when competing against their peers in the states.
The situation has reached the stage where block release students have to be taught in normal college stand down periods because of the severe overcrowding.

Furthermore, when the 1986 first year apprentices reach second year the teaching programme will be forced to revert to the 1954 syllabus involving bench work only due to safety and overcrowding concerns.
This has to be totally unacceptable to a government that purports to support young people and supposedly encourages the development of local industry.

In an attempt to meet the curriculum and licensing conditions students are being forced to work on training models that are within 2 feet of live electrical bus bars and light fittings. They are actually standing on platforms amongst these ceiling fillings. This is an extremely dangerous situation that cannot continue yet if they are to gain their licensing requirements these projects have to be completed.
It is a classic Catch 22 situation that will be abruptly resolved when a major accident occurs.
If it is necessary to have a serious accident to have action to alleviate a hazardous situation then this Association would not wish to be party to any such policy. It is quite unacceptable.

The facility was built in the early 1960's when the population was less than a third of what it is today. It has had one minor extension since then. Much of the equipment also dated from that era and the numbers of students have more than trebled.

Working space around machines is virtually non-existent, stores must be left on the workshop floor, power cables across the floor and some 24 students are required to work in a space that would only accommodate 12 tradesmen in industry and the numbers next year are set to increase!
The situation would be condemned in industry.
How the provisions of the Occupational Health and Safety Act will affect this area are a matter for some speculation.

The industry in the Australian Capital Territory Region is more than deeply concerned at a rapidly accelerating cost structure being forced upon it by the shortage of trained personnel while the potential apprentices to the trade are going to be turned away.
If it was not so serious it would be truely laughable when young people cannot get jobs because they cannot get the training.
Present estimates are that between 20 and 36 students will be turned away in the coming year in this one trade. We as an Association are willing and able to make our contribution.

Surely in these times of accelerating labour costs, high unemployment among the young and the governments stated policy of encouraging industrial self-sufficiency it is reasonable to expect support for those who are prepared to help.

These facts combined with the present unsatisfactory nature of the present facilities at Canberra Technical and Further Education College make an irrefutable case for the provision of at least reasonable facilities for the necessary apprentices training.
This Association believes it is imperative the facilities be commenced immediately. Any delay will only exacerbate an already unsatisfactory situation.

It is with the unanimous endorsement of this Association I seek your active and earnest support to have the funds made available to meet the reasonable requirement for training of plumbers, gasfitters and sanitary engineers in the Australian Capital Territory.
I would be pleased to discuss this most important matter with you at any time to provide further briefing.
Yours faithfully
A. MAYBURY
President

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer tonight to an advertisement which appeared in Queensland Country Life. The advertisement is headed `Oppose the Fringe Benefits Tax'. After some mischievous words it states:

SPEECH.PARA: Farmers will pay the tax themselves if they, for example,
provide wood to heat employees' homes
give employees' families a bucket of milk or a side of mutton
allow employees to service their cars in the farm workshop
and
Farmers who run their properties as a private family company will be taxed for
living in their own farmhouse
eating their homegrown vegetables, meat and milk
driving their children to catch the school bus in the farm ute
running their own generators to provide electricity for the house.
It then has the advice:
Don't fill in the form you've just received from the Taxation Department.
An example is given, which states:
An employee living on the property with his family in a home and provided with a side of mutton per week-
$ per week
Assessed value of cottage at say...
Electricity...
Gas...
Meat...
Value of fringe benefits for tax purposes...
The employer will pay $31.36 per week in fringe benefits tax, the equivalent of about 13% of the award rate for a station hand in addition to employment costs.
Worse still the $31.36 is not a tax deductible cost of employment.
That seems strange to me. I have never heard of tax being tax deductible. The advertisement goes on:
It will be paid out of the employer's after-tax income. If the employer's average tax rate is 25 per cent, this will amount to $10.45, a total cost of $41.81 per week.

I would like to ask the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) to comment on these points in the advertisement, to say whether they are correct or whether they are misleading. Perhaps he might be able to comment on the example given, assessing certain aspects at so many dollars per week. It would be helpful if the Minister could provide some information.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the advertisement in Queensland Country Life to which Senator Colston refers. It has also appeared in a number of other publications. The advertisement is not only dishonest in its presentation of the implications of the fringe benefits tax-and much of it is inaccurate-but it is also based on an assumption by Mr McLachlan, the President of the National Farmers Federation, that most farmers already deal dishonestly with the Australian Taxation Office. Perhaps he was speaking for himself on that matter-he usually does speak for himself. It is scandalous that the NFF should take farmers' money on the pretence of representing them, and in the process of purporting to represent them, actually to represent the interests of a wealthy group of rorters who have for so long avoided paying their fair share of the tax burden or, in some cases, probably pay no tax at all.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr McLachlan is behaving like a member of the old Country Party, pretending to represent the general rural interests while practising a form of politics which shows no recognition of the realities of the world in which most family farmers must do business, exploiting them for their votes but leaving them to their fate, while pursuing matters which affect the Parties in a constituency. McLachlan bases his case in the advertisement on the assumption that most farmers at this moment are cheating on their tax. His fundamental premise is that private expenses are being claimed by family companies when he knows that under the law they should not be treated for tax purposes in that way.

Mr McLachlan seems to think that all farmers are tax cheats and that their minds work the way his does. He seems to think that the family company is the tax haven. He wants to claim a deduction against taxable income for a house, a vehicle or a generator against the family company's income, but then he wants to provide those benefits to the family member who has an employee. He believes that the family member who is also an employee should escape tax but argues that the non-family employee should pay it. On this question as to who Mr McLachlan speaks for, he probably speaks for himself and a wealthy coterie of very large farmers. He certainly does not speak in this instance for the 80 per cent of Australia's farmers who do not employ permanent labour at all. In arguing that the tax should be levied on the employee, he ignores the fact that the administrative burden would still fall substantially on the employer, who would be required to provide the Taxation Office with the information and to deduct taxation at source as employers are already obliged to deduct pay as you earn taxation.

McLachlan is unperturbed by the fundamental injustice between the way he wants to treat the employee who s a member of the family and the employee who is not. He has also sought to greatly exaggerate the cost of the fringe benefits tax, in particular in respect of the employee who is not a member of the family, or the family company. First, he has tried to attribute a liability for fringe benefits tax to items which have no economic value, such as wood to heat the employee's home and the use of farm workshops to service the employee's car. Secondly, he has greatly exaggerated the value of produce, in particular meat, which might be made available to some employees in lieu of income, and he has completely ignored the $200 threshold which applies to the minimum value of goods and services before a fringe benefits tax becomes payable by anybody. Thirdly, he has exaggerated the rental value of a cottage on a property and ignored the fact that in a remote area a concession of 40 per cent of the real rental value would be allowable on the fringe benefits tax. Fourthly, he has ignored a similar 40 per cent concession on the cost of gas and electricity in a remote area for determining the fringe benefits tax.
