Fifthly, he has dealt less than even-handedly with the question of driving children to catch the school bus in a farm vehicle. Fringe benefits tax in respect of private use of company vehicles will be assessed according to a formula which may, in some cases, allow a generous concession for private use. If it does not, the option is there to keep a log book and pay the fringe benefits tax only for that proportion of the number of kilometres covered for private purposes.

Using these distorted figures, McLachlan has then gone back to his original corrupt thesis and suggested that the family company is being taxed twice on the fringe benefit because it has to pay the fringe benefits tax and it cannot claim it as a deduction. That ignores the deductions available to the family company for the expenses it incurs in making available the fringe benefits tax. It also ignores, of course, the principle to which Senator Colston drew attention-that is, that income tax is not deductible for income tax purposes. McLachlan says that it is a new tax on employment and a further tax on farm production costs when it is actually only replacing the existing tax regime and is not adding to the production costs of those who had not chosen under the old system to ignore this element of their tax liabilities, nor will it affect the 80 per cent of farmers who do not have full time employees at all.

Finally, McLachlan has exhorted the family company farmer not to fill in the form sent out by the Australian Taxation Office. What did that form ask for? It asked for the company's name, address and whether it provided fringe benefits and would therefore be subject to the tax. Why did the Taxation Office want that information? It wanted it so that it could keep the relevant people clearly informed about the tax. From what I have said, that is the last thing McLachlan and, by implication, the National Farmers Federation would want.

I regret to say that McLachlan in recent times has degenerated into a right wing ratbag who is calling for mass defiance of the law of the land. It would not be going too far to describe him as a proto-fascist. He is also weak on reasoning. I recall his specious argument at the Tax Summit last year when he said that if a capital gains tax were introduced it would be very difficult to attract new capital into long term low yield investments such as agriculture, which begs the fact: Why would any rational and responsible government want to attract new capital into long term low yield investments?

As Senator Chaney said of the people who are calling for mass defiance of the law, as McLachlan is, they are emulating the most lawless elements of the trade union movement, by which I presume Senator Chaney meant the Builders Labourers Federation, which this Government and the Labor governments of New South Wales and Victoria have moved to deregister. McLachlan is Normie Gallagher in moleskins and R. M. Williams boots. Finally, given his cheap jibe at public servants in Canberra last year, I remind McLachlan and all the others that I had calluses on my hands as a farmer when he was learning to play cricket on St Peter's oval.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not possible to let that last diatribe pass without some comment. The Opposition has no objection to Senator Walsh raising, by way of rebuttal, matters of fact. If he believes he is right on the facts and if he comes in with force and vigour to demolish an argument, that is all right. I agree with Senator Walsh when he decries anyone who calls for mass disobedience of the law. However much I might dislike a law, or however much we might have fought to prevent something going through the Parliament, once it is the law of the land we expect it to be observed by all citizens. Having done those things, having responded on a matter of fact, Senator Walsh cannot resist going back to the form of behaviour which has characterised him over the years; that is, within the Parliament, using the privilege of the Parliament free from any possibility of actions for defamation, and under the coward's castle privilege available to him to say about a citizen who has no redress, who has no way of responding and who has no rights in this place, things which are personally denigrating, which have nothing to do with the facts of the matter he raised and which are just the manifestations of a particularly unpleasant and warped personality. Whatever the facts of the argument Senator Walsh wanted to demolish there is no reason at all for this Minister to have called McLachlan-I missed the exact words-some kind of fascist. If Senator Walsh did that outside this place there would be a defamation writ on him as quick as he wants. If he is any kind of man, if he wants to get up and parade his credentials, he should repeat outside this place the words which he is so ready to utter inside while protected by the privilege of Parliament. If he wants to call him a Normie Gallagher, let him say it outside. If he wants to call him a fascist, let him say it outside and give him the opportunity to take from the Minister some of the thousands of dollars which he would collect. It is not for nothing that we on this side of the chamber have put down contingent notices of motion which relate to Senator Walsh's continued abuse, if not of the Standing Orders of the Parliament, at least of the canons of good taste. He is an embarrassment to this Parliament and tonight he has given one more example of why most of us hold him in contempt.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 18 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations offer funding to the States during 1984 for nurse refresher training courses under the Skills in Demand program.
(2) What has been the individual reaction of each of the 6 States to the Commonwealth offer.
(3) How much was offered to Queensland in financial terms, and under what conditions.
(4) Is there a shortage of trained nurses in several areas of Queensland.
(5) Are negotiations on the offer to Queensland still continuing between the Department and the Queensland Government; if so, what is the current state of progress.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) All States, except Queensland, have entered into agreements with the Commonwealth and undertaken nurse refresher training courses under the Skills in Demand (SID) program. From 1 January 1986 SID was subsumed under the National Skills Shortage component of the new Adult Training Program.

(3) The offer of nurse refresher training assistance to the States, including Queensland, was not made in financial terms. The offer of SID assistance was based on the States developing, in consultation with the relevant nursing unions, integrated State-wide training arrangements, involving each State making a significant contribution and guaranteeing jobs for successful graduates. The costing of the Commonwealth's financial contribution to the training is negotiated according to the training arrangements developed in each State.

(4) While there may not be a generalised nursing shortage in Queensland, there is evidence that shortages may be emerging in particular local areas and in certain specialist nursing occupations, such as intensive care.
(5) The Queensland Minister for Health has been invited to reconsider his attitude to Queensland's participation in nurse refresher training arrangements with the Commonwealth.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The total amount of CEP funds provided is $1.4 million.
(2) Yes.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Community Employment Program: Revenue Raising Activities

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 18 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have any projects involving revenue raising activities been sponsored under the Community Employment Program (CEP); if so, which projects.
(2) What was the total revenue raised in 1984-85 and what is the forecast revenue raising in 1985-86.
(3) What has happened to any revenue raised under CEP sponsored activities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As at 21 April 1986, some 732 Community Employment Program (CEP) projects, or 4% of the total of nearly 18,300 approved projects, had indicated a `revenue raising' component. Such an indication by project sponsors has normally been on the basis that it was to be of a secondary nature and incidental to the projects' primary objectives.

Precise information on revenue raised by projects is not available, and to collect it would require a substantial investment of resources by State and Territory Government officials, who are responsible for monitoring and financial control of individual projects. The following broad types of `revenue raising' activity can, however, be identified:

(a) Enhancements or extensions to existing facilities, for example, local information centres or community halls which, either through increased tourist spending or payment for use of public facilities, increased or caused the raising of revenue.
(b) Expanded community services, for example, child minding, youth co-ordinator, counselling services, involving a set or nominal fee for service.

(c) Development of community services or special interest training courses or workshops, for example, technology, theatre production, catering services, possibly involving `enrolment fees' but generally aimed at enhancing participants' subsequent employment and hence income earning capacity.
(d) Promotional activities involving fund raising for non-profit community organisations, for example, family planning, paraplegic and surf lifesaving associations.
It is not possible to more clearly identify specific direct revenue raising projects, distinct from the general project types listed above, given the information available.

(2) and (3) The State and Territory Government partners in the joint administration of the CEP, rather than the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, are responsible for the financial monitoring of approved projects. I am therefore not in a position to answer these parts of the honourable senator's question.

It should be noted, however, that the CEP guidelines only allow funding of projects involving revenue raising activities on the condition that no private appropriation of revenue or assets occurs at either the level of individual CEP participants or members of sponsoring organisations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science, upon notice, on 27 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the basis for complaint by Colonial Sugar Refinery Limited about the film ``Too Much of a Good Thing'' made by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization (CSIRO).
(2) What led the CSIRO to make that film.
(3) What is the attitude of the Government to domestic levels of sugar consumption in the light of the present difficulties facing sugar cane farmers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The National Marketing Manager of CSR complained about the use made in the film of an excerpt from a sugar industry television advertisement. He also questioned certain matters of fact contained in the film. CSIRO is of the view that the use of the excerpt was a fair dealing within the meaning of the Copyright Act. CSIRO believes the information given in the film is correct and is in the best interests of the Australian community.

(2) The film was produced by CSIRO as part of its public awareness activities. CSIRO has a duty to bring important facts based on research to the attention of the public. The intention of the film was to show how a balanced diet can contribute significantly to community well-being and the reduction of chronic disease. The film has had strong support from professional nutritionists and the endorsement of the Australian Nutrition Foundation and the Chairman of the Diet and Heart Disease Committee of the National Heart Foundation.

(3) The Government is sympathetic to the present difficulties facing the sugar industry and the Minister for Primary Industry announced on 15 April 1986 a range of measures to assist the industry. The Government does not have an official view on levels of consumption of sugar by individuals in the domestic market.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 March 1986, Senator Watson asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, a question without notice concerning the participation of women in community employment program projects, particularly on labouring work normally carried out by men. I undertook to seek further information from the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. The Minister has provided the following response:

ANSWER.PARA: The Community Employment Program (CEP) has been implemented as an equity program in which equal access to jobs for both males and females is an objective, specified in the guidelines.

As women have historically been restricted to a narrow range of jobs, it was clear that the CEP's equity objective would not be realised, and women would be under-represented on the Program, if CEP were to be conducted without consideration being given to overcoming this imbalance. Consequently, it was determined that females would be given the opportunity to be selected for a broader range of jobs, including those considered to be non-traditional work. This is not a matter of compulsion, but rather one of presenting females with a conscious choice of wider job opportunities.

The CEP's aim of promoting equal access for men and women to the full range of occupations is being realised, in part through developing women's interest in work outside the traditional female areas. To this end a 25% female target was instituted in the Jobs on Local Roads component of CEP in 1984. During 1984-85, around 34% of jobs in major construction, kerbing/road/drainage, water supply and storage, forestry, agriculture, and conservation were filled by females. During that period females accounted for approximately 46% of all CEP jobs.

Government policy on affirmative action and the affirmative action legislation introduced into Parliament this year have, as a main objective, the increase of women's occupational mobility into a broader range of jobs. The CEP may be seen to be directly in line with the principles of affirmative action.

Further, recognition of the importance of encouraging women to take on non-traditional work has been accorded by State Governments through the granting of special provisions and exemptions under their anti-discrimination legislation.
